headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CF Industries Holdings Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Shannon, and I will be your  coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the prese
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CF Industries Holdings Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Shannon, and I will be your  coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today, Mr. Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, please proceed.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Shannon. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings Inc. I'm Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations. And with me today are Tony Will, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Dennis Kelleher,
componenttext:
Thanks, Shannon. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings Inc. I'm Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations. And with me today are Tony Will, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Dennis Kelleher, our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Bert Frost, our Senior Vice President of Sales, Distribution and Market Development; and Chris Bohn, our Senior Vice President of Manufacturing. 
CF Industries Holdings Inc. reported its fourth quarter 2015 results yesterday afternoon, as did Terra Nitrogen Company, L.P. On this call we will review the CF Industries results in detail and discuss our outlook, referring to several of the slides that are posted on our website. At the end of the call, we'll host a question-and-answer session. 
As you review the news releases posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at cfindustries.com, and as you listen to this conference call, please recognize that they contain forward-looking statements as defined by Federal Securities Laws. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed on Slide 3 of the accompanying presentation, and from time to time with the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today and the company assumes obligation to update any forward-looking statements. 
This conference call will include discussion of certain non-GAAP financial measures, and each case a presentation of the most directly comparable financial measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP and coinciding reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measure to the most directly comparable measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP are provided in the earnings release and the slides in the webcast presentation on the company's website, www.cfindustries.com. 
Now let me introduce Tony Will, our President and CEO.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Last time we posted fourth quarter and full year results for 2015. For the fourth quarter, CF Industries generated EBITDA of $254 million and full year EBITDA of $1.7 billion. After taking into account hedging loss
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Last time we posted fourth quarter and full year results for 2015. For the fourth quarter, CF Industries generated EBITDA of $254 million and full year EBITDA of $1.7 billion. After taking into account hedging losses, an impairment loss on our Trinidad joint venture equity investment, costs related to both the CF strategic venture and the OCI transaction and expenses related to the project, adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter was $451 million and adjusted EBITDA for the full year was $2 billion.
Despite difficult market conditions, we generated gross margin of over 25% of the fourth quarter and over 35% for the year. If not for the unrealized mark-to-market losses of roughly $100 million of natural gas hedges, our gross margin for the fourth quarter would've been approximately 34%. And if not for the unrealized mark-to-market losses of approximately $175 million, our gross margin for the full year was roughly 40%.
Our quarterly and full year results continue to demonstrate the cash-generating capability of this company. We consistently deliver solid results because of our cost advantage position within the industry, despite the fact that the global fertilizer market is oversupplied. 
In several production regions of the world, currency devaluations and other factors have reduced costs for high-cost producers, some of which have continued to run despite negative margins, leading to excess the supply. As a result, there has been downward pressure on prices. Urea transactions have been reported at price levels not seen in a decade. However, even against this backdrop, we still delivered full year adjusted EBITDA of $2 billion. 
Our business is not like other commodities. It shares little to nothing with iron, steel, copper or coal. A country or region with a slowing economy may stop building skyscrapers, ships and highways, but it's people still need to eat. Global nitrogen demand remains strong and growing. To be sure there is excess supply, that we occupy the lowest cost position in the industry and continue to generate significant cash.
All commodities are not created equal, and it is critically important to keep our perspective on the underlying fundamentals of our business as distinct from others.
First, several weeks ago, there were reports of urea trading in the U.S. Gulf at or below $200 per short ton [ph]. While some business was done at this level, the volume was extremely thin because these prices were well below the replacement cost for the marginal producers. As we suspected all along, available volume was scarce and just 2 weeks later, urea is now reported trading in the range of $250 per ton [ph], up more than 25% from the beginning of February.
Second, we have seen a decrease in both Chinese exports and urea plant operating rates. The most recent industry publications for the Chinese fertilizer market indicate that operating rates for coal-based urea producers have declined 66 [ph] -- to 66% in January from 73% in December. While that may not sound like a large amount, the 7-point drop in Chinese operating rates equates to a reduction of approximately 6 million tons of urea on an annual basis. These facts are just to us the previously published prices are not sustainable. 
Third, even at the $200 per ton price trough published in January, a typical U.S. Gulf producer of urea generates roughly 50% cash margins. This is driven by low-cost North American natural gas, providing us the sustainable advantage versus producers in other regions, further bolstered by the import-dependent nature of North America.
While it should be obvious that the sky is not falling, that nitrogen is not like other commodities and that our business remains highly attractive and continues to generate significant cash. 
Turning to our strategic initiatives, we have made significant progress and are now in full delivery mode. Since our last earnings call, we amended our announced business combination with OCI's European, North American and global trading distribution businesses to incorporate in and become a tax resident of the Netherlands. We expect to close this transaction in the middle of 2016. 
We commenced our strategic venture with CHS, receiving a $2.8 billion payment and have begun shipping product in our supply agreement. 
We have also entered the final stages of our capacity expansion projects. The Donaldsonville urea plant has been in production since November of last year. The plant is mechanically complete and in the process of being commissioned, and we expect the welding and piping work on the ammonia plant, which represents the majority of the remaining work and cost, to be completed within the next 8 weeks. 
We also expect Port Neal to be mechanically complete in the second quarter of 2016, meaning all of our spending on this projects will very soon be behind us. The total costs for both projects remains in line with our previous estimates, and similarly our projected returns for the projects have not changed. 
I will now turn the call over to Bert and Dennis to go through the details of the quarter, and then I'll wrap up with some perspectives on strategy in the longer-term outlook. Bert?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. The global nitrogen market continues to be supplied driven with increased availability of internationally sourced product pressuring prices. During the fourth quarter prices for all fertilizer products declined including nitrogen. Excess sup
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. The global nitrogen market continues to be supplied driven with increased availability of internationally sourced product pressuring prices. During the fourth quarter prices for all fertilizer products declined including nitrogen. Excess supply around the world and new capacity coming online all helped to push the market lower. Urea prices declined throughout the quarter, decreasing from a high of $260 per short ton FOB at the beginning of the quarter to $220 per short ton FOB NOLA at the end of the quarter. As Tony said, very little business were done at these lower levels as the market was highly illiquid. During the fourth quarter, the Chinese government allowed the yuan to devalue further, continuing trend that began in the third quarter 2015. 
On accounting for the devaluation, along with the decrease in coal prices and continued weakness in ocean freight, cash cost of urea production for the marginal Chinese anthracite coal-based producer are now estimated to be near the seasonal low of roughly $225 per short ton delivered to the U.S. Gulf. As Tony mentioned, production rates in China are declining, and some high-cost producers have already curtailed production or shut down altogether. 
Exports out of China were 1.5 million tons lower in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to the same period in 2014. For the full year 2015, exports totaled approximately 13.8 million tons, which is slightly higher than the full year 2014. 
In the U.S., industrial ammonia demand was impacted by lower phosphate production and the fourth quarter agricultural ammonia application season was negatively impacted by weather. Warm weather into early November, coupled with a combination of rain and snow later that month, limited most of the Midwest from getting applications completed. In addition, customers were reluctant to buy urea in much of the fourth quarter due to the prospect of lower prices in the future. 
So weather-related disruption of the fourth quarter ammonia application season, along with the late purchases of UAN and urea during the fourth quarter should lead to a larger than average spring demand and a corresponding rebound in prices as nitrogen fertilizer must be applied on an annual basis.
Ahead of spring, the company's well-positioned with inventory prepared to serve key markets. Nitrogen fertilizer demand in North America is expected to remain steady in 2016 compared to 2015. Current projected returns for the 2016 crop, based on new crop futures, continue to favor corn planting over soybeans. As a result, 2016 corn planting is expected to reach approximately 90.5 million acres, which is a 2.5 million acre increase from 2015. 
North American natural gas continues to provide the company a substantial cost advantage compared to other global producers. The North American natural gas market began the fourth quarter of 2015 with minimal price movement and lower volatility. However, that quickly turned into a sharp downward shift in prices in the latter half of October. Stronger than expected El Niño conditions brought warmer weather that continued through much of the quarter and was a large contributor to the significant decrease in gas demand. Natural gas consumption North America for residential and commercial uses during the fourth quarter of 2015 was 16% lower in the fourth quarter of -- end of the fourth quarter of 2014. Despite the continued decrease in rig count, gas production continued at record levels during the fourth quarter and the storage balance in North America reached a record level of 4 trillion cubic feet at the end of the injection season. 
Now let me turn the call over to Dennis.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bert. In the fourth quarter we generated $254 million of EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $0.11. Included in these results were approximately a $98 million unrealized mark-to-market loss on our natural gas hedges, a $62 million loss for an
componenttext:
Thanks, Bert. In the fourth quarter we generated $254 million of EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $0.11. Included in these results were approximately a $98 million unrealized mark-to-market loss on our natural gas hedges, a $62 million loss for an impairment of our PLNL joint venture equity investment, $20 million in transaction costs related to the OCI transaction and the CHS strategic venture, $15 million in expansion costs for our Donaldsonville and Port Neal facilities, and a $3 million loss on our foreign currency hedges. When taking these items into account, our adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter was $451 million and our adjusted earnings per diluted share was $0.76. 
For the year we generated $1.7 billion in EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $2.96. Our adjusted EBITDA was $2 billion and our adjusted net earnings per diluted share was $3.88. Our realized natural gas cost for the quarter was $3.07 per MMBtu and consisted of purchased natural gas of $2.66 per MMBtu and a realized loss of $0.41 per MMBtu on our natural gas hedges for the fourth quarter of 2015. Our natural gas cost has declined by 25% when compared to fourth quarter of 2014.  For the full year 2015, our realized natural gas cost was also $3.07 per MMBtu, a 28% reduction compared to 2014. 
During the fourth quarter, the company did not enter into any additional natural gas hedges. 
The company completed a review of its equity method investments and Point Lisas Nitrogen Limited, PLNL, our 50% investment in an ammonia production joint venture located in the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. This review assessed the recoverability of the company's carrying value of the investment. 
During the fourth quarter of 2015, the company recognized an impairment charge of $62 million relating to its investment in PLNL due to continuing gas curtailments from the government-controlled gas supplier and the expectation is that these curtailments will continue. 
On December 18, 2015, the protecting Americans from tax hikes, [indiscernible], was signed into law and applies to tax years' 2015 through 2019. One of the provisions of that ad permits companies to deduct 50% of their capital expenditures for federal income tax purposes in the year qualifying assets are placed into service. As a result of this provision, for the year ended December 31, 2015, the company recorded a federal tax receivable of approximately $120 million that is expected to result in a tax refund. This receivable is primarily associated with new urea plants and related offsites that were placed into service at the companies at Donaldsonville and Louisiana complex during November of 2015.
In 2016, the company expects to place into service the new UAN and ammonia plants at Donaldsonville and a new urea and ammonia plant at Port Neal. Most of these assets will also qualify for the 50% bonus depreciation for fiscal year 2016. As a result of these additional assets being placed into service in 2016, the company expects to have significantly reduced cash tax payments for the year.
For the full year of 2015, our total capital expenditures were approximately $2.5 billion. This consists of approximately $1.7 billion for the capacity expansion projects plus approximately $600 million of sustaining improvement and other capital expenditures and $155 million of capitalized interest. 
For 2016, the company expects to have capital expenditures of approximately $1.8 billion, of which $1.2 billion will be for capacity expansion projects and $600 million will be for sustaining, improvement and other projects. 
With that, Tony will provide some closing remarks before we open the call to Q&A.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dennis. Before we move onto Q&A, I wanted to review our near and longer-term outlook and the significant benefits of our strategic initiatives. As we have already discussed, our business continues its strong operating performance, delivering $2
componenttext:
Thanks, Dennis. Before we move onto Q&A, I wanted to review our near and longer-term outlook and the significant benefits of our strategic initiatives. 
As we have already discussed, our business continues its strong operating performance, delivering $2 billion of adjusted EBITDA in 2015. Looking at the fundamentals, cash margins for North American producers are in the 50% to 60% range even with today's market conditions. Against this healthy backdrop, over the next roughly 6 months, we are about to grow significantly, adding 60% new production capacity to our portfolio with very similar margin structures to our current business. 
We are investment-grade and have a very strong balance sheet, having just received $2.8 billion in cash. Our spending on the capacity expansion projects is quickly coming to an end as we expect to be fully mechanically complete within the second quarter. Our business combination with OCI is expected to deliver roughly $500 million annually in after-tax, full run rate benefits. And we expect our longer-term effective tax rate to drop from 35% into the low 20s, making us that much more efficient at converting EBITDA into cash.
Finally, bonus depreciation will provide a significant cash flow benefit this year. 
The bright future we've been talking about is arriving now. This is a lot of very positive change all being delivered in a short period of time. However, one thing is constant through it all, and that is our focused strategy for driving total shareholder returns. Our goal is to grow cash generation per share and our capital allocation philosophy flows from that. We first look to grow our cash generation, the numerator in the equation. We do that with investments that have risk-adjusted rates of return well above our cost of capital and only if they drive cash flow per share accretion. Otherwise, we look to reduce our outstanding share count, thereby reducing the denominator of the equation. 
Consistent with our past actions, all excess cash will be returned to shareholders. While we are fully committed to maintaining our solid investment-grade credit rating, as we look forward we believe there will be significant cash available for deployment. We will do that consistent with our singular goal of growing cash generation per share just like we have in the past. 
I want to end today's call by thanking all of our employees who have worked so hard, not only on all of our strategic initiatives, but also keeping the core CF business running so strongly on a daily basis while delivering our best ever safety performance, a truly remarkable accomplishment. Many of the steps we have taken are already showing results, and I am excited that the next 6 months should see all of our initiatives move from planning and development into actually delivering cash flow to the bottom line. 
With that, we will now open the line to answer your questions. Operator.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Ben Isaacson with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Ben Isaacson with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Carl Chen stepping in for Ben. So we have seen an incredible rally in the urea prices over the past weeks, owing to the prospect of an early spring. Can you please also comment on your expectation for the string of ammonia and UAN pricing recovery
componenttext: This is Carl Chen stepping in for Ben. So we have seen an incredible rally in the urea prices over the past weeks, owing to the prospect of an early spring. Can you please also comment on your expectation for the string of ammonia and UAN pricing recovery, given that most have decided to curtail that production in Q1, and this early spring could reduce the need for UAN?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to ask [indiscernible] to take that question, but one observation you talked about that incredible rally in area, I mean the observation that I think that a lot of us around the table would make is that the trough pricing that was supported in J
componenttext: I'm going to ask [indiscernible] to take that question, but one observation you talked about that incredible rally in area, I mean the observation that I think that a lot of us around the table would make is that the trough pricing that was supported in January was a little bit artificial. It doesn't really reflect where the market has any kind of liquidity or volume. And that's one of the reasons why it looks like it come back because the minute there was demand, it rebounded to what the real value of the product is. But Bert, you want to handle the..

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do think about the urea market, it has recovered from more of a normal price range and I think we had an anomaly like you said. Very few margins were traded at those lower levels and we know that because we entered the market to buy a few and they were
componenttext: I do think about the urea market, it has recovered from more of a normal price range and I think we had an anomaly like you said. Very few margins were traded at those lower levels and we know that because we entered the market to buy a few and they were not there. I do anticipate we are seeing now probably the opportunity for an early Spring. Applications have already begun in the Southwest Texas and Oklahoma. And the temperature this weekend are very conducive to continue that activity. And I think you see that's alarming trend move through drying trend throughout the Midwest. I would think that within the month in the upper Midwest that being Nebraska, Iowa, we may even seek applications beginning then. You are correct that a lot of the ammonia stays within the producers hands and is available to the customers, those being the retailers who sell to the farmers their application. And I think the order trend has been a little bit different than in previous years, but the feedback we're getting from our customers is that there will be a significant demand. We lost a lot of ammonia applications in the fall just due to the weather issues we articulated. And so do that end will still needed to be applied. And so as you move that to Spring, we'll need to record ammonia season in order to fill some of that nitrogen demand, which I think will be difficult. And so for your comment on UAN, we believe that's going to fall, either to urea or both urea and UAN. And we're positioning our products and our terminals with our customers for that eventuality. We're seeing a pretty healthy market going forward for nitrogen on the demand side and a parallel positive position for pricing going into and through spring and even on the back half.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. Maybe just a follow-up question. We have seen reports indicate Chinese urea producers are producing low-cost and stockpiling in anticipation of a strong spring application similar to last year. Now if the spring application disappoints in China,
componenttext: Perfect. Maybe just a follow-up question. We have seen reports indicate Chinese urea producers are producing low-cost and stockpiling in anticipation of a strong spring application similar to last year. Now if the spring application disappoints in China, do you have a sense of how the residual inventory can wait on urea prices abroad?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Today, the indications we're getting out of China are that the terminal and the port inventories are lower than normal, and that makes economic sense. As what we said in the comments with, we believe that the Chinese producers, a majority of them, had bee
componenttext: Today, the indications we're getting out of China are that the terminal and the port inventories are lower than normal, and that makes economic sense. As what we said in the comments with, we believe that the Chinese producers, a majority of them, had been operating at or below cost. There's very little incentive for them to push product to the ports. So we're seeing the Chinese industry operate rationally and according to economic principles. Eventually gravity does work even in China. And so when you look at the day, what's going on in China, [indiscernible] has begun in China. And you're seeing product move into those markets. Today, the domestic price is better and the incentive then is for the Chinese producer, the urea producer to keep that product moving to the interior and then they'll probably look to the export market as we move through spring. Today, if you loaded a Chinese vessel, let's say March 1st, and we're sending that to the United States to New Orleans, there would probably be a 45-day voyage and discharge arriving in mid- to late April. And you're starting to get a little bit late. There have been Chinese vessels in the spring and we think they'll arrived in late March through early April. But once you get past April, it's difficult to have that product be applied for the spring and post planting season.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttextpreview: Bert, do you have an estimate of how much nitrogen inventory is in the retail channel now and how does that compare to storage levels for mid-February?
componenttext: Bert, do you have an estimate of how much nitrogen inventory is in the retail channel now and how does that compare to storage levels for mid-February?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It is a little bit anecdotal, but we do spend a lot of time trying to determine what physical inventory position is, whether that be dry on urea or UAN in the tanks. Most of the ammonia sitting with us or with other producers in the terminal system throug
componenttext: It is a little bit anecdotal, but we do spend a lot of time trying to determine what physical inventory position is, whether that be dry on urea or UAN in the tanks. Most of the ammonia sitting with us or with other producers in the terminal system throughout the Midwest. And so what we know, just based on imports and production levels of UAN, we expect that those levels are lower than historical, due to the fact that we trended into fertilizer year 2015 [ph] at a low level of inventory entering that season, and then the production and imports together with that build our number. On urea, I think there is sufficient inventory to begin the season. You can look at the import numbers and then again at the production numbers and our production numbers. So there is enough probably imposition, but it is in the right position. And then the second round of product that needs to be available and I think that's why you've seen this rally to scramble to get product in position.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how would you characterize those customers of yours? Are they fully engaged now in the building inventory for what you describe as that second round? Or are some of them still on the sidelines?
componenttext: And how would you characterize those customers of yours? Are they fully engaged now in the building inventory for what you describe as that second round? Or are some of them still on the sidelines?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's like a family. Everybody has a different opinion when you sit around and talk politics. Same thing about inventory on fertilizer. We participated in the TSI and that was the majority of customers. And we had the whole range of opinions of I'm not goi
componenttext: It's like a family. Everybody has a different opinion when you sit around and talk politics. Same thing about inventory on fertilizer. We participated in the TSI and that was the majority of customers. And we had the whole range of opinions of I'm not going to buy until the farmer comes into purchase and they'll pay the appropriate price at that time to those who have prepared and were anticipating. And so we're working with each of our customers and their risk level or their risk appetite, and some of that inventory has stayed with us and we're quite fine with that. Because we believe in the size of the spring application season and the need for this product will be probably very robust.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Adam Samuelson from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Adam Samuelson from Goldman Sachs.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe a question on the end market. I mean, you had a pretty good spike in urea in the last 10 days or so, I don't know. Tony you said today it was depressed in January and there was very little volume there. But at the same time, the UAN market trended d
componenttext: Maybe a question on the end market. I mean, you had a pretty good spike in urea in the last 10 days or so, I don't know. Tony you said today it was depressed in January and there was very little volume there. But at the same time, the UAN market trended down in conjunction with urea. And I felt like spot pricing, I would say that urea is trading at a premium on an end value basis, which seems unusual. So I'm trying to think about A, how your order book on UAN looks prospectively given there's less dependence on imports there; and B, how you think about the balance between the 2 products on an end value basis as we go into the spring.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: You did see a movement in UAN in January. We readjusted our -- or adjusted our prices at that point. But the urea market stayed very steadily -- steady July through into January. And there was a reflection on it end basis at that time to move UAN more in
componenttext: You did see a movement in UAN in January. We readjusted our -- or adjusted our prices at that point. But the urea market stayed very steadily -- steady July through into January. And there was a reflection on it end basis at that time to move UAN more in line with urea. But as you see urea move up, we've seen a demand build for UAN. And we believe that will continue through spring. UAN is a great product. It's so versatile and how it can be used, not only in wheat and corn. And so I do believe that you're going to see a price increase or value increase going into spring for UAN as well.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if you look at your own order book today versus prior year's on UAN, would you say you're ahead of last year, behind last year? Or any comments there?
componenttext: And if you look at your own order book today versus prior year's on UAN, would you say you're ahead of last year, behind last year? Or any comments there?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Every year is different. It's more you can be ahead or behind I'm not sure if that's as meaningful value associated with the product in the gas price. So we're pretty excited about the level that we're able to buy our feedstock. And I would think that the
componenttext: Every year is different. It's more you can be ahead or behind I'm not sure if that's as meaningful value associated with the product in the gas price. So we're pretty excited about the level that we're able to buy our feedstock. And I would think that these lower levels is not as attractive to us to sell, and so we would prefer to wait for some appreciation.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Vincent Andrew from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Vincent Andrew from Morgan Stanley.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Neil Kumar calling in for Vincent. I was just wondering if you can speak about some of the inputs you're assuming to build up to the marginal cost figure of $225 [ph] per short ton, specifically in terms of anthracite, coal prices, freight. And al
componenttext: This is Neil Kumar calling in for Vincent. I was just wondering if you can speak about some of the inputs you're assuming to build up to the marginal cost figure of $225 [ph] per short ton, specifically in terms of anthracite, coal prices, freight. And also can you just talk about how these inputs have changed from 3QS net of marginal cost of $2.50 [ph] to $2.85 [ph] per short ton.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Dennis. In this slide talking about this in the deck. What we've done here is basically what we look at basically all of the cost that exist at the plant site, plus all of the cost, and includes the cost to ship the coal to it, the plants th
componenttext: Sure. This is Dennis. In this slide talking about this in the deck. What we've done here is basically what we look at basically all of the cost that exist at the plant site, plus all of the cost, and includes the cost to ship the coal to it, the plants that incurred, the cost at the plant site that are incurred and the cost to ship that product to the port and then, obviously, to load it on the port so that it can be loaded in both ships to the U.S. Gulf. So all of that input from the coal mine all the way through the product arriving at the U.S. Gulf are included here. And what we do is on a regular basis, we're going to update that for everything from Chinese exchange rates to Chinese coal costs, in addition to that freight rate. And we do this across the curve. And so what's happened if you look at sort of where we come to is as you've seen a decline in coal prices but you've also seen a decline in the R&D exchange rate and we've also seen a decline in shipping rates. And so that's what accounts for sort of the shift downward and what we call the seasonal floor price range. And I want to be clear that this is a seasonal floor price range because we're seeing its $2.25 [ph] to $2.70 [ph]. But we do perhaps differently from the way other producers look at it is we look at the fluctuations and monthly offtake for urea. And so during low periods, you'll see lower prices like we've seen here in January and February. And then during high periods like when you get into the spring, it takes more dollars to bid the more expensive marginal producers into the market. But that's basically how we do this. We look at each of the buyers here in the cost curve and we will update that. With respect to China, we've got a lot of insight because studies that we've done on a plant by plant basis, and so we will update the cost on a plant-by-plant basis for the various subsets of their producers.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the leverage front, we're still 2x to 2.5x. I think as we get through the OCI transaction and reduce our effective tax rate, you could argue that the same amount of EBITDA actually goes farther because we're much more efficient at converting EBITDA int
componenttext: On the leverage front, we're still 2x to 2.5x. I think as we get through the OCI transaction and reduce our effective tax rate, you could argue that the same amount of EBITDA actually goes farther because we're much more efficient at converting EBITDA into cash. So you could see maybe another half turn of additional leverage that we can take on. So somewhere in the 2x to 3x range, I think, is probably reasonable. But we haven't socialized that necessarily with all of the rating agencies and so forth. And our view is always we want to maintain solid investment-grade rating, but have an efficient balance sheet. So we're going to thread the needle on those 2 constraints.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: So as we talked about in the past, there is a closing condition for nat gasoline. It has projects in the [indiscernible]. It is a very difficult project in the marketplace out there right now. And so in the last that was able to satisfy the closing condition or we otherwise waive it then nat gasoline would be excluded from the deal. So we're not in a position right now where it's decision time line any of that. But the closing condition are pretty clearly spelled out. That's one of the reasons the lack of projects in the was one of the reasons along with comments that we received from the SEC that in the last 4 filing that we made mage, which you saw was an assumption that the nat gasoline was not part of the deal, with a footnote that it could be included and that reflects just the status of financing on that project.

componenttext: And then a couple of updates. Can you talk about Vertigris, some of the outages there? And then also a lot of trade general reports that perhaps as the new capacity at Eagles come up, there's been some issues with that production. Are there any issues that you can speak of?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very happy with the new plant at Donaldsonville. It's running well. And I don't know how people drew that conclusion that the plant is running well. I think it's mentioned, we saw overpricing was rating on urea but at that level, we're buyers, not s
componenttext: We're very happy with the new plant at Donaldsonville. It's running well. And I don't know how people drew that conclusion that the plant is running well. I think it's mentioned, we saw overpricing was rating on urea but at that level, we're buyers, not sellers. Our decision to go and grab a few barges had nothing to do with the problem. It was all about the intrinsic value of the product versus where it was rating. So Chris, I let you talk about it.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on your forward order book. I noticed your customer advances were down 50% in dollar terms year-over-year. I assume your forward order book volumes were down even more. And Tony, you made a reference to some barges you're buying in intrins
componenttext: Just a question on your forward order book. I noticed your customer advances were down 50% in dollar terms year-over-year. I assume your forward order book volumes were down even more. And Tony, you made a reference to some barges you're buying in intrinsic value. It seems you've been more aggressive in buying out barges this year, where you think the price is attractive. Is that an accurate assessment?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, Don, that we haven't done that historically. And so even if we were to buy 1 or 2 barges, that would be by definition more aggressive than we've been in the past. We just look at the numbers and said this price makes no sense. We have more than e
componenttext: I'd say, Don, that we haven't done that historically. And so even if we were to buy 1 or 2 barges, that would be by definition more aggressive than we've been in the past. We just look at the numbers and said this price makes no sense. We have more than enough demand to accommodate us bringing on some barges. So we're in the mode of wanting to vacuum some of that up. I'll ask Bert to comment on the forward order book.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things on the forward order book. On the price differentials of this spring compared to last spring, it would be $100 per product change. So that's just on the aggregate dollar terms that you mentioned. But having a forward order book or not h
componenttext: A couple of things on the forward order book. On the price differentials of this spring compared to last spring, it would be $100 per product change. So that's just on the aggregate dollar terms that you mentioned. But having a forward order book or not having a forward order book to me is a reflection of your view of the market. We do -- we are interested in selling. We had a plant and logistical asset that we need to maintain and move. So there is an incentive, matter of fact, there is a requirement to make sure that, that happens. However, that's also compared or contrasted against what the market is offering and the view that we think the market is going to improve. So the incentive to have a forward order book in January and December just wasn't there. And we have the capability to hold that product and inventory or change the production mix or export products. And so we're able to maintain and move through those periods a lot better than I think we used to, and that's what you're seeing to me it reflected in that number rather than a desire to be out there, build the order book at lower prices.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: So most of the recent price line up should be realized as I go forward and contrast the last urea locked in more forward business?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Matthew Korn from Barclays.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me ask this. What right now are the most opportune export markets for you today, both in geography and product? I'm wondering if Brazil allowed any development for foundations of UAN market down there. And then just in terms of housekeeping, how much
componenttext: Let me ask this. What right now are the most opportune export markets for you today, both in geography and product? I'm wondering if Brazil allowed any development for foundations of UAN market down there. And then just in terms of housekeeping, how much product did you send offshore this past quarter and this past year?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the export markets, it's the marginal ton or the incremental ton for us at this point. We're in North America, an import market, where we have our assets are well-placed. And when I say asset, that's the whole base, production, logistics,
componenttext: When you look at the export markets, it's the marginal ton or the incremental ton for us at this point. We're in North America, an import market, where we have our assets are well-placed. And when I say asset, that's the whole base, production, logistics, terminals, pipelines to serve the American, North American farmer. And so we want to be active participants in this market and monetize our position here. And then the next step is looking at the export market, because we're adding this new capacity to be a 12-month, 365-day producer of these products, you need to be able to move things out and at times move them out in large quantities. So that's when we look up the specs with markets we're active-duty in France, Belgium, Argentina, Mexico, Brazil on UAN, we've opened up Colombia recently. And so when we're focused on products today, it's predominantly a UAN play. And the next step, we've had some ammonia exports. We work with various people in that market as well as destination consumers. But urea is coming as we bring up -- we brought up the new plant and we moved to the spring, we believe it will be active more in the world urea market. And so I think -- you see our export participation continue to grow and to be an integral part of our business.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'll add to the first comment is particularly when we're through the OCI transaction and have a trading distribution business as part of a whole, our desire to export, will likely increase. And that's one of the reasons that Bert and his te
componenttext: The only thing I'll add to the first comment is particularly when we're through the OCI transaction and have a trading distribution business as part of a whole, our desire to export, will likely increase. And that's one of the reasons that Bert and his team have really been developing some of these market opportunities for us, like UAN to Brazil and Argentina, giving us ready demand and outlets for that product as we go through the OCI deal.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. Let me ask this then. Everyone of course, is focused on currency implications for price risk. But at a different angle, is there any immediate risk you see as a function of China's support? Does that put their domestic planting, the
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. Let me ask this then. Everyone of course, is focused on currency implications for price risk. But at a different angle, is there any immediate risk you see as a function of China's support? Does that put their domestic planting, their nitrogen demand at significant risk and stability to absorb much of it's supply?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, just on the currency devaluation issue, central bank stepped in. They recently provided some exchange-rate pegging that's actually more favorable than we thought things were likely going to go. We thought the exchange could get close to 7 [ph], a
componenttext: Matthew, just on the currency devaluation issue, central bank stepped in. They recently provided some exchange-rate pegging that's actually more favorable than we thought things were likely going to go. We thought the exchange could get close to 7 [ph], and it's kind of pegged and holding steady at 6.51 [ph] or 6.50 [ph]. So from that perspective, I think there is at least as we see today a little bit less risk on the exchange rate side, but Bert, why don't you go and handle that.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when you look at what is going on with corn, price supports and corn production, you see an interesting change over the last 10 to 15 years, as China has outsourced their soybean production to Brazil, Argentina, the United States, and has con
componenttext: Yes, I think when you look at what is going on with corn, price supports and corn production, you see an interesting change over the last 10 to 15 years, as China has outsourced their soybean production to Brazil, Argentina, the United States, and has continued to grow. And with that growth in demand for corn and wheat. And stockpiles of corn aren't high. That has created some perverse incentives. And so you see store of them, those substitute products coming in at a greater level into China. So I think with this release for pricing on corn, you're probably going to see -- you could see maybe a lower level of planting. But again, it's at a pretty high price today with that subsidy. And -- but they also have a fairly low yield. So several things are changing in China. The move to acquire Syngenta, which we believe were the seed technology and germplasm associated with that, and the change possibly to GMO products in China I think we have an evolving situation coupled with a change in the economy, this currency devaluation. All these things together, I think it's a little early to predict what that result will be to nitrogen. But we see each of these steps as positive opening steps and greater participation on the global market, which sustains the price of corn, soybeans and wheat going forward.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mark Connelly with CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two easy questions. You mentioned the prospect of a stronger than normal back half of the year. I'm curious if you expect to carry out more inventory from spring or whether the ramp in new capacity is enough to take care of that? And then the second quest
componenttext: Two easy questions. You mentioned the prospect of a stronger than normal back half of the year. I'm curious if you expect to carry out more inventory from spring or whether the ramp in new capacity is enough to take care of that? And then the second question, I'm assuming you're still unhedged on the European business. I'm wondering if you could talk about your hedging strategy is going to evolve as you pick up OCI?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me make one clarification and I'll ask Bert to pick up that one. I think when we're talking about a stronger, second half of the fertilizer year as opposed to a stronger half of the second half of the calendar year, because what happens was with th
componenttext: So let me make one clarification and I'll ask Bert to pick up that one. I think when we're talking about a stronger, second half of the fertilizer year as opposed to a stronger half of the second half of the calendar year, because what happens was with the low level of application of ammonia in the fall are relatively lighter application, we still see total nitrogen aggregate demand in North America being roughly equivalent to where it was last year. So corn acres are off a bit. Wheat acres are down a bit. Overall, the same amount of nitrogen. But with less going down in the fall, that means more has got to go down in the spring with the same kind of yield. So that's why we're pretty bullish here on the spring application season. I think everyone says the second half of the year, once you get past July 1, that's a complete reset and you start all over again. I don't know that we're taking a strong position on that one. Relative to Europe, yes, we are completely unhedged, both on the U.K. production as well as anything on the continent. And our view historically has been that we hedged in order to take out price volatility, typically associated with weather-related events. And recently here, as we got into last year, we took some longer positions in North America. Obviously those positions are upside down. And as we have kind of stepped back and evaluated our thinking on this, I think you'll see us head more towards our traditional approach, which is hedging is not to try to lock in any particular cost base over a long period of time, but it's really to take out these volatility and possibly get rid of some basis risk.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Chris Parkinson with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Chris Parkinson with Credit Suisse.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you comment on your longer-term expectations regarding the respective cost curves for ammonia and nitrate versus urea? Do you get the regional differences of feedstock cost, FX, et cetera? And then based on this, how do you proceed the average price s
componenttext: Can you comment on your longer-term expectations regarding the respective cost curves for ammonia and nitrate versus urea? Do you get the regional differences of feedstock cost, FX, et cetera? And then based on this, how do you proceed the average price spread in terms of nutrient tons? Do you believe parties will hold or even potentially expand on specifically in the potential event for further UAN depreciation?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, let me start off on kind of the long-term, how we view sort of in-cycle pricing, which is the way that we can evaluate that is based on low-cost gas regions bring on new capacity. New capacity will continue to be added until the next marginal plant
componenttext: Chris, let me start off on kind of the long-term, how we view sort of in-cycle pricing, which is the way that we can evaluate that is based on low-cost gas regions bring on new capacity. New capacity will continue to be added until the next marginal plant only reaches its kind of cost of capital return. And that's the price at which we say kind of long-term mid-cycle prices. Even though feedstock costs have declined, as you've said, one of the things that's helpful in that equation is the fact that capital cost continues to increase. And the lowest-cost gas region right now in terms of that new facility is North America. And if you look at what the cost to bring new production on in North America, it is very high as we know all too well. And the results of that is, we have not seen a dramatic shift in our long-term view of where pricing has to be in order to support a healthy marketplace. It's moving a little bit, but not dramatically. And it's really, the vast majority of cost is on the ammonia making step from a viable cost perspective. And so we believe that you continue to have sort of traditional increases in relative values. The more upgrade you do, because you've got to pay for new capital even though there's not very much variable cost there, you have to pay for the new capital to put in each new step in the upgrade process, and the functionality of UAN stock is greater than urea and whatnot. So each step in the process has to return an appropriate capital and also farm gets more utility out of UAN that they pay a premium for. So we don't see that there being a radical change in terms of the underlying margin or pricing structure between products. And in fact, over the long-term, we don't see a radical change in terms of where we expect product pricing to trend.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, specific to the cost curve, we've looked at the urea cost curve that's the most widely traded fertilizer, nitrogen fertilizer biz. And we look at the cost curve and dial ahead 2018, 2019, Chinese UAN cycle production remains the marginal producer. So
componenttext: Yes, specific to the cost curve, we've looked at the urea cost curve that's the most widely traded fertilizer, nitrogen fertilizer biz. And we look at the cost curve and dial ahead 2018, 2019, Chinese UAN cycle production remains the marginal producer. So from a cost curve perspective, although there will be additions in between substractions, puts and takes at the far right-hand side of the cost curve remains Chinese producers and at the far left-hand side of the cost curve, we believe, maintains North American production, which is where we sit. So we don't see any major shift in terms of what the actual supply curve looks like going forward.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up. Now that it's been roughly 6 months since the announcement of the OCI deal, can you just give a little comment on regarding your compliments in the x tax synergy number across both the U.S. and also European potential? Do you s
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up. Now that it's been roughly 6 months since the announcement of the OCI deal, can you just give a little comment on regarding your compliments in the x tax synergy number across both the U.S. and also European potential? Do you still feel just as comfortable as you did then? Or have there even been new discoveries for potential opportunities?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, as we continue to do meetings and integration planning with our OCI counterparts, we continue to find opportunities and other synergies that were not necessarily previously known. I wouldn't say that all of those are on the tax front. In fact, most
componenttext: Chris, as we continue to do meetings and integration planning with our OCI counterparts, we continue to find opportunities and other synergies that were not necessarily previously known. I wouldn't say that all of those are on the tax front. In fact, most of them are not. They're mostly on the operational side. But there hasn't been any change in law at this point. And so our confidence level and projections are based on current law. So that remains as it was. And that's why we say from an effective tax rate, we're sort of in the low 20s where we'll settle out, we believe.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from PJ from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is from PJ from Citi.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Its Dan Jester on for PJ. If I heard Bert correctly, we missed an application in the fall, the winter buying season was slow and there's a risk of early spring. In the past, that has been a scenario at which the supply chain has gotten pretty stressed. So
componenttext: Its Dan Jester on for PJ. If I heard Bert correctly, we missed an application in the fall, the winter buying season was slow and there's a risk of early spring. In the past, that has been a scenario at which the supply chain has gotten pretty stressed. So can you talk if you're doing anything differently from a logistic standpoint this spring compared to the last couple of springs?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Bert answer that, but I won't say it's a risk of an early spring, it's nothing but positive. In fact, we start moving products here earlier than normal. But Bert?
componenttext: I'll let Bert answer that, but I won't say it's a risk of an early spring, it's nothing but positive. In fact, we start moving products here earlier than normal. But Bert?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we look at a number of scenarios. And like any company would be in doing scenario planning and look at our asset capability and meet the customer demand, staying in contact with customers what they think they're going to see. So I do believe you will h
componenttext: So we look at a number of scenarios. And like any company would be in doing scenario planning and look at our asset capability and meet the customer demand, staying in contact with customers what they think they're going to see. So I do believe you will have a stress system. That being said, we have set up with our barge service provider, ample service in what will be coming out of the plant, mostly Donaldsonville on barge. And utilizing our terminals from -- that are served from the pipeline as well as by barges, that being ammonia. And we are well-positioned for that, and then it's UAN. And so when you look at probably in an early release on barges for ice-locked getting up into the upper Midwest to our furthest northernmost point, Minneapolis, we think we'll be well supplied, well-positioned. And as you see the weakening in the oil in the coal markets on rail, we're getting a lot better service from our rail providers. And we have 5,000 to 6,000 rail cars in our service as well as extras if needed. And we're fully utilizing those assets to get product in position.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would add to Bert's comments, Dan, is given our broad base in-market production and all the different major rail lines that we're on, plus all of our storage in different locations, we are sort of really able to deal with supply chain, s
componenttext: The other thing I would add to Bert's comments, Dan, is given our broad base in-market production and all the different major rail lines that we're on, plus all of our storage in different locations, we are sort of really able to deal with supply chain, stress and disruptions on any of the reverse or rail systems, I think better than most people because of the diversity of our asset base and our mix. And so in a lot of cases, when those discontinuities or stress point happen, it benefits us disproportionately compared to other people. So we're not afraid of it necessarily. Oftentimes, it made some benefit to us.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay that's really helpful. And then just quickly on Trinidad. Gas curtailments have been going on there for several years now. So is there something that changed your view about the outlook for Trinidad that forced the impairments this quarter?
componenttext: Okay that's really helpful. And then just quickly on Trinidad. Gas curtailments have been going on there for several years now. So is there something that changed your view about the outlook for Trinidad that forced the impairments this quarter?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think a couple of things, Dan. As you know, most of the Trinidadian-based gas contracts are indexed off of the underlying product. So in our case, for our -- our 1 plant joint venture it's indexed off of ammonia pricing. Some of them are off of met
componenttext: Yes, I think a couple of things, Dan. As you know, most of the Trinidadian-based gas contracts are indexed off of the underlying product. So in our case, for our -- our 1 plant joint venture it's indexed off of ammonia pricing. Some of them are off of methanol pricing, some of them are off of ammonia pricing and so forth. And so what happens is as product pricing has come down, that means the gas priced into the Point Lisas has stayed also correspondingly come down. And it's -- it means there's less money going to NGC, National Gas Company. It's in a situation where at the price it's currently being paid for the gas that's below what we believe replacement cost of gas in Trinidad is. And so one of the things that is different today than maybe a year or 2 ago is we believe that curtailments may have been more temporary in the past than the new production coming online. As we sit here today, gas price doesn't justify the new investment needed to bring on additional production and at the lower product price  in the marketplace. You can't make out for the loss production that we're losing. So it's that combination of factors that's really led us to take the impairment.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Andrew Wong with RBC.
componenttext: Our next question is from Andrew Wong with RBC.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So regarding the share purchases. I mean I know they're on hold because of the OCI transaction. How quickly can you resume repurchases after the transaction is complete? I know there's blackout periods and stuff like that. Can you walk us through some of
componenttext: So regarding the share purchases. I mean I know they're on hold because of the OCI transaction. How quickly can you resume repurchases after the transaction is complete? I know there's blackout periods and stuff like that. Can you walk us through some of that thinking? And what sort of magnitude can you expect for this year?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say through, we -- the our focus right now on getting through close. And as part of that process, of course, we're evaluating, updating our capital position. We believe, as I said earlier that there's a lot of things that are really wind i
componenttext: Yes, so I would say through, we -- the our focus right now on getting through close. And as part of that process, of course, we're evaluating, updating our capital position. We believe, as I said earlier that there's a lot of things that are really wind in our sales. So a combination of the CHS venture commencing and getting that cash in the door and the benefits that we're going to be receiving as a result of bonus depreciation means that we've got a lot of liquidity. And given where the share price is trading, of course we're very anxious to start deploying that. But we need to get through the close first and then we'll make an appropriate announcement. It's going to require authorization by the new Board of Directors of the newly constituted company before we're able to do anything. But I'm as anxious as anyone to get after it as soon as possible.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just switching to something else. Chinese nitrogen production, I know there's recently some reports they have lower operating rates. Do you have a sense of whether these are more temporary type curtailments, or are we talking about more per
componenttext: And then maybe just switching to something else. Chinese nitrogen production, I know there's recently some reports they have lower operating rates. Do you have a sense of whether these are more temporary type curtailments, or are we talking about more permanent type shutdowns?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our view is and there's been a lot of new capacity coming on in China, the excess overhang is capacity that the world doesn't really need. But these reduction in operating rates tend to be more offset, permanent offsets, against some of the new ca
componenttext: I think our view is and there's been a lot of new capacity coming on in China, the excess overhang is capacity that the world doesn't really need. But these reduction in operating rates tend to be more offset, permanent offsets, against some of the new capacity that's, on. We don't think that it makes sense for all of that production running where it was. And so when you see operating rates come back, I think it's not because of their producing -- going to be producing more, it's because some of those plants are going to be permanently shut down and taken kind of off of the capacity curve.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2016
