headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CF Industries Holdings First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Liz, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] .I would now like to turn the presentation over to the
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CF Industries Holdings First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Liz, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] .
I would now like to turn the presentation over to the host for today, Mr. Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, please proceed.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Liz. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings, Inc. I'm Dan Aldridge, Senior Director of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications; and with me are Tony Will, our President and Chief Executiv
componenttext:
Thanks, Liz. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings, Inc. I'm Dan Aldridge, Senior Director of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications; and with me are Tony Will, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Dennis Kelleher, our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Bert Frost, our Vice President of Sales, Distribution and Market Development; and Chris Bohn, our Senior Vice President of Manufacturing. 
CF Industries Holdings, Inc. reported its first quarter 2016 results yesterday afternoon as did Terra Nitrogen Company, L.P. 
On this call, we'll review the CF Industries' results in detail and discuss our outlook referring to several of the slides that are posted on our website. At the end of the call, we'll host a question-and-answer session.
As you review the news releases posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at cfindustries.com and as you listen to this conference call, please recognize that they contain forward-looking statements as defined by federal securities laws. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed in Slide 2 and from time to time, in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today, and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
This conference call will include discussion of certain non-GAAP financial measures. In each case, a presentation of the most directly comparable financial measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP in coinciding reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measure to the most to write the comparable financial measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP is provided in the earnings release and the slides of this webcast presentation on the company's website, cfindustries.com. 
Before I turn the call over to Tony, I want to highlight the scope for today's call. On this call, we will be focusing on CF Industries in our first quarter financial results. We do not intend to take comment on, our take questions related to, our pending transaction with the OCI. We will provide updates on the OCI transactions when appropriate through filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a company press releases and/or other corporate communication. 
Now let me introduce Tony Will, our President and CEO.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we posted CF Industries 2016 first quarter results in which we generated an EBITDA of $207 million. Adjusted EBITDA was $300 million after taking into account net foreign currency losses, mark-to-mark
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we posted CF Industries 2016 first quarter results in which we generated an EBITDA of $207 million. 
Adjusted EBITDA was $300 million after taking into account net foreign currency losses, mark-to-market hedge losses, transaction costs related to CHS and OCI and expenses related to the capacity expansion projects. 
The difficult market conditions in North America from late last year persisted into the early part of this year. However, as demand developed with the onset of spring, prices quickly moved up into the range we believe represents sustainable prices for the industry. 
Although industry publications reported January and February year repricing in NOLA well below $200, our realized price for the quarter was $256 a ton. 
Our reported gross margin was $217 million or 22% of approximately $1 billion of net sales. What I want to focus on is the strength and the underlying fundamentals of our business. To really understand those fundamentals, it is necessary to strip away the noise and short-term timing issues and look at just the core business. Excluding the impact of our natural gas hedges, consolidated gross margin would have been $294 million or around 30%. The unrealized mark-to-market derivative loss was $21 million and the realized natural gas derivative loss was $56 million for a full impact of $77 million associated with natural gas hedges. 
Over time, as the hedge position roles off, that noise will disappear and the core business will shine through. 
As we talked about in our last call and as shown on Slide 12 of our materials, even at our urea price of $200 per ton, a typical U.S. Gulf producer generates roughly 50% cash margins on each incremental ton and into this attractive environment that we are bringing on our new capacity additions. 
Our newly reappointed Donaldsonville is placed into service last November and is reliably operating 10% to 15% above nameplate capacity. Our new Donaldsonville in and UAN in plants where placed into service in March and are reliably operating 15% to 20% above nameplate capacity and we haven't even pushed them to the limit yet. 
We are mechanically complete on the Donaldsonville ammonia plant, and I'm in the process of recommissioning and commissioning activities. So the burn rate spend there has wound back considerably. And we expect to be fully completed Port Neal by the end of the second quarter, meaning our spending on the new projects will largely be wrapped up in the next 2 months. 
Finally, during the first quarter, our strategic venture with the CHS commenced. We received $2.8 billion in cash and began selling urea and UAN to them at market prices. 
On a global basis, capacity additions, along with lower feedstock cost and cheaper ocean freight, have led to a widening and flattening of the global cost curve over the last year. However, due to sustained annual growth in nitrogen demand, even with all of the additional capacity, during periods with more robust demand, higher cost tons must be bid into the market. We believe the Chinese anthracite coal-based facilities will continue to be the marginal cost producers for the foreseeable future, setting the global cost forward. 
In fact, Burt and I recently spent a week in China and met with about 10 different industry participants at their plans, the ports and their offices to gain additional insights into the evolving dynamics in China. 
Over the course of several days and over 1,000 miles travel, we came away with a few key themes: one, there are broad-based expectations that the nitrogen fertilizer industry will continue to rationalize, closing high cost inefficient plants. It is estimated that between 50% and 60% of the installed industry capacity in China is still side based coproductions and these facilities, along with certain gas plans, are the ones most at risk. 
Subsidies are being dramatically reduced or eliminated all together, including rail, electricity and feedstock. One producer we spoke with suggested that met roughly $25 to $30 per ton cost increase for them.
And there's a heightened awareness and significant pressure being applied both at the central and local government levels regarding the significant environmental impact caused by these facilities. All of these points to just, in fact, almost every group we met with expects that significant capacity will be removed from China over the next several years.
With that, I'll hand the call over to Bert and Dennis to go through the details of the quarter, then I'll ramp up made a few final thoughts. Bert?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. The first quarter was definitely a tale of 2 very different time periods. Entering the quarter, pricing and demand were low and the industry outlook wasn't very positive. As Tony mentioned, in North America, urea traded at less than $200 per
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. The first quarter was definitely a tale of 2 very different time periods. Entering the quarter, pricing and demand were low and the industry outlook wasn't very positive. As Tony mentioned, in North America, urea traded at less than $200 per ton in U.S. Gulf at the beginning of the quarter, which we considered unsustainable. As such, we decided to position the company for unimproved forward market. As spring weather broke early in many parts of the country, we began selling into the market as prices quickly rebounded. 
prices began to rise in mid-February and continued pricing through March, with urea and the Gulf topping out at $270 a ton and prices in the corn belt trading above $300 per ton. 
In addition to the earlier arrival of spring weather, low prices of the begin of the quarter did not attract a high level of imports of factory and UAN to North America, which also aided the rebound and led to nitrogen Q1 supply being short in the corn belt.
Shipment and application activities were strong in March for ammonia, UAN -- and UAN, but especially for ammonia. Warm dry weather came early and farmers in the Southern Plains and Midwest were prepared and ammonia sales in those regions marked one of our best starts to a spring season. To put this into perspective, the previous record shipment for March out of our Blair, Nebraska terminal was 38,000 tons. In March, we surpassed 62,000 tons. That means that the terminal had to, on average, load 4 trucks an hour, 24 hours a day every day of the month. 
Our consolidated sales volume for the quarter was very strong, up approximately 39% year-over-year, aided by the addition of CF fertilizers U.K. and our capacity expansions. We also load direct quarter for the production of urea at approximately 819 tons. 
Looking to the global markets, reduction in feedstock costs continue to have a big impact in the first quarter of 2016, along with currency devaluations. However, global cost appear to have hit floor levels in the first quarter of 2016. The coal supply is low. Coal prices found the bottom in December and have remained stable since. Similarly, the global oil situation is still low on supply, but prices have begun to recover from the lows in January.
Ocean freight rates have declined substantially due to oversupply of both vessels and lower fuel prices, but it appears that after 2 years of decline, these costs has hit the floor as well. 
Export activity from China was down almost 38% year-over-year for the first quarter of 2016 as the global prices continued to fall, high-cost Chinese after site called-based producers began to curtail production and limited ton ship to the ports for export. 
In addition, Chinese fertilizer industry publications recently stated that several urea producers in China were permanently shut down in 2015, which was the first time ever in that reductions have exceeded new production coming online.
Additionally, the Chinese Nitrogen Fertilizer Associations 2016 to 2020 Development Plan culture more of the smaller old plants to be faced out by the end of the decade, reducing the country's ammonia capacity by an estimated 10 million metric tons per year and the urea capacity by 13 million metric tons per year. All of these data points lead us to believe that our view of the global cost curve is reasonably accurate. 
Moving onto North American natural gas. The market began the first quarter with unexpectedly cold January that changed in the gas market's focus from how good prices could potentially fall to high quickly prices could climb. Henry Hub, Gas Daily, was trading at $1.54 on December 28, 2015, and reached prices as high as $2.53 only 15 days later on January 12. 
This rally was short-lived as prices decline due to the latter half of January and into the beginning of March. The declining price was due to a collapse of gas weighted heating degree days that far exceed even the mildest projections, underperforming industrial demand and slower-than-anticipated LNG exports. The combination of these factors led to an end of March storage balance just under 2.5 TCF, 54% higher than the 5-year average and more than 1 TCF higher than last year.
We believe this abundant resource will continue to provide CF with a competitive advantage over other global producers for the foreseeable future.
The outlook for the remainder of 2016 and into 2017 remains positive. But with did capacity coming online globally over the next 12 months, we expect nitrogen pricing to remain under pressure. We expect urea demand at the U.S. Gulf to be continued to be relatively from through the spring application season. 
On the agriculture front, economics continue to support planting corn over soybeans, and our planted corn forecast is 92 million acres with further upside possible given a favorable USDA's survey for spring planting intentions. Corn growth is forecasted at 2% for the fertilizer year 2016 and '17 as demand is expected to rebound near 2014 levels. And December corn is currently trading near $3.90 per bushel, all positive signs for the farmer and for our business.
Now let me turn the call over to Dennis.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bert. In the first quarter of 2016, we generated $217 million of EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $0.11. Included in these results were on a pretax basis, approximately $42 million of net foreign currency losses, $21 unrealized mark-to-mar
componenttext:
Thanks, Bert. In the first quarter of 2016, we generated $217 million of EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $0.11. Included in these results were on a pretax basis, approximately $42 million of net foreign currency losses, $21 unrealized mark-to-market losses on our natural gas derivatives, $16 million in expansion cost for our Donaldsonville important new facilities and $14 million in transaction costs related to the OCI transaction and the CHS strategic venture. 
When taking these items into account, our adjusted EBITDA for the first quarter was $300 million and our adjusted net earnings per diluted share was $0.40. 
Included in these results, the realized loss of $56 million or $0.79 per MMBtu on our natural gas hedges for the first quarter of 2016. This compares to realized loss of $32  million or $0.52 per MMBtu on our natural gas hedges in the first quarter of 2015. 
During the first quarter of 2016, the company did not enter into any additional natural gas hedges. Additionally, in the first quarter of 2016, the company placed into service the new UAN plant at Donaldsonville. This expect to place into service the new ammonia at Donaldsonville and the new ammonia and urea plant at Port Neal later this year. 
As we mentioned in our last call, most of these assets will qualify for the 50% bonus depreciation for fiscal year 2016 as a result of the passage of the Pact Act by Congress last year. 
As a result of these additional assets being placed into service, the company expects to have significantly reduced cash tax payments for the year. 
I'd like to take a brief moment to describe the mechanics of the CHS strategic venture. On February 1, 2016, we received $2.8 billion in our cash account related to this investment. Each quarter, we recognized a noncontrolling interest amount related to this investment, which for the first quarter was $17 million. However, the cash distribution payables semiannually to CHS may be different from the amount recorded as noncontrolling interest in any given period based on the terms of the agreement, which, in effect, provides reduced economics to CHS. The estimate of this distribution pertaining to the first quarter is approximately $30 million.
Moving on. For 2016, the company expects to have total capital expenditures in the range of $1.8 billion to $2 billion, of which, $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion will be used to the capacity expansion of private and the other $500 million to $600 million for sustaining improvement of other projects. With that, Tony will provide some closing remarks before we open the call to Q&A.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dennis. I want to summarize why we continue to be so excited and optimistic about our business. The fundamentals of our business remains strong. There is a growing demand for our products, and we benefit from low-cost North American gas.Our cons
componenttext:
Thanks, Dennis. I want to summarize why we continue to be so excited and optimistic about our business. The fundamentals of our business remains strong. There is a growing demand for our products, and we benefit from low-cost North American gas.
Our consolidated gross margin was 30%, x the impact of gas hedges and our cash margins for incremental production are 50% or better. Our plants are running well. We had record production for urea in the first quarter and one of the top 3 quarters for ammonia production as well. 
We fully expect to hit an all-time record for UAN production here in Q2 with the new diesel plant online. The expansion projects are almost done. We are mechanically complete on the Donaldsonville ammonia plants and within 2 months of being mechanically complete at Port Neal, so the spending is quickly coming to an end. When those plants are online, they will increase our productive capacity by more than 25% and, along with it, our corresponding cash flow generation as well.
Our balanced sheet credit metrics and liquidity are all strong. We have a solid investment grade rating, we have a $2 billion undrawn revolver and we have $2.7 billion of cash on the balanced sheet at quarter end. 
Finally, bonus depreciation will provide a significant cash flow benefit this year and next.
So although the pricing environment is weaker than we'd like, nonetheless, we are extremely excited about the bright future ahead and what the next few months hold for us. 
With that, we will now open the lines to answer your questions. Operator?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joel, this is Bert. Looking at Q1 and the start of Q1 and at the low level of customer advances was a direct reflection of our view of the market that at that time going out of Q4 and into Q1 that prices that were at that point available to us in the Nort
componenttext: Joel, this is Bert. Looking at Q1 and the start of Q1 and at the low level of customer advances was a direct reflection of our view of the market that at that time going out of Q4 and into Q1 that prices that were at that point available to us in the North American market just were not attractive and we're a bit of probably levels even below that. And we decided at that point it was more appropriate for us to utilize our storage capabilities and our terminus system and that is one is our plant space and prepare for a market that we believe would come later in Q1, which was then materialized or start to materialize in February as prices started to be going into spring. So you've seen us over the years take different tactics at the market. Sometimes we had sold forward in previous year. We don't do it as much of that anymore. And we're playing on a global market where we've looked at opportunities, both inside North America and outside their markets. We have relationships around the world, and we intend to utilize those capabilities as well as flexible production options because that's how we built these plants for new plants that coming online to be tremendously flexible for us in terms of going full UAN, full urea or even full ammonia as we have it during this Q1 period satisfied the high ammonia demand we had.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Dennis. Well, I'll start with the financial gas hedges and start to think about that. Without getting into specific numbers, I think it's really to see that if you think about the disclosures that we made in the past. We disclosed how many MM
componenttext: Yes. This is Dennis. Well, I'll start with the financial gas hedges and start to think about that. Without getting into specific numbers, I think it's really to see that if you think about the disclosures that we made in the past. We disclosed how many MMBtus we have hedged going forward, and there was a graph, I think, that we put out as part of the 4Q earnings release to pace we mapped out exactly what those hedges are going in full time and whether price. So we about the forward curve through that period, as that forward curve rise and different tax rises, it may fall as well.  We don't know. So if you think about where that forward curve is, when we valued it at quarter's end at March 31 versus where it may move through time in the quarter, that will have a change on sort of the mark-to-market. Because the mark-to-market stuff that you're seeing is in relation to hedges that have not been realized yet as they've not closed out. So if you go through times, few things are happening. More of those things are being realized sort of effectively falling off the forward map. And at the same time, the curve is rising and falling versus the price on those curves. You saw the add up on the MMBtus and then the difference between where any given point is on the curve and where we are on the hedge curve, which we've disclosed. You can kind of come out of that way mathematically.

componenttext: On the second question, this is Bert, regarding the ammonia pricing and what was expected and what was possibly put out there by different groups. You have to understand that Q1 is not necessarily an ammonia application period, although as we stated in our prepared remarks, we had record pull out of our player terminal. And that was a phenomenal. In Q1, it was predominantly in that Nebraska region. However, just as prices were very low in January for urea, there also a very low for ammonia. We have not only on the import market, which is Tampa-driven, which is a 3 10 a metric ton or about $280 a short ton. That number got pulled into the United States in several regions and prices were low. And we took the same tactic that we did with urea, we decided not to sell into the market. The industrial percentage of our business in Q1 is higher and that most industrial contractors are gas based during that 3 $2 [ph] gas. And again, Tampa base, so I already gave you the Tampa number. We also had an export vessel, 25,000 tons that we exported at Tampa equivalents or a little bit below that. All that to say that the weight of that -- of the Q1 number was pushed more towards the industrial side of our business. You'll see that revert back to more of a traditional strip for Q2 as that's more of an  base quarter.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Wong from Piper Jaffray.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brett, you spoke about expected production phase out in China over the coming year. I was just wondering, if you can talk about how much of that relates to kind of economics and how much to environmental. And from your trip, are there environmental pressu
componenttext: Brett, you spoke about expected production phase out in China over the coming year. I was just wondering, if you can talk about how much of that relates to kind of economics and how much to environmental. And from your trip, are there environmental pressures in China that can result in faster pace out of the capacity there?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as Tony said in his remarks, we spent a week, a little over 10 days in Asia. We went to some other places. And the consistent message coming out of China for us was one of they're going through a change. And as we've said, in the past, each year s
componenttext: Yes. So as Tony said in his remarks, we spent a week, a little over 10 days in Asia. We went to some other places. And the consistent message coming out of China for us was one of they're going through a change. And as we've said, in the past, each year seems to be a different economic year coming out of China. And centers are different, subsidies are different, taxes are different, production levels are different. And today, they're really struggling to try to find their way and trying different steps in order to maintain profitability. Last year, that step was record export. We just don't see that going forward. It's unsustainable. And what they were doing last year was just sending products of the ports. The entire we visited last year, there was probably 2 million, 2.5 million tons sitting in bags at the port ready for export unsold. What we're seeing transit has a transition to a more market-based decisions as we've heard from several traders and participants that until they sell those tons, they're not going to move them to the port. A great economic decision, which we think will present some of the low prices that were coming in last year. So economics are driving a lot of decisions on how they look at efficiencies, how they look at investments, how they are looking at shipments. And this year, first quarter and into the second quarter, the domestic market was much more profitable than the export market and you saw a lot of produces pull away from the export market. So I think it's a maturing. They're understanding what their options are. In 2011, '12 and '13 when urea was over $400, everybody made money. It was an easy decision to participate in produce. That's no longer going to be the case of the several high-cost producers those at the site coal produces. And we think rationalization will continue. On environmental front, all I can tell you is it's dirty. And we drove to several places in several cities in both Tommy and I were amazed. You see the pictures in the newspapers, it's a different in real life. And you almost could cut through it and you can see every half a mile away. you drive by rivers, you drive by piles of garbage. That can't continue. Just as we had rivers burn in the '60s and '70s in Wisconsin in Lake Erie, we had to make the same kind of changes that they're going to have to make. They're going to have to change their effluent streams, they're going to capture some of these gas streams and that will all come in with investment, and environmental awareness will take place.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we've heard specifically on the environment side is the central government has put in place certain parameters and thresholds, and the local governments are able to put tighter ones in place the cat port more last one so it really the better for the
componenttext: What we've heard specifically on the environment side is the central government has put in place certain parameters and thresholds, and the local governments are able to put tighter ones in place the cat port more last one so it really the better for the region that you're in, but there were certainly some areas for which a significant capital is required in order going to be record in order to keep running those plants. And based on the current economic outlook, we still see that capital being spent, and we heard that loud and clear.

componenttext: Helpful. And just one more for me. If -- as you look to export more out of the that will be in time, but do you have plans to access the Brazilian energy market? And how do you expect kind of do that? Is there a large capital needs there, partnership to gain access to that market?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I guess I'll let Bert answer the question, but let me answer is philosophically about it for a second, which is we have always tried to stick with our knitting in terms of things that we do really well and then find partners to participate in the
componenttext: Yes, so I guess I'll let Bert answer the question, but let me answer is philosophically about it for a second, which is we have always tried to stick with our knitting in terms of things that we do really well and then find partners to participate in the areas of the channels where they do things well. We are not interested in taking on receivable risk from farmers. We're not interested in taking on currency risk. So when we participate in these markets, it tends not to be with owned assets on the ground in those locations where we're exposing ourselves to those kinds of risks. It tends to be with partnering with other people and selling it. There on delivered places into their tanks are on an FOB basis. But Bert, what you just talk specifically about it?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're active in Brazil today. We were when key traders with us, and we will continue to be probably more involved as we do have more volume of experts that are available to us but it would have to be net-back driven. Brazil tended to be a very low
componenttext: Yes, so we're active in Brazil today. We were when key traders with us, and we will continue to be probably more involved as we do have more volume of experts that are available to us but it would have to be net-back driven. Brazil tended to be a very low priced market in relation to the rest of the world's options. But we know those people down there. I spent 8 years in Brazil. I'll be down there next month with a group and intent to connect with some of the industry participants. At Tony said, we don't necessarily desire to beat -- we do not desire to be asset owners in that market. We do not believe that we need to be. We think the channel is well served there. There are good partners out there. We desire to monetize our position immediately and not take the risk that Tony mentioned. I do think there were a change in the Petrobras asset-based that are coming. I don't think they're -- I think they're on the high end of the cost curve. And I don't think where their assets are located and what they're doing today make a lot of sense. So you have a 5 million-ton urea market that's available. A lot of the international producers are participating. We're developing UAN. We ship several cargoes down there, and we think that will grow -- I think it has a very good growth pattern. So you'll see us down there more and more.

componenttext: Just a question on Chinese imports to the U.S. and I recognize the 2015 data is a little bit skewed by the size of the exports from China in general. But I'm just curious, of the 12 months of the year, in the United States come how many of those months do you think we still need to actually physically have Chinese products coming? And has that changed over the last couple of years? And do you think the risk is that in those months are really just don't need to cover that cost at all in the U.S. and, therefore, any Middle Eastern company could come in and sell at that price?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Traditionally, Chinese has been perceived as lower quality. They're granular products because how they move it to the port, how it's loaded onto vessels and the times. Sometimes it sits in the port, it degrades and then it arrives because of a long voyage
componenttext: Traditionally, Chinese has been perceived as lower quality. They're granular products because how they move it to the port, how it's loaded onto vessels and the times. Sometimes it sits in the port, it degrades and then it arrives because of a long voyage to the United States. And a lot of the comments we get back from our customers is they prefer not to buy it. So what you see today is there are 2 price levels in NOLA for Chinese and non-Chinese. But we are an important market. And an import market will draw tons from everywhere, Middle East, Russia, Asia. And today, chinese product trades at a discount. And I think as long as it trades with a differential low enough, people will buy it. That being said, Chinese participation -- Chinese product participation in the North America market looks to be declining. You have a few to bring it and blended. And so what we see going forward, I think the story, the broad story where we're communicating today is that a part of these changes is probably Chinese product will remain more and more in Asia, maybe go into South America a little bit. But you see declining exports, which means fewer imports in the North America most likely.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vincent, I think even at the high watermark, there wasn't more than about 1.5 million tons from China that they were found its way to the U.S. Generally speaking, both tons defined and Canadian that's come to the U.S. marketplace. But from the North Ameri
componenttext: Vincent, I think even at the high watermark, there wasn't more than about 1.5 million tons from China that they were found its way to the U.S. Generally speaking, both tons defined and Canadian that's come to the U.S. marketplace. But from the North American perspective, it's mostly Gulf and the Chinese stuff is more around the French. So we see most of those tons being backed out. But North America is going to even after our projects come online and the other ones that are in construction today, North America was still import roughly 30% of its total nitrogen requirements. And so we've heard this noise about it's going to become a balanced market, but the people who say that include Trinidad tons as part of the North American balance. And the last time I looked on the map, Trinidad wasn't part of North America. my geography teacher thought. So there's notion somehow that the end market premium is going away. I'd say show me where the production is that's going to make that happen. Someone still has to bid those tons into the marketplace in order for there to be enough nitrogen to hit the ground in the corn belt. And that's not happening organically from new steel in the ground in that region. So we don't see that happening. Now yes, there is going to be a shifting trade balance as the new capacity comes online. We don't think Chinese tons makes sense here anymore, but we're still pretty substantially in import marketplace.

componenttextpreview: You mentioned the favorable start to the ammonia application season. Do you see this in any way detracting from later season demand for urea or UAN?
componenttext: You mentioned the favorable start to the ammonia application season. Do you see this in any way detracting from later season demand for urea or UAN?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, the total nitrogen need is still there we have a very strong quarter end pull of ammonia and then we kind of win into a wet and cool period yet. Also remember, we had a four fall, so the net and need for spring is fairly large. And applicati
componenttext: No. Actually, the total nitrogen need is still there we have a very strong quarter end pull of ammonia and then we kind of win into a wet and cool period yet. Also remember, we had a four fall, so the net and need for spring is fairly large. And application tended to change a little bit. I think there's a push to get your spring ammonia down. There's also going to be a spring side-dress ammonia season that's going to come, but a lot of folks are moving -- or a lot of farmers are moving towards split applications with either UAN and urea or going over the top with urea by plane. So what we see today and what we anticipate is a full utilization of the products that have made it into the market and low inventories coming out of Q2. But we have a lot of applications ahead of us. The Northern market, North Dakota, and Canada are just kicking off now and going strong. We still have the side-dress season in Indiana and Ohio. This is all for ammonia. And then application on top. So we anticipate this season running our little bit longer, running a little bit bigger with 92 million to 93 million acres of corn and don't anticipate that the fuel season will begin until later in the year.

componenttextpreview: So look, we're one of the lowest cost producers globally. And given North America's new port marketplace, we're going to run 24 7 3 65. And I think the question isn't quite as easy as what's the aggregate operating rate. Because I think what happens is th
componenttext: So look, we're one of the lowest cost producers globally. And given North America's new port marketplace, we're going to run 24 7 3 65. And I think the question isn't quite as easy as what's the aggregate operating rate. Because I think what happens is those people that are comfortably cash flow positive are going to run near 100%. They're going to keep their plants running. Those that are on the fringe are going to try as hard as they can to continue to run and those that are really at the high cost ones are going to ultimately shut down permanently. And we see most of those shutdowns happening in China, maybe some in Eastern Europe, but...

componenttext: Trinidad has got some curtailment problems and other, so. componenttextpreview: On Chinese coal prices on Slide 9, you indicate no perceptible response to oil price changes. Do you think that's a lag issue and it's still coming? Do you think the linkage is now much weaker than it's been in the past because of the global oversupply in
componenttext: On Chinese coal prices on Slide 9, you indicate no perceptible response to oil price changes. Do you think that's a lag issue and it's still coming? Do you think the linkage is now much weaker than it's been in the past because of the global oversupply in coal?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean the dynamics around where the coal price change in China are not related to the oil price at all. It's absolutely related to -- when we went over there, one of the things Bert and I consistently heard was the domestic coal price, the domestic c
componenttext: No. I mean the dynamics around where the coal price change in China are not related to the oil price at all. It's absolutely related to -- when we went over there, one of the things Bert and I consistently heard was the domestic coal price, the domestic coal price and where that sat. And it's not directly linked to external energy sources that you can track back to a lot of it has to do. Fundamentally, with it just what's of the cost of production and distribution within the country, and that's been relatively firm. And as Bert says, if anything we see that likely picking up instead of staying flat or going lower. So we don't see that being directly connected necessarily with the external energy environment, which is why when gas or oil price was $90 or $100, you didn't see it coal price in China running way up. And as oil prices come down, it has really a muted effect on internal pricing.

componenttext: So we're a proponent of precision Ag and work with a lot of our larger more sophisticated customers to how we can help serve that whole trend. componenttext: And Steve, to tag along what Dan's answer there, ultimately, were we see that had the disk higher crop density. The more precision the improvements in the field, you've got higher densities of crop, which then actually the way be projected increases the amount of nitrogen per unit of land as opposed to the other way around. And so in aggregate, we think this is a very favorable trend, not only because the environmental and social aspects of what Bert talked about, but it will be also just because we view consumption and demand increasing in North America as a result of that.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Matthew, a couple of things. One  of which as we announced relative to the PMH business we had and unscheduled downtime in Verdigris for one of our ammonia plants and that also carried on to one of the UAN plants there was well. And so as a result of
componenttext: Yes. Matthew, a couple of things. One  of which as we announced relative to the PMH business we had and unscheduled downtime in Verdigris for one of our ammonia plants and that also carried on to one of the UAN plants there was well. And so as a result of unscheduled downtime, we ended up with a fair bit of fixed overhead absorption into that business without the corresponding production plants that go along with it. On the distribution side, Bert has really led some investments that we've made at the distribution terminals to allow them to both receive inbound and also export outbound ammonium market quickly, which allows us to have a kind of results we did at Blair in the first quarter leading into the second quarter. And so as some of the initiatives like the 4 hours some that Bert talked about means that we'll see likely less ammonia going down in the fall being able to really pump it out hard in the spring as a critical thing. And that's part of the reason why we've made the investments that we've had is to really shifts and be able to move those tons quickly. Of the other thing that you got to look at, I'd say, Matthew, is we do have now both the urea and UAN plants that the Donaldsonville operating, and so we do have quite a bit more depreciation expense that's going to be rolling through the P&L than what we've had in the past. And as we bring on the ammonia plant and then Port Neal, you're going to see those depreciation numbers continue to climb.  So while that is an important to look at, can be really focused on cash flow generation, and so our focus, the thing that we would point you to has really take a hard look at how much operating cash flow we're generating going forward as a much better metric ton the distortion of what the new depreciation is going to be in terms of the underlying health and economics of the business.

componenttext: So we had -- we did see the domestic demand, but a lot of changes are taking place in Chinese agriculture, and you've been reading about these and seeing pictures. We still have a lot of smaller operations in the South. As you go north, you're seeing a lot of bigger some of the state on the operations are fairly large. And so we do see some positive trends. The huge domestic market estimates or when you include industrial demand as well as agricultural demand for urea and ammonium sulfate. It is large, and I do think it's going to grow. But change in crop subsidies for corn and how that's going to impact probably will have some changes, but I don't think as much as people are anticipating. So relative to the rest of the role of their domestic demand period and enter Q2 into Q3, we think exports we've said are going to be around 10 million tons for the year. We're still with that number, so off about 4 million tons from last year. I think there's going to be some prolonged downtimes at several plants. I don't think we do see the push to stop the ports for exports. We have to see this develop and see if our hypothesis holds true.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to highlight that last point that Bert mentioned and you mentioned it earlier. I think it's a really good one, which is everyone we spoke with, in fact the general manager of the port operations and all the as well is that, that the producers are n
componenttext: I want to highlight that last point that Bert mentioned and you mentioned it earlier. I think it's a really good one, which is everyone we spoke with, in fact the general manager of the port operations and all the as well is that, that the producers are not just blindly shipping product into the port and then have that available for the traders to kind of cover short positions in the tenders the way they used to do. They're being much more rational about only taking product to port, and a they've made some investments on railroad out and load in infrastructure, and so forth, in order to be able to move quickly. And so they're waiting until they actually see business that they want to take before they start moving product to port. And that's one of the reasons that they claim anyway that they've had some better discipline in terms of pricing into some of these tenders this year than they have in the past, which is its fundamentally different behavior on the part of the producers. And they're getting away from letting the traders just short these tenders like crazy and then going to the overflowing ports to cover. And so we think not only is the rationalization of capacity improving kind of the overall market dynamics, but the behavioral aspect of it is really important as well.

componenttext: Yes. Okay. So look, China -- as we said about fertilizer, I'd say the same thing about corn. And China has been changing. They have subsidized corn production to the tune of $9 a bushel, we expect. And those numbers are coming off. And so I can't give you what that is it 1 million, 6 million tons of urea equivalent? I don't have that number.

The Chinese farmers sort of look at urea as being the really critical important element of fertilization for yield. And even though there's some view of balance fertilization needs to increase, the sense that we got from the people over there is they don't expect much of a change.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Donaldsonville urea is running north of 10% above nameplate. So nameplate is 38 50, and we've seen rates north of 4,500, 4,800 tons a day. So that plant is really coming along. And on the UAN plant, the nameplate on that is, and everything I'm giv
componenttext: Yes, so Donaldsonville urea is running north of 10% above nameplate. So nameplate is 38 50, and we've seen rates north of 4,500, 4,800 tons a day. So that plant is really coming along. And on the UAN plant, the nameplate on that is, and everything I'm giving you is short tons, is 5,050 a day. And we've seen rates north of 5,800. And again, as I said, we haven't even really pushed it to max rates yet, and so we think 20% is likely achievable at that UAN. So that was the already largest single train UAN plant in the world at nameplate. We're getting much, much better results than that already. And the way that we went about designing these plants was understanding from a process flow perspective what the bottlenecks were, what the things we knew to upsize when that same approach we've taken of the ammonia plant as well as that 40 [indiscernible] so while it's a little early to claim victory on the ammonia production yet, our expectation is that we're going to be in a same kind of region, relative to production on the ammonia and also at Port Neal. And important thing to also highlights is when we did the original investment thesis and justification, it was strictly based on nameplate production. So with the incremental ton that we're getting off of these plants show up at that 50% to 60% cash margin number and all of those are just for free cash into the equation on the economics of the plant. So we feel very good about where we are.

componenttext: 2 2 questions on pricing.  One, near term. Bert, you talked about high mix of non-corn belt ammonia in Q1. How does that mix change as you get into Q2 between having higher proportion of corn belt sales and not much of a forward order book? I assume that you'd be able to capture most of this recent run-up in corn belt ammonia pricing. And then longer term, as you look in the second half of this year with more capacity coming online, are you seeing pressure from distributors to have price protection on nitrogen products like they've been getting on Potash or potash now is price protected from the manufacturer?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for near term, you're correct. the ammonia in Q1 for Ag application, we did get April pull into March, but we're still going to see a very healthy Q2 application period. We'll work through April into May. And again, as we march forward, that northerly
componenttext: So for near term, you're correct. the ammonia in Q1 for Ag application, we did get April pull into March, but we're still going to see a very healthy Q2 application period. We'll work through April into May. And again, as we march forward, that northerly tier starts kicking in. So I don't have exact numbers for you, but we're planning on historical spring, 6-month period. We look at this as a 6-month cycle for spring. And pricing, you're right. You're correct. It did vary quite a bit from $100 to $150 a ton. And we did have tons available to sell, and we anticipate that we have captured a pretty good part of that. You're correct. There is capacity coming online in UAN for us, urea with CS and some others as well as ammonia. The price protection is not in the mix. What we have seen happen is flat potash and phosphate on price protection is really a short-term gain, long-term loss. And as you put product in the inventory for periods like this spring when you could have had price appreciation, you do not get that and it creates a negative dynamic in the market that the risk stays with the producer, and you continue to push their product out from logistical basis and it just doesn't help the market at all. We believe that we need to price our products appropriately for our retail and wholesale customers. And at the risk then stays with them, then they get a reward when they sell and they provide services, they provide different products. It's part of their product portfolio. We're just 1 participant in that chain. And so we just don't see that price protection has a future in North America. At least in nitrogen, it doesn't.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CF Industries Holdings First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Liz, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions]I would now like to turn the presentation over to the
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the CF Industries Holdings First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Liz, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions]
I would now like to turn the presentation over to the host for today, Mr. Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, please proceed.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Liz. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings, Inc. I'm Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations. And with me are: Tony Will, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Dennis Kelleher, our Sen
componenttext:
Thanks, Liz. Good morning, and thanks for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings, Inc. I'm Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations. And with me are: Tony Will, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Dennis Kelleher, our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Bert Frost, our Senior Vice President of Sales, Distribution and Market Development; and Chris Bohn, our Senior Vice President of Manufacturing.
CF Industries Holdings, Inc. reported its first quarter 2016 results yesterday afternoon as did Terra Nitrogen Company, L.P.
On this call, we will review the CF Industries' results in detail and discuss our outlook referring to several of the slides that are posted on our website. At the end of the call, we'll host a question-and-answer session.
As you review the news releases posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at cfindustries.com and as you listen to this conference call, please recognize that they contain forward-looking statements as defined by federal securities laws. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed in the accompanying presentation and from time to time, in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today, and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
This conference call will include discussion of certain non-GAAP financial measures. In each case, a presentation of the most directly comparable financial measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP and coinciding reconciliation of the non-GAAP financial measure to the most directly comparable financial measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP is provided in the earnings release and the slides for this webcast presentation on the company's website, cfindustries.com.
Before I turn the call over to Tony, I want to highlight the scope for today's call. On this call, we will be focusing on CF Industries and our first quarter financial results. We do not intend to take comment on, or take questions related to, our pending transaction with OCI. We will provide updates on the OCI transaction when appropriate through filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, company press releases and/or other appropriate communications.
Now let me introduce Tony Will, our President and CEO.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we posted CF Industries' 2016 first quarter results in which we generated EBITDA of $207 million. Adjusted EBITDA was $300 million after taking into account net foreign currency losses, mark-to-market h
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we posted CF Industries' 2016 first quarter results in which we generated EBITDA of $207 million. Adjusted EBITDA was $300 million after taking into account net foreign currency losses, mark-to-market hedge losses, transaction costs related to CHS and OCI and expenses related to the capacity expansion projects.
The difficult market conditions in North America from late last year persisted into the early part of this year. However, as demand developed with the onset of spring, prices quickly moved up into the range we believe represents sustainable prices for the industry. Although industry publications reported January and February we're repricing NOLA well below $200, our realized price for the quarter was $256 a ton.
Our reported gross margin was $217 million or 22% of approximately $1 billion of net sales. What I want to focus on is the strength in the underlying fundamentals of our business. To really understand those fundamentals, it is necessary to strip away the noise in short-term timing issues and look at just the core business. Excluding the impact of our natural gas hedges, consolidated gross margin would have been $294 million or around 30%. The unrealized mark-to-market derivative loss was $21 million, and the realized natural gas derivative loss was $56 million for a total impact of $77 million associated with natural gas hedges. Over time, as the hedge position roles off, that noise will disappear and the core business will shine through.
As we talked about on our last call and as shown on Slide 12 of our materials, even at our urea price of $200 per ton, a typical U.S. Gulf producer generates roughly 50% cash margins on each incremental ton, and into this attractive environment that we are bringing on our new capacity additions.
Our new urea plant at Donaldsonville was placed into service last November and is reliably operating 10% to 15% above nameplate capacity. Our new Donaldsonville nitric acid and UAN plants were placed into service in March and are reliably operating 15% to 20% above nameplate capacity, and we haven't even pushed them to the limit yet.
We are mechanically complete on the Donaldsonville ammonia plant and are in the process of precommissioning and commissioning activities. So the burn rate spend there has wound back considerably. And we expect to be fully mechanically complete at Port Neal by the end of the second quarter, meaning our spending on the new projects will largely be wrapped up in the next 2 months.
Finally, during the first quarter, our strategic venture with the CHS commenced. We received $2.8 billion in cash and began selling urea and UAN to them at market prices.
On a global basis, capacity additions, along with lower feedstock cost and cheaper ocean freight, have led to a widening and flattening of the global cost curve over the last year. However, due to sustained annual growth in nitrogen demand, even with all of the additional capacity, during periods with more robust demand, higher cost tons must be bid into the market. We believe the Chinese anthracite coal-based facilities will continue to be the marginal cost producers for the foreseeable future, setting the global cost forth.
In fact, Bert and I recently spent a week in China and met with about 10 different industry participants at their plants, the ports and their offices to gain additional insights into the evolving dynamics in China. Over the course of several days and over 1,000 miles travel, we came away with a few key themes: one, there are broad-based expectations that the nitrogen fertilizer industry will continue to rationalize, closing high cost inefficient plants. It is estimated that between 50% and 60% of the installed industry capacity in China is still anthracite-based coal production, and these facilities, along with certain gas plants, are the ones most at risk; subsidies are being dramatically reduced or eliminated all together, including rail, electricity and feedstock. One producer we spoke with suggested that meant roughly $25 to $30 per ton cost increase for them; and there's a heightened awareness and significant pressure being applied both at the central and local government levels regarding the significant environmental impact caused by these facilities. All of these points suggest that, in fact, almost every group we met with expects that significant capacity will be removed from China over the next several years.
With that, I'll hand the call over to Bert and Dennis to go through the details of the quarter, then I'll wrap up with a few final thoughts. Bert?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. The first quarter was definitely a tale of 2 very different time periods. Entering the quarter, pricing and demand were low and the industry outlook wasn't very positive. As Tony mentioned, in North America, urea traded at less than $200 per
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. The first quarter was definitely a tale of 2 very different time periods. Entering the quarter, pricing and demand were low and the industry outlook wasn't very positive. As Tony mentioned, in North America, urea traded at less than $200 per ton in the U.S. Gulf at the beginning of the quarter, which we considered unsustainable. As such, we decided to position the company for an improved forward market. As spring weather broke early in many parts of the country, we began selling into the market as prices quickly rebounded.
Prices began to rise in mid-February and continued rising through March with urea at the Gulf topping out at $270 a ton and prices in the corn belt trading above $300 per ton. In addition to the earlier arrival of spring weather, low prices at the beginning of the quarter did not attract a high level of imports of urea and UAN to North America, which also aided the rebound and led to nitrogen Q1 supply being short in the corn belt.
Shipment and application activities were strong in March for ammonia, urea and UAN, but especially for ammonia. Warm dry weather came early, and farmers in the Southern Plains and Midwest were prepared, and ammonia sales in those regions marked one of our best starts to a spring season. To put this into perspective, the previous record shipment for March out of our Blair, Nebraska terminal was 38,000 tons. In March, we surpassed 62,000 tons. That means that the terminal had to, on average, load 4 trucks an hour, 24 hours a day, every day of the month.
Our consolidated sales volume for the quarter was very strong, up approximately 39% year-over-year, aided by the addition of CF Fertilisers UK and our capacity expansions. We also logged directive [ph] quarter for the production of urea at approximately 819,000 tons.
Looking to the global markets, reduction in feedstock costs continued to have a big impact in the first quarter of 2016, along with currency devaluations. However, global costs appear to have hit floor levels in the first quarter of 2016. Though coal supply is long, coal prices found the bottom in December and have remained stable since. Similarly, the global oil situation is still long supply, but prices have begun to recover from the lows in January.
Ocean freight rates have declined substantially due to oversupply of both vessels and lower fuel prices, but it appears that after 2 years of decline, these costs had hit the floor as well.
Export activity from China was down almost 38% year-over-year for the first quarter of 2016. As global prices continued to fall, high-cost Chinese anthracite coal-based producers began to curtail production and limited tons shipped to the ports for export. In addition, Chinese fertilizer industry publications recently stated that several urea producers in China were permanently shut down in 2015, which was the first time ever that reductions have exceeded new production coming online.
Additionally, the Chinese nitrogen fertilizer associations 2016 through 2020 development plan calls for more of the smaller old plants to be phased out by the end of the decade, reducing the country's ammonia capacity by an estimated 10 million metric tons per year and the urea capacity by 13 million metric tons per year. All of these data points lead us to believe that our view of the global cost curve is reasonably accurate.
Moving on to North America natural gas. The market began the first quarter with unexpectedly cold January that changed the gas market's focus from how low prices could potentially fall to how quickly prices could climb. Henry Hub gas daily was trading at $1.54 on December 28, 2015, and reached prices as high as $2.53 only 15 days later on January 12. This price rally was short-lived as prices decline through to latter half of January and into the beginning of March. The declining price was due to a collapse of gas-weighted heating degree days that far exceeded even the mildest projections, underperforming industrial demand and slower-than-anticipated LNG exports. The combination of these factors led to an end of March storage balance just under 2.5 Tcf, 54% higher than the 5-year average and more than 1 Tcf higher than last year. We believe this abundant resource will continue to provide CF with a competitive advantage over other global producers for the foreseeable future.
The nitrogen outlook for the remainder of 2016 and into 2017 remains positive. But with new capacity coming online globally over the next 12 months, we expect nitrogen pricing to remain under pressure. We expect urea demand at the U.S. Gulf to continue to be relatively firm through the spring application season.
On the agricultural front, economics continue to support planting corn over soybeans, and our planted corn forecast is 92 million acres with further upside possible given a favorable USDA's survey for spring planting intentions. Corn use growth is forecasted at 2% for the fertilizer year 2016 and '17 as demand is expected to rebound near 2014 levels. And December corn is currently trading near $3.90 per bushel, all positive signs for the farmer and for our business.
Now let me turn the call over to Dennis.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bert. In the first quarter of 2016, we generated $217 million of EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $0.11. Included in these results were, on a pretax basis, approximately $42 million of net foreign currency losses, $21 unrealized mark-to-ma
componenttext:
Thanks, Bert. In the first quarter of 2016, we generated $217 million of EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $0.11. Included in these results were, on a pretax basis, approximately $42 million of net foreign currency losses, $21 unrealized mark-to-market losses on our natural gas derivatives, $16 million in expansion cost for our Donaldsonville and Port Neal facilities and $14 million in transaction costs related to the OCI transaction and the CHS strategic venture. When taking these items into account, our adjusted EBITDA for the first quarter was $300 million and our adjusted net earnings per diluted share was $0.40.
Included in these results is a realized loss of $56 million or $0.79 per MMBtu on our natural gas hedges for the first quarter of 2016. This compares to realized loss of $32  million or $0.52 per MMBtu on natural gas hedges for the first quarter of 2015.
During the first quarter of 2016, the company did not enter into any additional natural gas hedges. Additionally, in the first quarter of 2016, the company placed into service the new UAN plant at Donaldsonville. We expect to place into service the new ammonia plant at Donaldsonville and the new ammonia and urea plants at Port Neal later this year.
As we mentioned on our last call, most of these assets will qualify for the 50% bonus depreciation for fiscal year 2016 as a result of the passage of the PATH Act by Congress last year. As a result of these additional assets being placed into service, the company expects to have significantly reduced cash tax payments for the year.
I want to take a brief moment to describe the mechanics of the CHS strategic venture. On February 1, 2016, we received $2.8 billion in our cash account related to this investment. Each quarter, we recognize a noncontrolling interest amount related to this investment, which, for the first quarter, was $17 million. However, the cash distribution payables semiannually to CHS may be different from the amount recorded as noncontrolling interest in any given period based on the terms of the agreement, which, in effect, provides a producer economics to CHS. The estimate of this distribution pertaining to the first quarter is approximately $30 million.
Moving on, for 2016, the company expects to have total capital expenditures in the range of $1.8 billion to $2 billion, of which, $1.3 billion to $1.4 billion will be used for the capacity expansion projects and the other $500 million to $600 million for sustaining improvement at other projects.
With that, Tony will provide some closing remarks before we open the call to Q&A.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dennis. I want to summarize why we continue to be so excited and optimistic about our business. The fundamentals of our business remain strong. There is a growing demand for our products, and we benefit from low-cost North American gas.Our conso
componenttext:
Thanks, Dennis. I want to summarize why we continue to be so excited and optimistic about our business. The fundamentals of our business remain strong. There is a growing demand for our products, and we benefit from low-cost North American gas.
Our consolidated gross margin was 30%, ex the impact of gas hedges, and our cash margins for incremental production are 50% or better. Our plants are running well. We had record production for urea in the first quarter and one of the top 3 quarters for ammonia production as well.
We fully expect to hit an all-time record for UAN production here in Q2 with the new diesel plant online. The expansion projects are almost done. We are mechanically complete on the Donaldsonville ammonia plant and within 2 months of being mechanically complete at Port Neal, so the spending is quickly coming to an end. When those plants are online, they will increase our productive capacity by more than 25% and, along with it, our corresponding cash flow generation as well.
Our balanced sheet credit metrics and liquidity are all strong. We have a solid investment grade rating. We have a $2 billion undrawn revolver, and we have $2.7 billion of cash on the balanced sheet at the quarter end. Finally, bonus depreciation will provide a significant cash flow benefits this year and next.
So although the pricing environment is weaker than we'd like, nonetheless, we are extremely excited about the bright future ahead and what the next few months hold for us.
With that, we will now open the line to answer your questions. Operator?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
