headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Graeme Welds, on for Chris. First question, was just wondering if you could help us to think about what the effect of your mark-to-market hedges will be once nat gas starts kind of rebounding off of its lows. Just any help on how the realized and
componenttext: This is Graeme Welds, on for Chris. First question, was just wondering if you could help us to think about what the effect of your mark-to-market hedges will be once nat gas starts kind of rebounding off of its lows. Just any help on how the realized and unrealized gains or losses will flow through the P&L from that. And then second question is just on your realized ammonia prices in 1Q. They were a bit lower than what we were expecting. And we were just wondering if you could help us parse out kind of where those tons are going and why that kind of came in at a slightly lower level than we were expecting.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Dennis. Why don't I start with the natural gas hedge and how to sort of think about that? Without getting into specific numbers, I think it's really easy that if you think about the disclosures about what we've made in the past. We've disclos
componenttext: Yes. This is Dennis. Why don't I start with the natural gas hedge and how to sort of think about that? Without getting into specific numbers, I think it's really easy that if you think about the disclosures about what we've made in the past. We've disclosed how many MMBtus we have hedged going forward, and there was a graph, I think, that we've put out in -- as part of the 4Q earnings release that basically mapped out exactly what those hedges are going through time and where they're priced. So as you think about the forward curve through that period, as that forward curve rises, if, in fact, it rises, it may fall as well. We don't know. So as we think about where that forward curve is when we valued it at quarter's end here at March 31 versus where it may move to through time in the quarter, that will have a change on sort of the mark-to-market because the mark-to-market stuff that you're seeing is in relation to hedges that have not been realized, that have been not closed out. So as they go through time, 2 things are happening: more of those things are being realized, so they're effectively falling off the forward map; and at the same time, the curve is rising and falling versus the price on those curves. You sort of add up the MMBtus and then the difference between where any given point is on the curve and where we are on the hedge curve, which we've disclosed, you can kind of come at it that way mathematically.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the second question, this is Bert, regarding the ammonia pricing and what was expected or what was possibly put out there by different groups, you have to understand that Q1 is not necessarily an ammonia application period, although as we stated in our
componenttext: On the second question, this is Bert, regarding the ammonia pricing and what was expected or what was possibly put out there by different groups, you have to understand that Q1 is not necessarily an ammonia application period, although as we stated in our prepared remarks, we had record pull out of our Blair terminal, and that was a phenomenon in Q1 that was predominantly in that Nebraska region. However, just as prices were very low in January for urea, they were also a very low for ammonia. We had not only on the import market, which is Tampa-driven, which is at $310 a metric ton or about $280 a short ton, that number got pulled into the United States in several regions, and prices were low. And we took the same tactic that we did with the urea. We decided not to sell into that market. The industrial percentage of our business in Q1 is higher, and that -- most industrial contracts are gas-based,during that period, you had $2 gas. And again, Tampa based, so I already gave you the Tampa number. We also had an export vessel, 25,000 tons that we exported at Tampa equivalents or a little bit below that. All that to say that the weight of that -- of the Q1 number was pushed more towards the industrial side of our business. You'll see that revert back to more of a traditional strip for Q2 as that's more of an ag base quarter.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Wong with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brett Wong with Piper Jaffray.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bert, you spoke about expected production phase out in China over the coming years. I was just wondering if you can talk about how much of that relates to kind of economics and how much to environmental. And from your trip, are there environmental pressur
componenttext: Bert, you spoke about expected production phase out in China over the coming years. I was just wondering if you can talk about how much of that relates to kind of economics and how much to environmental. And from your trip, are there environmental pressures in China that can result in faster phase out of the capacity there?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Tony and I did -- as Tony said in his remarks, spent a week, a little over 10 days, in Asia. We went to some other places. And the consistent message coming out of China for us was one of they're going through a change. And as we've said in the pa
componenttext: Yes. So Tony and I did -- as Tony said in his remarks, spent a week, a little over 10 days, in Asia. We went to some other places. And the consistent message coming out of China for us was one of they're going through a change. And as we've said in the past, each year seems to be a different economic year coming out of China. Incentives are different. Subsidies are different. Taxes are different. Production levels are different. And today, they're really struggling trying to find their way and trying different steps in order to maintain profitability. Last year, that step was record exports. We just don't see that going forward. It's unsustainable. And what they were doing last year was just sending product to the ports. Yantai, where we visited last year, there was probably 2 million, 2.5 million tons sitting in bags at the port ready for export unsold. What we're seeing transit -- as a transition to more market-based decisions is we've heard from several traders and participants that until they sell those tons, they're not going to move them to the port. A great economic decision, which we think will prevent some of the low prices that were coming in last year. So economics are driving a lot of decisions on how they look at -- on efficiencies, how they look at investments, how they're looking at shipments. And this year, first quarter and into the second quarter, the domestic market was much more profitable than the export market, and you saw a lot of producers pull away from the export market. So I think it's a maturing, and they're understanding what their options are. In 2011, '12 and '13 when urea was over $400, everybody made money. It was an easy decision to participate and produce. That's no longer going to be the case for several of the high-cost producers, those anthracite coal producers. And we think rationalization will continue. On an environmental front, all I can tell you is it's dirty. And we drove through several places in several cities, and both Tony and I were amazed. You see the pictures in the newspapers, it's different in real life. And you almost could cut through it, and you could see maybe a half a mile away. You drive by rivers. You drive by piles of garbage. That can't continue. Just as we had rivers burn in the '60s and '70s in Wisconsin and Lake Erie, we had to make the same kind of changes that they're going to have to make. They're going to have to change their effluent streams. They're going to have to capture some of these gas streams, and that will all come in with investment, and environmental awareness will take place.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we heard specifically on the environmental side is the central government has put in place certain parameters and thresholds, and then local governments are able to put tighter ones in place. They can't put more lax ones, and so it really depends upo
componenttext: What we heard specifically on the environmental side is the central government has put in place certain parameters and thresholds, and then local governments are able to put tighter ones in place. They can't put more lax ones, and so it really depends upon the region that you're in. But there are certainly some areas for which significant capital is required in order -- going to be required in order to keep running those plants. And based on the current economic outlook, we don't -- still see that capital being spent, and we heard that loud and clear.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just one more for me. If -- as you look to export more out of D'Ville, and I get that will be in time, but do you have plans to access the Brazilian nitrogen market? And how do you expect to kind of do that? Is there a large capital ne
componenttext: That's helpful. And just one more for me. If -- as you look to export more out of D'Ville, and I get that will be in time, but do you have plans to access the Brazilian nitrogen market? And how do you expect to kind of do that? Is there a large capital need there or partnership to gain access to that market?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'm going to let Bert answer the question, but let me just talk philosophically about it for a second, which is we have always tried to stick with our knitting in terms of things that we do really well and then find partners to participate in the
componenttext:
Yes. So I'm going to let Bert answer the question, but let me just talk philosophically about it for a second, which is we have always tried to stick with our knitting in terms of things that we do really well and then find partners to participate in the areas of the channel that -- where they do things well. We are not interested in taking on receivable risk from farmers. We're not interested in taking on currency risk. So when we participate in these markets, it tends not to be with owned assets on the ground in those locations where we're exposing ourselves to those kinds of risks. It tends to be with partnering with other people and selling it and then on a delivered basis, into their tanks or on an FOB basis.
But Bert, why don't you talk specifically about it?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're active in Brazil today. We were when KEYTRADE was with us, and we'll continue to be probably more involved as we do have the volume of exports that are available to us, but it'll have to be net-back-driven. Brazil has tended to be a very low
componenttext: Yes. So we're active in Brazil today. We were when KEYTRADE was with us, and we'll continue to be probably more involved as we do have the volume of exports that are available to us, but it'll have to be net-back-driven. Brazil has tended to be a very low-priced market in relation to the rest of the world's options. But we know those people down there. I spent 8 years in Brazil. I'll be down there next month with a group and intend to connect with some of the industry participants. As Tony said, we don't necessarily desire to be -- matter of fact, we do not desire to be asset owners in that market. We do not believe we need to be. We think that  the channel's well served. There are good partners down there. We desire to monetize our position immediately and not take the risks that Tony mentioned. I do think there are changes to Petrobras's asset base that are coming. I don't think they're -- I think they're on the high end of the cost curve. And I don't think where their assets are located and what they're doing today make a lot of sense. So you have a 5 million ton urea market that's available. A lot of the international producers are participating. We're developing UAN. We've shipped several cargoes down there, and we think that will grow -- I think it has a very good growth pattern. So you'll see us down there more and more.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Andrews with Morgan Stanley.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on Chinese imports to the U.S. and I recognize the 2015 data is a little bit skewed by the size of the exports from China in general. But I'm just curious, in -- of the 12 months of the year, in the United States, how many of those months
componenttext: Just a question on Chinese imports to the U.S. and I recognize the 2015 data is a little bit skewed by the size of the exports from China in general. But I'm just curious, in -- of the 12 months of the year, in the United States, how many of those months do you think we still need to actually physically have Chinese product come in? And how has that changed over the last couple of years? And do you think the risk is that in those months we really just don't need to cover that cost at all in the U.S. and, therefore, any Middle Eastern company can come in and sell at that price?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Traditionally, Chinese product has been perceived in -- as lower quality. Their granular product. Because how they move it to the port, how it's loaded on to vessels and the time, sometimes it sits in the port, it degrades and then it arrives because of a
componenttext: Traditionally, Chinese product has been perceived in -- as lower quality. Their granular product. Because how they move it to the port, how it's loaded on to vessels and the time, sometimes it sits in the port, it degrades and then it arrives because of a long voyage into the United States. And a lot of the comments we get back from our customers is they prefer not to buy it. So what you see today is there are 2 price levels in NOLA, for Chinese and non-Chinese. But we are an import market. And an import market will draw tons from everywhere, Middle East, Russia, Asia. And today, Chinese product trades at a discount. And I think as long as it trades at a differential low enough, people will buy it. That being said, Chinese participation and Chinese product participation in the North America market looks to be declining. You have a few that bring it in and blend it. And so what we see going forward, I think, the story, the broad story we're communicating today is that a part of these changes is probably Chinese product will remain more and more in Asia, maybe go into South America a little bit. But you'll see declining exports, which mean fewer imports into North America, most likely.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so does that mean that we don't necessarily need to have the -- I guess, what I'm trying to ask, is there now going to be a more localized cost curve based on where products are distributed to, rather than sort of the global cost curve.
componenttext: And so does that mean that we don't necessarily need to have the -- I guess, what I'm trying to ask, is there now going to be a more localized cost curve based on where products are distributed to, rather than sort of the global cost curve.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Vincent, I think even at the high watermark, there wasn't more than about 1.5 million tons from China that ever found its way to the U.S. Generally speaking, it's Arab Gulf tons that find -- and Canadian tons that's come into the U.S. marketplace. But
componenttext: So Vincent, I think even at the high watermark, there wasn't more than about 1.5 million tons from China that ever found its way to the U.S. Generally speaking, it's Arab Gulf tons that find -- and Canadian tons that's come into the U.S. marketplace. But from the North American perspective, it's mostly Arab Gulf, and the Chinese stuff is more around the fringe. So we see most of those tons being backed out. But North America is going to -- even after our projects come online and the other ones that are in construction today, North America will still import roughly 30% of its total nitrogen requirements. And so we've heard this noise about, oh, it's going to become a balanced market, but the people that say that include Trinidad tons as part of the North American balance. And the last time I looked on the map, Trinidad wasn't part of North America, at least the way my geography teachers taught it. So this notion, somehow, that the end market premium is going away, I'd say show me where the production is that's going to make that happen. Someone still has to bid those tons into the marketplace in order for there to be enough nitrogen to hit the ground in the corn belt. And that's not happening organically from new steel in the ground in that region. So we don't see that happening. Now yes, there is going to be a shifting trade balance as the new capacity comes online. We don't think Chinese tons make sense here anymore, but we're still pretty substantially an import marketplace.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Sandy Klugman with Vertical Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Sandy Klugman with Vertical Research.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the favorable start to the ammonia application season. Do you see this, in any way, detracting from later season demand for urea or UAN?
componenttext: You mentioned the favorable start to the ammonia application season. Do you see this, in any way, detracting from later season demand for urea or UAN?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, the total nitrogen need is still there. We had a very strong quarter-end pull of ammonia, and then we kind of went into a wet and cool period. You have to also remember, we had a poor fall, so the net end need for spring is fairly large. And
componenttext: No. Actually, the total nitrogen need is still there. We had a very strong quarter-end pull of ammonia, and then we kind of went into a wet and cool period. You have to also remember, we had a poor fall, so the net end need for spring is fairly large. And application tendencies have changed a little bit. I think there's a push to get your spring ammonia down. There's also going to be a spring side-dress ammonia season that's going to come, but a lot of folks are moving -- or a lot of farmers are moving towards split applications with either UAN and urea or going over the top with urea by plane. So what we see today and what we anticipate is a full utilization of the products that have made it into the market and low inventories coming out of Q2. But we have a lot of applications ahead of us. The Northern market, North Dakota, Canada are just kicking off now and going strong. We still have the side-dress season in Indiana and Ohio, this is all for ammonia, and then application on top. So we anticipate this season running a little bit longer, a little bit bigger with 92 million to 93 million acres of corn and don't anticipate that the fill season will begin until later in the year.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bert and Sandy, on that question, Bert jump in here, but I -- for 92 million, 93 million acres, we would normally anticipate about 4 million tons of ammonia hitting the ground.
componenttext: Bert and Sandy, on that question, Bert jump in here, but I -- for 92 million, 93 million acres, we would normally anticipate about 4 million tons of ammonia hitting the ground.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, 4 million or 4.5 million.
componenttext: Yes, 4 million or 4.5 million.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: 4.5 million tons. And so given the poor fall, you have to have all of these tons go down, otherwise, there's a nitrogen deficit, and it's tough to get enough urea, UAN to make up for the quantum of molecules that are the impact you have in ammonia tons, s
componenttext: 4.5 million tons. And so given the poor fall, you have to have all of these tons go down, otherwise, there's a nitrogen deficit, and it's tough to get enough urea, UAN to make up for the quantum of molecules that are the impact you have in ammonia tons, so.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's going on with weather today in Brazil with the impact, a negative impact for Brazil on their second-crop corn, you've seen the rally in corn now up to $3.90 there. I think December is at $3.85. But you're going to see farmers fertilize for yield, a
componenttext: What's going on with weather today in Brazil with the impact, a negative impact for Brazil on their second-crop corn, you've seen the rally in corn now up to $3.90 there. I think December is at $3.85. But you're going to see farmers fertilize for yield, and that extra bump, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 bushels is money in their pocket. We anticipate that will come from nitrogen.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, when you think about the medium-term supply-demand balance for the nitrogen industry, what's your approximation where benchmark global urea operating rates could be in 2020? And how does this compare to your expectations for the level at
componenttext: Great. And then, when you think about the medium-term supply-demand balance for the nitrogen industry, what's your approximation where benchmark global urea operating rates could be in 2020? And how does this compare to your expectations for the level at which CF will be able to operate its facilities?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, we're one of the lowest-cost producers globally. And given North America is in the import marketplace, we're going to run 24/7, 365. And I think the question isn't quite as easy as what's the aggregate operating rate because I think what happens
componenttext: So look, we're one of the lowest-cost producers globally. And given North America is in the import marketplace, we're going to run 24/7, 365. And I think the question isn't quite as easy as what's the aggregate operating rate because I think what happens is those people that are comfortably cash flow positive are going to run near 100%. They're going to keep their plants running. Those that are on the fringe are going to try as hard as they can to continue to run. And it's those that are really at the high cost ones that are going to ultimately shut down permanently. And we see most of those shutdowns happening in China, maybe some in Eastern Europe, but...

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Then the announcements out of Kuwait. Egypt's been having gas...
componenttext: Then the announcements out of Kuwait. Egypt's been having gas...

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Trinidad has got some curtailment problems and others. So there are some disruptions in other parts of the world, but in terms of permanent shuts -- shutdowns, most of that, I think, is going to be China and Middle East -- or I'm sorry, and Eastern
componenttext: Well, Trinidad has got some curtailment problems and others. So there are some disruptions in other parts of the world, but in terms of permanent shuts -- shutdowns, most of that, I think, is going to be China and Middle East -- or I'm sorry, and Eastern Europe. And otherwise, you're going to see a very high operating rate for those assets that are cash flow positive.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Roberts with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Roberts with UBS.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Chinese coal prices on Slide 9, you indicate no perceptible response to oil price changes. Do you think that's a lag issue, and it's still coming? Or do you think the linkage is now much weaker than it's been in the past because of the global oversuppl
componenttext: On Chinese coal prices on Slide 9, you indicate no perceptible response to oil price changes. Do you think that's a lag issue, and it's still coming? Or do you think the linkage is now much weaker than it's been in the past because of the global oversupply in coal?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I think that the dynamics around where the coal price change in China are not related to the oil price at all. It's absolutely related to that -- when we were over there, one of the things Bert and I consistently heard was the domestic coal pr
componenttext: No. I mean, I think that the dynamics around where the coal price change in China are not related to the oil price at all. It's absolutely related to that -- when we were over there, one of the things Bert and I consistently heard was the domestic coal price, the domestic coal price and where that's set. And it's not directly linked to external energy sources that you can track back to. A lot of it has to do, fundamentally, with just what's the cost of production and distribution within the country, and that's been relatively firm. And as Bert says, if anything, we see that likely ticking up instead of staying flat or going lower. So we don't see that being directly connected necessarily with the external energy environment, which is why when gas -- or oil price was $90 or $100, you didn't see it -- coal price in China running way up. And as oil prices come down, it has really a muted effect on internal pricing.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve Byrne with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve Byrne with Bank of America.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just continuing on with the discussion here about Chinese coal. Do you have an estimate of what fraction of China's anthracite-based nitrogen industry receives financial support from local governments and/or is back-integrated into the anthracite coal pro
componenttext: Just continuing on with the discussion here about Chinese coal. Do you have an estimate of what fraction of China's anthracite-based nitrogen industry receives financial support from local governments and/or is back-integrated into the anthracite coal production?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll ask -- I'll answer the second half of that and let Bert talk about the first half. We did explore the sort of the question of how much is integrated and the estimates that we got from people there. And also, looking back at our previous analysis a
componenttext: So I'll ask -- I'll answer the second half of that and let Bert talk about the first half. We did explore the sort of the question of how much is integrated and the estimates that we got from people there. And also, looking back at our previous analysis and work in China, suggests it's maybe in the somewhere in the 10%-ish plus or minus range that's actually integrated with coal production. Other than that, they tend to be more stand-alone facilities, not integrated with coal mining or ownership activities.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so Steve, on the question of -- I'm a little uncomfortable giving an exact percentage. I just don't have that today.
componenttext: And so Steve, on the question of -- I'm a little uncomfortable giving an exact percentage. I just don't have that today.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in the U.S. market, I wanted to drill in a little bit about a precision ag trend, and that is there's a couple of software programs out there in the corn belt to predict residual nitrogen mid-season. Wanted your view on those as to whether they
componenttext: Okay. And in the U.S. market, I wanted to drill in a little bit about a precision ag trend, and that is there's a couple of software programs out there in the corn belt to predict residual nitrogen mid-season. Wanted your view on those as to whether they might have an impact on nitrogen use trends and/or maybe a shift towards UAN.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're a big proponent of precision ag and work with a lot of our larger, more sophisticated customers to how we can help serve that whole trend because, coupled with precision ag and the 4Rs and the proper utilization of our products only lead to good
componenttext: So we're a big proponent of precision ag and work with a lot of our larger, more sophisticated customers to how we can help serve that whole trend because, coupled with precision ag and the 4Rs and the proper utilization of our products only lead to good outcomes, which is higher yield, more efficient use, more environmentally friendly practices, and we're a big supporter. And yes, that is the trend you're seeing, is that UAN, over time, we believe in split applications, coupled with possibly other products or adding different products along with UAN. Ammonium thiosulfates continue to grow because there's a need for S. So a lot of these coupled together, you'll see the better, and this is why you're seeing consolidation in this space, that the better more financially solid retail groups are moving towards the service-providing and value-creating aspects of precision ag for the farmer.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Steve, to tag along with Bert's answer there, ultimately, where we see that headed is higher crop density. The more precision the improvements in the field, you get higher densities of crop, which then, actually, the way we project it, increases the a
componenttext: And Steve, to tag along with Bert's answer there, ultimately, where we see that headed is higher crop density. The more precision the improvements in the field, you get higher densities of crop, which then, actually, the way we project it, increases the amount of nitrogen per unit of land as opposed to the other way around. And so in aggregate, we think this is a very favorable trend, not only because of the environmental and social aspects of what Bert talked about but be -- also just because we view consumption and demand increasing in North America as a result of that.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matthew Korn with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew Korn with Barclays.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there anything -- I was very curious about your commentary around the distribution asset and how hard that's running. I'm curious whether there's been anything meaningful that's changed with the -- with your costs on the distribution and transportation
componenttext: Is there anything -- I was very curious about your commentary around the distribution asset and how hard that's running. I'm curious whether there's been anything meaningful that's changed with the -- with your costs on the distribution and transportation side. And also, I guess, similarly, have ramped-up operations at Donaldsonville caused any other kind of near-term inefficiencies, are there any costs that might be rolling on or rolling off? Because really, what I'm trying to figure out is ex the natural gas noise, which you all are delineating, are there any shifts in your cost structure kind of product by product that I should notice going into the second quarter to third quarter?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Matthew, a couple of things. One of which is as we announced relative to the TNH business we had an unscheduled downtime in Verdigris for one of our ammonia plants, and that also carried on to one of the UAN plants there was well. And so as a result
componenttext: Yes. Matthew, a couple of things. One of which is as we announced relative to the TNH business we had an unscheduled downtime in Verdigris for one of our ammonia plants, and that also carried on to one of the UAN plants there was well. And so as a result of unscheduled downtime, we ended up with a fair bit of fixed overhead absorption into that business without the corresponding production tons that go along with it. On the distribution side, Bert has really led some investments that we've made at the distribution terminals to allow them to both receive inbound and also export outbound ammonium more quickly, which allows us to have the kind of results we did at Blair in the first quarter leading into the second quarter. And so as some of the initiatives like the 4Rs that Bert talked about means that we see likely less ammonia going down in the fall being able to really pump it out hard in the spring is a critical thing. And that's part of the reason why we've made the investments that we've had is to really shift and be able to move those tons quickly. The other thing that you got to look at, I'd say, Matthew, is we do have now both the urea and UAN plants at Donaldsonville operating, and so we do have quite a bit more depreciation expense that's going to be rolling through the P&L than what we've had in the past. And as we bring on the D'Ville ammonia plant and then Port Neal, you're going to see those depreciation numbers continue to climb. So while that's an important thing to look at, again, we really focus on cash flow generation. And so our focus, the thing that we would point you to is really take a hard look at how much operating cash flow we're generating going forward, that's a much better metric than the distortion of what the new depreciation is going to be in terms of the underlying health and economics of the business.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, Tony. That's actually very helpful. Let me then follow up with another question regarding your China trip. I'm curious whether you got a sense that there was indeed much better-than-expected Chinese domestic demand for nitrogen over this past seas
componenttext: Got it, Tony. That's actually very helpful. Let me then follow up with another question regarding your China trip. I'm curious whether you got a sense that there was indeed much better-than-expected Chinese domestic demand for nitrogen over this past season, and whether you sense any risk that as -- that demand dries up over the next several weeks that there's expectations that the exports could see an uptick later on into this summer.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we had -- we did see the domestic demand, but a lot of changes are taking place in Chinese agriculture. And you've been reading about these and seeing pictures. We still have a lot of smaller operations in the South. As you go North, you're seeing a lo
componenttext: So we had -- we did see the domestic demand, but a lot of changes are taking place in Chinese agriculture. And you've been reading about these and seeing pictures. We still have a lot of smaller operations in the South. As you go North, you're seeing a lot of bigger -- some of the state-owned operations are fairly large. And so we do see some positive trends. There's a huge domestic market estimates or when you include industrial demand as well as agricultural demand for urea and ammonium sulfate. It is large, and I do think it's going to grow. But a change in crop subsidies for corn and how that's going to impact probably will have some change but I don't think as much as people are anticipating. So relative to as they roll off their domestic demand period and enter Q2 into Q3, we think exports, we've said, are going to be around 10 million tons for the year. We're still with that number, so off about 4 million tons from last year. I think there is going to be some prolonged downtimes at several plants. I don't think you're going to see the push to stuff the ports for exports. But we have to see this develop and see if our hypothesis holds true.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to highlight that last point that Bert mentioned, and he mentioned it earlier. I think it's a really good one, which is everyone we spoke with, in fact, the general manager of the port operations at Yantai called this out as well, which is that the
componenttext: I want to highlight that last point that Bert mentioned, and he mentioned it earlier. I think it's a really good one, which is everyone we spoke with, in fact, the general manager of the port operations at Yantai called this out as well, which is that the producers are not just blindly shipping product into the port and then have it available for the traders to kind of cover short positions in the -- on tenders, the way they used to. They're being much more rational about only taking product to port, and they've made some investments on rail load-out and load-in infrastructure, and so forth, in order to be able to move quickly. And so they're waiting until they actually see business that they want to take before they start moving product to port. And that's one of the reasons that they claim anyway that they've had some better discipline in terms of pricing into some of these tenders this year than they have in the past, which is it's fundamentally different behavior on the part of the producers. And they're getting away from letting the traders just short these tenders like crazy and then go into the overflowing ports to cover. And so we think, not only is the rationalization of capacity improving kind of the overall market dynamics, but the behavioral aspect of it is really important as well.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Connelly with CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tony, I want to be respectful of not commenting on OCI, but if I remember correctly, you said that OCI will be very helpful in your Latin access for Donaldsonville. And I think you're saying today that you're doing pretty well without it. So can you just
componenttext: Tony, I want to be respectful of not commenting on OCI, but if I remember correctly, you said that OCI will be very helpful in your Latin access for Donaldsonville. And I think you're saying today that you're doing pretty well without it. So can you just remind us what the difference is? And then the second easy question, can you remind us where you are with Wever?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Mark, one of the benefits in terms of the OCI transaction is that the trading entity that they have in Dubai and it allows for very efficient trading of products out of Donaldsonville into other parts of the world. That's not to say that we don't
componenttext: Yes. So Mark, one of the benefits in terms of the OCI transaction is that the trading entity that they have in Dubai and it allows for very efficient trading of products out of Donaldsonville into other parts of the world. That's not to say that we don't have access to those markets. In fact, Bert and his team has -- or have developed those relationships all across the globe. And it's not an issue of access to those demand centers or ability to get product there. It's more of the efficiency and the cost...

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The efficiency of how you do it. Okay. Okay, super. That's very helpful. And can you just give us update on Wever?
componenttext: The efficiency of how you do it. Okay. Okay, super. That's very helpful. And can you just give us update on Wever?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'd say, Mark, OCI is a publicly traded company. Wever is their project. It's much more appropriate to allow them to answer any questions related to Wever. I wouldn't want someone else answering a question about how Donaldsonville [indiscernible]. I do
componenttext: So I'd say, Mark, OCI is a publicly traded company. Wever is their project. It's much more appropriate to allow them to answer any questions related to Wever. I wouldn't want someone else answering a question about how Donaldsonville [indiscernible]. I don't feel appropriate answering questions on Wever.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Adam Samuelson with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Adam Samuelson with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. A lot of ground's been covered, but I wanted to return, Bert, I guess, to the comment you made about the subsidies in China on the demand outlook medium term, and you just said you don't think the impact is as big as some people think. And I maybe wa
componenttext: Yes. A lot of ground's been covered, but I wanted to return, Bert, I guess, to the comment you made about the subsidies in China on the demand outlook medium term, and you just said you don't think the impact is as big as some people think. And I maybe wanted you to expand on that a little bit. I heard some talk about some pretty sizable reductions in corn acres in China, they have application rates that for urea, for nitrogen, at least, that are pretty close to Western levels, and I wanted to just get your thoughts on why you don't think the domestic demand impact from subsidy change will be as big as people think.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you're focused on the corn subsidies, not the production of fertilizer subsidies. Is that correct?
componenttext: So I think you're focused on the corn subsidies, not the production of fertilizer subsidies. Is that correct?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the demand side.
componenttext: Yes, on the demand side.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. So look, China -- as we said about fertilizer, I'd say the same thing about corn. And China has been changing. They have subsidized corn production to the tune of $9 a bushel, we expect. And those numbers are coming off. They do have -- they ha
componenttext: Yes. Okay. So look, China -- as we said about fertilizer, I'd say the same thing about corn. And China has been changing. They have subsidized corn production to the tune of $9 a bushel, we expect. And those numbers are coming off. They do have -- they have had, as with other commodity products, high levels of storage and stored materials for food security. And so what we expect from that is that [indiscernible]these subsidies will [indiscernible] corn of good quality. We don't think it is. And that some of that corn will be sold in different ways or possibly even dumped. But I think we're in the middle of a changing market and how that totally impacts the total end number because corn will be replaced with another product, probably wheat or cotton or something else. And so I can't give you what that -- is it 1 million, 6 million tons of urea equivalent? I don't have that number.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, the other thing that we heard also from a number of the participants over there is there are some subsidy things that can come in and go, but it's hard to reverse thousands of years of behavior and practice. And the Chinese farmers sort of look at u
componenttext: Adam, the other thing that we heard also from a number of the participants over there is there are some subsidy things that can come in and go, but it's hard to reverse thousands of years of behavior and practice. And the Chinese farmers sort of look at urea as being the really critical important element of fertilization for yield. And even though there's some view of balanced fertilization needs to increase, the sense that we got from the people over there is they don't expect much of a change.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then maybe if you just -- you talked about Donaldsonville production rates that are already running above nameplate, and that's something that you think is sustainable. Maybe help size kind of the magnitude there. And what kind of
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then maybe if you just -- you talked about Donaldsonville production rates that are already running above nameplate, and that's something that you think is sustainable. Maybe help size kind of the magnitude there. And what kind of output levels from the new plants do you think are actually achievable in medium term maybe above nameplate?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Donaldsonville urea is running north of 10% above nameplate. So nameplate is 3,850, and we've seen rates north of 4,500, 4,800 tons a day. So that plant is really humming along. And on the UAN plant, the nameplate on that is, and everything I've g
componenttext: Yes. So Donaldsonville urea is running north of 10% above nameplate. So nameplate is 3,850, and we've seen rates north of 4,500, 4,800 tons a day. So that plant is really humming along. And on the UAN plant, the nameplate on that is, and everything I've given you is short tons, is 5,050 a day. And we've seen rates north of 5,800. And again, as I've said, we haven't even really even pushed it to max rates yet, and so we think 20% is likely achievable at D'Ville UAN. So it was already the largest single-train UAN plant in the world even at nameplate. We're getting much, much better results on that already. And the way that we went about designing these plants was understanding from a process flow perspective where the bottlenecks were, what the things we needed to upsize where, and that's the same approach we've taken on the ammonia plant as well as at Port Neal. And so while it's a little early to claim victory on the ammonia production yet, our expectation is that we're going to be in a same kind of region, relative to production on the ammonia and also at Port Neal. And the important thing to also highlight, Adam, is that when we did the original investment thesis and justification, it was strictly based on nameplate production. So every incremental ton that we're getting off of these plants show up at that 50% to 60% cash margin number, and all of those are just sort of free cash into the equation on the economics of the plant. So we feel very good about where we are.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Don Carson with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Don Carson with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions on pricing. One, near term, Bert, you talked about high mix of noncorn belt ammonia in Q1. How does that mix change as you get into Q2? And between having higher a proportion of corn belt sales and not much of a forward order book, I assume
componenttext: Two questions on pricing. One, near term, Bert, you talked about high mix of noncorn belt ammonia in Q1. How does that mix change as you get into Q2? And between having higher a proportion of corn belt sales and not much of a forward order book, I assume that you'll be able to capture most of this recent run-up in corn belt ammonia pricing. And then longer term, as we look in the second half of this year with more capacity coming online, are you seeing pressure from distributors to have price protection on nitrogen products like they've been getting on potash where virtually all potash now is price protected from the manufacturer?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for the near term, you're correct that ammonia in Q1 for ag application, we did get April pulled into March, but we're still going to see a very healthy Q2 application period. We've worked through April. We're into May. And again, as we march forward,
componenttext: So for the near term, you're correct that ammonia in Q1 for ag application, we did get April pulled into March, but we're still going to see a very healthy Q2 application period. We've worked through April. We're into May. And again, as we march forward, that northerly tier starts kicking in. So I don't have exact numbers for you, but we're planning on a historical spring, 6-month period. We look at this as a 6-month cycle and -- for spring. And pricing, you're right. You're correct. It did rally quite a bit from $100 to $150 a ton. And we did have tons available to sell, and we anticipate that we have captured a pretty good part of that. You're correct, there is capacity coming online in UAN for us, urea with CF and some others as well as ammonia. The price protection is not in the mix. What we have seen happen with potash and phosphate on price protection is it's really a short-term gain, long-term loss. And as you put product in the inventory for periods like this spring when you could have had price appreciation, you do not get that, and it creates a negative dynamic in the market that the risk stays with the producer and you continue to push that product out from logistical basis, and it just doesn't help the market at all. We believe that we need to price our products appropriately for our retail and wholesale customers, and that the risk then stays with them. And they get a reward at -- when they sell and they provide services, they provide different products. It's part of their product portfolio. We're just 1 participant in that chain. And so we just don't see that price protection has a future in North America. At least in nitrogen, it doesn't.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Said differently, being the largest producer globally and larger than the next 6 combined in North America, we have no interest in -- we're completely unwilling to engage in that kind of practice. And we'll find a way where liquidity is achieved in the ma
componenttext: Said differently, being the largest producer globally and larger than the next 6 combined in North America, we have no interest in -- we're completely unwilling to engage in that kind of practice. And we'll find a way where liquidity is achieved in the marketplace, so that, that doesn't happen here, at least in nitrogen.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 CF Industries Holdings Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over t
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Second Quarter 2016 CF Industries Holdings Earnings Conference Call. My name is Danielle, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to the host for today, Mr. Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, please proceed.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Danielle. Good morning and thanks for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings, Inc. I'm Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations, and with me are Tony Will, our President and Chief Financial Officer; Dennis Kelleher, our
componenttext:
Thanks, Danielle. Good morning and thanks for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings, Inc. I'm Dan Aldridge, Director of Investor Relations, and with me are Tony Will, our President and Chief Financial Officer; Dennis Kelleher, our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Bert Frost, our Senior Vice President of Sales, Market Development and Supply Chain; and Chris Bohn, our Senior Vice President of Manufacturing and Distribution.
CF Industries Holdings, Inc. reported its second quarter 2016 results yesterday afternoon as did Terra Nitrogen Company, L.P. On this call, we'll review the CF Industries' results in detail and discuss our outlook referring to several of the slides that are posted on our website. At the end of the call, we'll host a question-and-answer session  related to the company's financial results for the quarter. 
As you review the news releases posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at cfindustries.com and as you listen to this conference call, please recognize that they contain forward-looking statements as defined by federal securities laws. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed in Slide 2 of the accompanying  presentation and from time to time, in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today, and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
This conference call will include a discussion of certain non-GAAP financial measures. In each case, a presentation of the most directly comparable financial measure calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP and coinciding with consolation of the non-GAAP measures to the most to run the comparable financial measure calculated and presented, in accordance with GAAP is provided in the earnings release and the slides for this webcast presentation on the company's website, www.cfindustries.com. 
Now, let me introduce Tony Will, our President and CEO.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we posted our financial results for the second quarter of 2016 in which we generated EBITDA of $329 million. Adjusted EBITDA was $342 million after taking into account unrealized mark-to-market hedgin
componenttext:
Thanks, Dan, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we posted our financial results for the second quarter of 2016 in which we generated EBITDA of $329 million. 
Adjusted EBITDA was $342 million after taking into account unrealized mark-to-market hedging gains, cost related to determination of the OCI transaction; net foreign currency losses on intercompany loans and expenses related to the capacity expansion projects.
Included in these results and not adjusted for is a realized loss on natural gas hedges of $61 million. 
For the first half 2016, EBITDA was $536 million, while adjusted EBITDA was $642 million after taking into account the same factors as for the second quarter. The first half results included realized loss on natural gas hedges of $117 million, which was not adjusted for. 
So even with the challenging conditions in the gold fertilizer market, our underlying business performance remained strong. 
Before turning the call over to Bert and Dennis to give details on the quarter, I want to provide some observations and thoughts about the nitrogen market and our response to current industry conditions. There are some industry elements that are more structural and permanent in nature, while others tend to be more temporal. Fortunately, the elements that are structural tend to be strengthen and benefit CF. These include the global nitrogen demand continues to grow at roughly 2% per year, so there is strength underpinning our industry. Natural gas represents about 2/3 to 3/4 of the cash cost of producing nitrogen and North America has a long-term natural gas cost advantage.
North America is one of the largest nitrogen consumption regions where demand far exceeds domestic supply and, therefore, is heavily dependent upon imported products. 
CF is the world's low-cost nitrogen leader with the largest North American interior production and distribution system. CF's nitrogen ton production will increase by more than 25% in the next few months, and as a result, CF has the enviable position of being structural advantaged and one of the most profitable nitrogen manufacturers in the world with significant growth imminent. 
However, the industry is under pressure facing several significant challenges. Fortunately, these issues tend to be more transitory in nature and include the nitrogen industry as a state of significant overcapacity with additional new capacity yet to still come on stream through 2017. However, there is little-to-no new capacity additions currently in sight beyond 2017, and with underlying demand growth in nitrogen, the global supply-demand balance should start to resolve beginning in 2018. 
The combination of access nitrogen capacity with lower global energy cost, coupled with the valuation of certain key currencies and assisted by low freight have led to the dramatic fall in nitrogen product prices. We expect this situation to persist in the near term with prices under continued pressure in 2017.
However, even in these conditions, CF enjoys greater than 30% gross margins. I want to pause for a moment and reemphasize this last point. We operate in a commodity business, and even in the face of significant industry overcapacity with prices that have cratered, CF Industries was able to deliver first half 2016 gross margin of 35%. How was that possible in a commodity industry, you might ask? The answer is though although the global cost curve has widened with new capacity additions and has flattened because of lower global energy cost, it is certainly not flat, far from it. 
North America producers still enjoy a very significant advantage. With our realized price of urea roughly $250 per ton in the second quarter and with gas around $3 per MMBtu, the typical North American producer earns approximately 50% cash margin on incremental production. The take away here is not all commodities are created equally, and we occupy a very advantaged position within the nitrogen industry. 
Current industry conditions are at the level that we believe is unsustainable over the medium-term. Pricing is below cash cost for a significant amount of total global production, and industry profitability in many regions is too low to support normal maintenance and turnaround activity let alone equity returns and certainly well below that's required investments for new capacity. 
This situation is leading to curtailment or permanent closure of high-cost production. China alone has announced closure of over 4 million tons of urea since the first quarter and over 7.5 million tons year-to-date, with utilization rates currently around 60%. 
Similarly, producers in countries with relatively high cost, such as Lithuania, Hungary and the Ukraine have utilization rates under 60% as well. The net result is that although we expect difficult industry pricing conditions to persist through next year, the lack of meaningful new construction activity after 2017, coupled with expected capacity closures, is expected to lead to price recovery beginning in 2018. 
Against this backdrop, CF's long-term strategy remains unchanged, which is to focus on operational excellence by being the safe, efficient, reliable operator of our assets, while maximizing returns by leveraging our world-leading production distribution network.  Grow our cash flow per share by delivering accretive initiatives with returns well above our cost of capital and maintain investment grade ratings and a strong balanced sheet after which, excess cash is returned to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. 
Our plan over the next 18 months is consistent with our long-standing strategy and addresses the current challenging industry environment. Specifically, we will complete and start up our major expansion projects at Donaldsonville in Port Neal. At Donaldsonville, we have fired up the reformer and expect ammonia production to begin during this quarter. 
At Port Neal, off sites and utilities are complete and operational, and ammonia production is expected to begin late third quarter or early fourth quarter with the urea plant to follow closely thereafter.
We will reduce annual CapEx to less than $450 million starting next year. This level of spend allows for continued safe, reliable and compliant operations, while reducing discretionary spending and conserving cash. We will reduce our controllable expenses and we'll maintain a strong balanced sheet by preserving cash. To do this, we have suspended our share repurchase program, and we'll be in a position to deliver in 2018 when $800 million of debt matures.
Now, let me turn the call over to Bert and Dennis, who will discuss our performance for the quarter and our outlook in more detail. Bert?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Given the challenging market for nitrogen, we are pleased with our sales outlook for the quarter as it demonstrates the active role we take in responding the shifts in global supply and demand, market opportunities and customer needs. A lowe
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Given the challenging market for nitrogen, we are pleased with our sales outlook for the quarter as it demonstrates the active role we take in responding the shifts in global supply and demand, market opportunities and customer needs. A lower pricing environment of the second quarter were driven global oversupply with an excess of tons targeted to the U.S. despite NOLA and Tampa trading below international parity. 
In North America, the quarter began with solid demand at the beginning of April that helped to support selling prices. The strong run we witnessed in March for ammonium applications resulted in a portion of seasonal demand being pulled forward into the first quarter, which had a negative impact on the volume of second quarter ammonia shipments. 
The positive pricing position during the first quarter lasted  for approximately 3 weeks into the second quarter after which, pricing moved steadily lower for all products.
In early April, there was a tale of 2 Corn Belts in U.S. with Western farms planting on time, while the Eastern States were hampered by several weeks of wet and cold weather that delayed fertilizer applications in the middle of the season. This delays allows wholesalers and traders a window to import additional product and supply eventually exceeded demand. 
As a result, pricing fell throughout the quarter and hit levels that did not appear to make economic sense. By the middle of the quarter, wholesale liquidation took place, pushing prices even lower with importers struggling to generate cash positive returns.
The combination of additional imported product and subsequent liquidation pressured the urea barge market down below $200 per short ton FOB NOLA by early May. By the end of the quarter, the NOLA value for urea had fallen to just below $175 a short ton. 
Against this backdrop, the company's realized price for urea during the second quarter was $247 per short ton, a significant premium to prices reported at the U.S. Gulf. 
CF also responded to changing conditions by actively leveraging our scale, efficiency and expertise in distribution, targeting new alternative destinations and logistical options. Our fleet over 5,500 railcars and 32 barges is complemented by over 2.5 million tons of North American storage and access to both the new Star and Magellan ammonia pipelines. 
The recent completion of our urea injection terminal at Garner, Iowa affords us new flexibility in how we move ammonia throughout the pipeline. By gaining the ability to reinject ammonia at this site, it allows our teams to instantaneously transport products from the Western Corn Belt to the Eastern Corn Belt, which is a tremendous benefit to have as Port Neal comes on later this year. 
In rail, we are identifying new approaches in how we can better transport additional volume. In the prior year, our teams did not have a single unit train departed Donaldsonville site. In 2016, however, we have loaded 19 unit trains to date. For those who may not be familiar with shipping, unit trains become increasingly economical as the volume transport increases and with the capacity expansion projects coming online, we have leveraged that additional volume to our benefit.
Additionally, the recent draft with the Service Transportation Board's language on competitor switching are encouraging and present additional opportunities to streamline rail distribution routes and reduce costs. 
Our team also responded to changes in the domestic fertilizer business through our ability to switch production quickly and safely from one product to another. As I described earlier, imports continue to pressure NOLA urea prices late in the quarter. However, during this time, UAM was trading at a premium to urea on a nitrogen equivalent basis. We responded this opportunity by pivoting our capacity to maximize our UAN production at the expense of urea. As a result, we're able to better capture the nutrient basis differential that was priced into the market at that time. 
This up to improve our average price per ton for UAN, which is $202 per short ton for the second quarter of 2016. Many of our investors have heard us describe this capability that's built into our system before, and the second quarter was a prime example of our production and distribution flexibility and action. 
In aggregate, the combined result of an increased focus on system-wide maximization with healthy price realizations across the 3 major products, ammonia, urea and UAN. They were notably higher when compared to the reference published prices at NOLA and Tampa. We believe the  2016 denotes the high watermark for urea capacity additions globally, and we do not expect any new capacity to be added to the global system beyond 2017 and into the foreseeable future. 
As we said many times, farmers must apply nitrogen every year to feed the world. As such, global demand for nitrogen continues to grow at an approximate rate of between 1.5% and 2.5% per year, or the [indiscernible] at 2.7 million to 4.6 million metric tons of gross urea capacity. While this continued demand growth will absorb excess supply in the coming years, as Tony said, we see tangible evidence today that suggest that additional rationalization should continue to occur throughout the global system. 
In the current pricing environment, estimates indicate that despite the decrease in the cost curve, many global nitrogen producers are estimated to be operating at or near their variable costs. The result thus far has been more than 8 million short tons of globally urea capacity that has been shut down in 2016 with the vast majority of that capacity located in China. 
The steady decrease in Chinese operating rates to the lowest point in more than 4 years support this observation. Compared to decreased domestic pricing, Chinese producers have historically looked to the export market. However, the trailing 12-month average of their exports have declined steadily since its peak in July of 2015 and prices globally were notably higher than they are today. 
Accordingly, Chinese exports are expected to reach full year volume of approximately 9 million to 10 million metric tons in 2016 compared to more than 14 million metric tons exported in 2015. 
Domestic prices in China are down approximately 30% year-over-year and at a price of $195 per metric ton FOB China for an export, we estimate that up to half of the urea industry in China is unprofitable. 
Moving on to the North American natural gas market. April Henry Hub prices cash prices began the second quarter below $2 per MMBtu, aided by a warmer normal first quarter. Cash prices traded as well as  $1.71 per MMBtu in mid--April, primarily due to a healthy storage balance and reduced demand coming out of winter. After any of withdrawal season with nearly 2.5 Tcf  in storage, strong demand and production declines contributed to a slower-than-normal start to the injection season. Throughout the quarter, natural gas prices have trended upward with smaller-than-average storage injections and forecast for a warm summer contributing to the increases. 
On June 30, natural gas traded at $2.93 in the cash market, an increase of $1.22 per MMBtu from the quarter ago. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Dennis.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bert. In the second quarter of 2016, we generated $329 million of EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $0.20. Included in these results were, on a pretax basis, approximately $211 million in unrealized net mark-to-market gains on our natural g
componenttext:
Thanks, Bert. In the second quarter of 2016, we generated $329 million of EBITDA and earnings per diluted share of $0.20. Included in these results were, on a pretax basis, approximately $211 million in unrealized net mark-to-market gains on our natural gas derivatives; $165 million in transaction cost, mainly comprised of the termination fee of $150 million paid to OCI; $38 million of net foreign currency losses related to intercompany loans; and $19 million expansion cost for our Donaldsonville and Port Neal facilities. 
When taking these items into account, our adjusted EBITDA for the second quarter was $342 million and our adjusted earnings per diluted share was $0.33.
Included in these results is a realized loss of $61 million or $0.75 per MMBtu on our natural gas hedges for the second quarter of 2016. During the second quarter of 2016, the company did that enter into an additional natural gas hedges. 
In 2017, we expect to receive a refund of approximately $690 million related to the carryback of certain U.S. tax losses from the current year to prior tax years associated with the bonus depreciation provision of the [indiscernible] half. The amount of this refund is dependent upon the timing and completion for certain capital projects. 
As of June 30 2016, our prepaid income taxes were $855 million, including approximately the $690 million related to the carryback of these U.S. tax losses.
The effective tax rate for the second quarter was 53.2% and was impacted by the following items: first, we recaptured the manufacturing profits deduction we took in 2014 when we decide to carryback current tax losses to that year; second, we established a valuation allowance against certain deferred tax asset related to our foreign operations. These were partially offset by the deduction of previously capitalized OCI transaction cost. The net effect of these 3 items is about a 20% increase in our tax rate. Excluding these items, our tax rate for the second quarter would have been closer to the statutory rate of 35%. Interest expense for the second quarter was $61 million and include the following: $76 million in interest on our outstanding debt plus $32 million in amortization of loan fees, which is included amounts related to the terminated bridge Alona associated with the OCI transaction less $47 million in capitalizing interest. 
The first distribution from CF nitrogen to CHS under our strategic venture with them occurred on August 1, 2016, for $75 million. This total is comprised of approximately $30 million related to the partial first quarter of 2016 during which, the strategic venture commenced and approximately  $45 million related to the second quarter of 2016. 
If you recall, each quarter, we recognize a noncontrolling interest amount related to this investment, which for the first quarter was $17 million and for the second quarter was $23 million. 
However, the cash distribution payables to CHS may be different from the amount recorded as noncontrolling interest in any given period based on the terms of our agreement, which in effect, provide producer economics to CHS. 
For 2016, the company expects to have total capital expenditures in the range of $2 billion to $2.2 billion, of which, $1.6 billion to $1.7 billion will be for the capacity expansion projects and $450 million to $500 million for sustaining improvement and other projects. The increase I project spend is mainly related to labor productivity issues with third party contractors. 
For 2017, we expect capital expenditures to be in the range of $400 million to $450 million. This will focus on sustaining capital to ensure our plants and facilities operate in a safe, compliant and reliable fashion. As Tony mentioned, we are reducing capital expenditures, sustaining a strong liquidity position and maintaining and defending our investment grade credit ratings. 
On July 29, 2016, the company amended its senior unsecured revolving credit agreement to reduce the size of the facility from $2 billion back to the $1.5 billion in place prior to the announcement of the OCI transaction and to increase the maximum total net leverage covenant from the third quarter of 2016 to the fourth quarter of 2017. 
We have provided a scheduled in the press release that goes over the details. This will provide us with additional liquidity and flexibility should we need it. 
We're also in the process of seeking a similar amendment to mark private placement of note holders. As of June 30, 2016, we were well in compliance with all covenants and indebtedness. 
The amendment we have made to our revolver and the amendment we are seeking to make to our private placement notes reflect the prudent and proactive manner in which we manage our capital structure. Additionally, we have been making reductions in our controllable caused by managing down activity and M&A and Information Technology, along with a reduction in third party plant level contractor expenses. 
With that, Tony will provide some closing remarks before we open the call to Q&A.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dennis. CF's business model, assets and team are resilient. Although falling energy prices, capacity growth and currency devaluations have created an extended period of low prices, CF's structural advantages continue.Ultimately, we believe highe
componenttext:
Thanks, Dennis. CF's business model, assets and team are resilient. Although falling energy prices, capacity growth and currency devaluations have created an extended period of low prices, CF's structural advantages continue.
Ultimately, we believe higher costs capacity will shut down, leading to a recovery in nitrogen prices and margins. We remain among the lowest cost nitrogen producers in the world, have significant imminent growth in the next 2 months and have advantaged access to the world's largest consumption regions. Our business remains strong, and we have a bright future ahead. 
With that, we will now open the line to your questions. Denio?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Chris Parkinson from Crédit Suisse.
