headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we run our plants at capacity every day. So we're obviously looking to optimize our production capacity based on ammonia and what's available and then how we can upgrade, which is the higher-margin product, for urea, UAN and ammonia. And so i
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we run our plants at capacity every day. So we're obviously looking to optimize our production capacity based on ammonia and what's available and then how we can upgrade, which is the higher-margin product, for urea, UAN and ammonia. And so if you look, the aggregate number is going to be just based on our capacity, and we'll move that product into the global market as well as the U.S. But I'd say 18 million tons.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's product tons, not nutrient tons.
componenttext: That's product tons, not nutrient tons.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Matthew Korn from Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Matthew Korn from Barclays.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you've all been pretty consistent in your call, of course, for U.S. natural gas prices to remain low. In your deck, you're laying out this view of what's available at $3.50. I'm interested in your view on the medium- to long-term relative natural gas c
componenttext: So you've all been pretty consistent in your call, of course, for U.S. natural gas prices to remain low. In your deck, you're laying out this view of what's available at $3.50. I'm interested in your view on the medium- to long-term relative natural gas costs in exporting regions like Ukraine. Your cost curve notes in your presentation acknowledge there's been substantial year-over-year compression in the spread versus the U.S. price. How do you regard the threat that a globally more evened out energy price environment can place a cap on your profitability going forward, even once we see some of this excess supply today absorbed?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as we look at the factors, Matthew, that could affect that, one of the big ones is just where Russia Gazprom prices their exports to places like the Ukraine and so forth. There's another one that is kind of how LNG continues to evolve and how
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as we look at the factors, Matthew, that could affect that, one of the big ones is just where Russia Gazprom prices their exports to places like the Ukraine and so forth. There's another one that is kind of how LNG continues to evolve and how much of the new production ends up moving off of kind of oil-linked-based contracts more on to a spot basis. We think over time it's about $3 or $4 to get any sort of reasonable capital recovery on LNG contracts. And so if you say Henry Hub trades at kind of $3, that means LNG importing regions should trade somewhere in the neighborhood of $7 or maybe a little bit above by the time you re-gas and distribute from there into production plants. So as we look forward, our view is we're likely to be able to enjoy, call it, $4 plus or minus of advantage over most of the rest of the kind of the importing or gas-deficient regions.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, the other thing I think you necessarily have to look at when you talk about energy costs, you really got to kind of look at oil. And what we do know is with the low oil prices that we've seen, you've seen oil exploration drop off by major oil com
componenttext: Matthew, the other thing I think you necessarily have to look at when you talk about energy costs, you really got to kind of look at oil. And what we do know is with the low oil prices that we've seen, you've seen oil exploration drop off by major oil companies. They're not putting the kind of money into the deepwater and the Arctic and these more frontier regions that they used to be in terms of exploration development. In addition to that, we've also seen development activity in North America with respect to onshore oil production come off as well. So eventually, the problem solves itself. The stuff that's on continues to decline. The declines don't get replaced with new projects. And eventually, the oil market straightens out. The question is how far off are we from that happening? Today, it doesn't look like it's near, but certainly, at some point, the piper has to be paid, because if the investment hasn't gone into the exploration and development, eventually the supply dries up and the demand -- while the demand is growing.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dennis, appreciate that. Let me ask this then a follow-up. I actually cover a number of companies that are benefiting pretty substantially from political efforts that have resulted in trade restrictions. And I saw last month that commerce is moving ahead
componenttext: Dennis, appreciate that. Let me ask this then a follow-up. I actually cover a number of companies that are benefiting pretty substantially from political efforts that have resulted in trade restrictions. And I saw last month that commerce is moving ahead with its investigation on claimed ammonium sulfate dumping and/or unfair subsidies out of China. What's the potential for you in the domestic nitrogen industry, this may sound way out there, but to pursue more of these kinds of measures, particularly now that the threshold for "damage" at the hands of overseas product has been somewhat reduced and the nitrogen import requirement itself has reduced?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's something that we continue to investigate and look at. As you can appreciate, these cases are fairly complex and take a long time to get there. One of the issues of bringing a new damage claim is the demonstration of financial harm. And there's
componenttext: Yes, it's something that we continue to investigate and look at. As you can appreciate, these cases are fairly complex and take a long time to get there. One of the issues of bringing a new damage claim is the demonstration of financial harm. And there's a baseline threshold in terms of profitability. The challenge a little bit is even though pricing is down, margins are down, profitability is down, our gross margins for the first half of the year were still 35%; for the second quarter, over 45%. And the problem is at that level of profitability, the commerce department doesn't have a lot of time and interest in talking about the economic harm that we may have suffered. So something we continue to look at, we probe, but there's not a lot of, I would say, imminent movement likely to happen in that regard.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Sandy Klugman from Vertical Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Sandy Klugman from Vertical Research.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Slide 17 in the presentation doesn't explicitly call out India. I was hoping you could comment on how their push for greater self-sufficiency factors into your estimates. And then post-2016, I might have missed it, but do you have a forecast for Chinese u
componenttext: Slide 17 in the presentation doesn't explicitly call out India. I was hoping you could comment on how their push for greater self-sufficiency factors into your estimates. And then post-2016, I might have missed it, but do you have a forecast for Chinese urea exports?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Slide 17, I'm sorry...
componenttext: Slide 17, I'm sorry...

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, 13, where you show the capacity additions and closures. And maybe India's factored into the other component, but I was wondering if it does factor into the outlook.
componenttext: Sorry, 13, where you show the capacity additions and closures. And maybe India's factored into the other component, but I was wondering if it does factor into the outlook.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So India is -- does show up in other in both '15, '16 and I think into '17. But I think there's only 1 or 2 plants that we're talking about that are net new capacity that's coming online. So it's not a huge volume of production.
componenttext: Yes. So India is -- does show up in other in both '15, '16 and I think into '17. But I think there's only 1 or 2 plants that we're talking about that are net new capacity that's coming online. So it's not a huge volume of production.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look at India though, just for a quick comment, they are a huge market at over 30 million tons of consumption, with 21 million, 22 million of that produced and 8 million more or less imported. And when you look at the gas constraints, the energy co
componenttext: If you look at India though, just for a quick comment, they are a huge market at over 30 million tons of consumption, with 21 million, 22 million of that produced and 8 million more or less imported. And when you look at the gas constraints, the energy constraints, power constraints, you have a hard time looking at that as an opportunity to build urea plants when you can import that at below their production costs, and that energy is not being directed to the public's better use. There had been a lot of announcements on new capacity, but most years, there are announcements and most years those don't happen.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing is, in India in particular, because there are such heavy subsidies and price controls in place, the return profile that you're able to potentially get there is really subject to government control. And there's no -- there's no guarantees a
componenttext: The other thing is, in India in particular, because there are such heavy subsidies and price controls in place, the return profile that you're able to potentially get there is really subject to government control. And there's no -- there's no guarantees anywhere in a commodity market. It's tough enough even in a place like the U.S., but when you're operating in an environment where the end product may be subject to pricing controls where it limits the price that you're able to charge in the domestic market, it's really a difficult thing to get your mind around wanting to put new capital in the ground over there.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, and a new plant that was built 2 years ago, that still does not have gas supplied to it, and has not operated. That's a 1.2 million urea plant sitting idle. So I have a hard time with Tony, how can you invest when you don't even have gas for your cu
componenttext: Well, and a new plant that was built 2 years ago, that still does not have gas supplied to it, and has not operated. That's a 1.2 million urea plant sitting idle. So I have a hard time with Tony, how can you invest when you don't even have gas for your current plans?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And just a follow-up. Nitrogen advisory services are obviously a key component of precision ag platforms. How do you expect this impact the application rates? And do you expect it to lead to any changing grower preference betwee
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And just a follow-up. Nitrogen advisory services are obviously a key component of precision ag platforms. How do you expect this impact the application rates? And do you expect it to lead to any changing grower preference between different grades of nitrogen?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one of the things that we see, Sandy, is across a couple of different initiatives, one of which is the 4R nutrient stewardship programs that have been rolled out, which is to minimize the environmental impact or loss to the environment of nutrients; ke
componenttext: So one of the things that we see, Sandy, is across a couple of different initiatives, one of which is the 4R nutrient stewardship programs that have been rolled out, which is to minimize the environmental impact or loss to the environment of nutrients; keep the applied nutrients where they should be, in the field and available to the crop; changes around a little bit the sort of the application, intensity away from the fall and more of it into the spring and over the course of the spring, instead of just one big dump. But one of the benefits of the targeted precision ag is higher crop densities. And so if you're going to get the same kind of yield with higher density, you actually need to get an increase of nitrogen application per acre in order to accomplish anything at the grower level. So we do see those trends kind of moving in a direction that is, I would say, net-net positive for us over the long run. It might change the form a little bit or the timing of when that happens from the fall more into the spring, but that's one of the benefits that Bert talked about with our extensive flexible distribution network, that we're willing to inventory product and kind of take that risk off of the hands of the retailer and then capitalize on the opportunity when the application season does come. So for us, we look at all of those trends as being kind of a net positive for our business.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the Chinese export tariff. The Chinese producers appear to be lobbying the government to reduce it or get rid of it entirely. It seems to me that if they get rid of it, it's just going to lower the price anyway. But how important do you
componenttext: Just a question on the Chinese export tariff. The Chinese producers appear to be lobbying the government to reduce it or get rid of it entirely. It seems to me that if they get rid of it, it's just going to lower the price anyway. But how important do you think that decision is by the Chinese government at this point to sort of indicate their desire or willingness to support the industry or to kind of push it more towards the rationalization and environmental cleanup phase?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we see, again, from China, every year is a different year and every year is a different pronouncement or program coming out of China. If you look at the base model of China, we have unsustainable coal prices, unsustainable logistics, unsustainable is
componenttext: What we see, again, from China, every year is a different year and every year is a different pronouncement or program coming out of China. If you look at the base model of China, we have unsustainable coal prices, unsustainable logistics, unsustainable issues in terms of pollution and just areas surrounding what's being produced and exported. And so they are going to have to rationalize, and we see that taking place with 8 million tons coming off. And we expect additional rationalization, and if pricing remains at its current level, possibly permanent shutdowns. The export tariff is about $12 per ton. So if -- today, and this number has been moving, but Chinese urea is quoted in the $195 to $200 range FOB for granular. And so you cut that price down to, let's say, $185, you're still -- one, quality is poor or less -- it's not received as well as our products or some of the products coming out of the Arab Gulf. And so is that enough for them to compete? I don't think $12 is going to get them over the hump to allow them to compete on a consistent basis at the current market. So we expect to see -- they need to have rationalization. Their domestic industry cannot support the total capacity they have. So like Tony said, they're operating in the 60% to 65% operating rate and their exports are trending down. All those are trends that -- in the lowest-cost position that they will have with, again, coal being low, currency around CNY 6.65. And so the only thing probably going forward, I'd say, moderating is moderating up on all those issues. So you can get $12 on your export tariff, you're probably not going to lose that to raw material costs and freight costs over time.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in particular in that regard, the subsidy on electrical use in energy-intensive industries is going away, as is freight. And so, to Bert's point, we see a number of things that are offsetting to the higher-cost side internal to China that will either
componenttext: And in particular in that regard, the subsidy on electrical use in energy-intensive industries is going away, as is freight. And so, to Bert's point, we see a number of things that are offsetting to the higher-cost side internal to China that will either be a net increase in the cost structure in aggregate or at least offset any kind of reduction in the export tariff.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just as a follow-up. I saw last night a note that indicated that SABIC is trying to raise urea prices by about $20. Is that something that you're hearing? Do you think it has the ability to stick? I mean, clearly, that region has been a big impor
componenttext: And then just as a follow-up. I saw last night a note that indicated that SABIC is trying to raise urea prices by about $20. Is that something that you're hearing? Do you think it has the ability to stick? I mean, clearly, that region has been a big importer into the U.S. this year.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, SABIC does a good job. They move their products all around the world. They have contracts into the U.S. They have contracts into Thailand and Australia, and so they try to ratably move their product around the world. We're seeing -- I can't really co
componenttext: Yes, SABIC does a good job. They move their products all around the world. They have contracts into the U.S. They have contracts into Thailand and Australia, and so they try to ratably move their product around the world. We're seeing -- I can't really comment on them raising prices, other than that I think what you're seeing in NOLA, which is our market, at the low of $160, $165, we're now at $185 and probably even moving up from that. So prices are slowly moving up. I think that's in recognition of when you look at the UAN and urea comparison. Both those products are trading at a very good value. And actually moving forward with maybe another question, looking at how farmers should be looking at nutrients for fall applications and even spring applications, yes, corn is down at, let's say, $3.40 for a forward harvest position of corn. But ammonia has moderated equally down, and all the nutrients are down. So on a nutrient basis, it's still profitable to plant, and we see consumption to be fairly strong.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other issue on that one is we think that there is such a substantial portion of the global capacity that's operating at or below cash cost, that I think somewhere in the range that you're talking about is necessary just to keep supply available over t
componenttext: The other issue on that one is we think that there is such a substantial portion of the global capacity that's operating at or below cash cost, that I think somewhere in the range that you're talking about is necessary just to keep supply available over the medium term anyway. So I think that's kind of what has to happen over time.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your interest expense -- your book interest expense is running at about $140 million or so a year, ex nonrecurring items. Does that number go up to roughly $300 million next year when you can no longer capitalize your interest? I understand that doesn't c
componenttext: Your interest expense -- your book interest expense is running at about $140 million or so a year, ex nonrecurring items. Does that number go up to roughly $300 million next year when you can no longer capitalize your interest? I understand that doesn't change the cash interest that you pay, but does your book interest go up to about $300 million? And when you receive the $690 million tax refund, are your plans to repay debt with that?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, let's start with the first piece. The answer to that is yes. Once we've stopped capitalizing interest, Jeff, we'll be back around $300 million a year towards the expense. As you know, our interest payments, quarterly, run around $75 million,
componenttext: Yes. I mean, let's start with the first piece. The answer to that is yes. Once we've stopped capitalizing interest, Jeff, we'll be back around $300 million a year towards the expense. As you know, our interest payments, quarterly, run around $75 million, $76 million a quarter. So that won't change, just won't be capitalizing anymore and that will start to go to expense. With respect to the cash from the refi, I don't really sort of think of it that way because cash is all fungible. The cash will come in the door and it, along with the operating cash flow that we generate and other sources, obviously, will be used for a whole number of -- for obviously running the operation and a whole number of other things. But what I would do is just sort of repeat Tony's comment. We're going to build cash on our balance sheet, so we've got the flexibility to take out that $800 million in 2018 if we have to do that to defend our rating.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And for my follow-up. I think Ma'aden will bring on about 1 million tons of ammonia in the fourth quarter, with phosphate operations not really starting up maybe till midyear next year. Do you think that, that capacity will make a difference
componenttext: Okay, great. And for my follow-up. I think Ma'aden will bring on about 1 million tons of ammonia in the fourth quarter, with phosphate operations not really starting up maybe till midyear next year. Do you think that, that capacity will make a difference to the global ammonia market? Or do you think it doesn't make much of a difference?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the additions to ammonia that are coming on, not just SABIC's, but Dyno's plant in Waggeman, our own, yes, there's additional capacity coming on. Traditionally, the Arab Gulf ammonia tons stay in the East, and so supplying South Korea, Ja
componenttext: When you look at the additions to ammonia that are coming on, not just SABIC's, but Dyno's plant in Waggeman, our own, yes, there's additional capacity coming on. Traditionally, the Arab Gulf ammonia tons stay in the East, and so supplying South Korea, Japan and some of the caprolactam production there. And so they've done a good job of managing their production and supply. So any additional supply you have to watch and see how it goes. I can't give you a number on what the impact would be.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the benefits we have a little bit, Jeff, in that regard, which is the seaborne ammonia trade doesn't directly impact kind of our ag markets. Because unless you've got the in-market cryogenic storage, which really only the producers have, you otherw
componenttext: One of the benefits we have a little bit, Jeff, in that regard, which is the seaborne ammonia trade doesn't directly impact kind of our ag markets. Because unless you've got the in-market cryogenic storage, which really only the producers have, you otherwise can't move anhydrous ammonia from the Gulf or from Tampa up into the Corn Belt. And so while it affects some of our industrial-based contract business, it doesn't really affect our ag business that much.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Don Carson from Susquehanna.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Don Carson from Susquehanna.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ben Richardson [ph] sitting in for Don. I wanted to ask a question about the timing of your start-ups and how that might affect mix, both the Donaldsonville facility and the Port Neal facility?
componenttext: This is Ben Richardson [ph] sitting in for Don. I wanted to ask a question about the timing of your start-ups and how that might affect mix, both the Donaldsonville facility and the Port Neal facility?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the upgrades are running at Donaldsonville currently, and so when the ammonia plant starts up, that doesn't really affect the mix at all. All it does add additional new ammonia production to the network. And as you know, we have a pretty sizable supply
componenttext: So the upgrades are running at Donaldsonville currently, and so when the ammonia plant starts up, that doesn't really affect the mix at all. All it does add additional new ammonia production to the network. And as you know, we have a pretty sizable supply agreement in place with Mosaic that's going to start up at the beginning of next year. So a big piece of those tons are already spoken for beginning next year in terms of where they're going. Relative to Port Neal, we have the urea plant attached to the ammonia plant. We would expect to run the urea plant absolutely full out, with the excess being some incremental anhydrous that shows up in Port Neal. But generally speaking, we're going to want to run that urea plant flat out, and there isn't a lot of ability to move the mix in Port Neal. There's a couple hundred thousand tons that we can flex back and forth between urea and UAN, but generally speaking, the new plants are just going to come on and kind of run at capacity.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Adam Samuelson from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Adam Samuelson from Goldman Sachs.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe first a question for Dennis. I know you talked about preserving cash on the balance sheet to prepare for the 2018 maturity. Is there anything you could do to accelerate that? Or you got the cash basically sitting there at this point? I know there is
componenttext: Maybe first a question for Dennis. I know you talked about preserving cash on the balance sheet to prepare for the 2018 maturity. Is there anything you could do to accelerate that? Or you got the cash basically sitting there at this point? I know there is a call premium on the bonds, but other options on tenders or anything like that, that you could explore?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, when we look at the 2018 bonds, last time we looked at it, Adam, effectively, the make-whole provision on it or the premium that it's trading at in the market were roughly about the same. And I think our philosophy is: a, we don't need to do
componenttext: Yes. I mean, when we look at the 2018 bonds, last time we looked at it, Adam, effectively, the make-whole provision on it or the premium that it's trading at in the market were roughly about the same. And I think our philosophy is: a, we don't need to do that; and b, if I'm going to be paying somebody to use his money, then I'm going to use his money. So there really is -- there's not really a lot of economics in that and there really isn't the need to do it. I think it's just a matter of having the liquidity available at the time to repay it if we have to do that to defend our rating.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then on market, I was hoping you could talk a little bit about export out of the Gulf and how you're doing on driving some increased export opportunities. I would guess UAN is the bigger priority into South America, maybe size what that
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then on market, I was hoping you could talk a little bit about export out of the Gulf and how you're doing on driving some increased export opportunities. I would guess UAN is the bigger priority into South America, maybe size what that potential could be over the next 12, 18, 24 months.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we have been exploring the export opportunities for the company over the last several years in preparation for the additional capacity that's coming online, and the upgrading capacity already has come online. So this year, you've seen us export all 3 o
componenttext: So we have been exploring the export opportunities for the company over the last several years in preparation for the additional capacity that's coming online, and the upgrading capacity already has come online. So this year, you've seen us export all 3 of the major products: ammonia, urea and UAN. Smaller for ammonia and urea, and for UAN, we'll hit a record this year. And we're exploring all different kinds of markets. So we've been shipping product to Europe, to Argentina as well as opening new markets in Colombia, Chile and Brazil. And we're excited about the opportunities in South America because we do believe in the benefits of UAN and that's being received well, and so the growth is there. So I think you'll see us continue to grow those opportunities, but it is weighted against, obviously, netback options and what's best for the company. And so I think urea will grow as we bring the capacity online. If we have a differential again like we've had in -- for 6 months of this year, where the U.S. traded at discount to the international market, then we have a pretty good incentive to export the products out of the United States. So today, I would say, all going well, we'll be less than 1 million tons of total exports for the year out of Donaldsonville.
