componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2016 CF Industries Holdings Earnings Conference Call. My name is Cy, [ph] and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] .
I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today, Mr. Anthony Fusco, with CF Investor Relations. Sir, please proceed.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dave. [ph] Good morning, and thank you for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings, Inc. I'm Anthony Fusco with CF Investor Relations. Along with me today are Tony Will, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Dennis Ke
componenttext:
Thank you, Dave. [ph] Good morning, and thank you for joining us on this conference call for CF Industries Holdings, Inc. I'm Anthony Fusco with CF Investor Relations. Along with me today are Tony Will, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Dennis Kelleher, our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Bert Frost, our Senior Vice President of Sales, Market Development and Supply Chain; and Chris Bohn, our Senior Vice President of Manufacturing and Distribution.
CF Industries Holdings, Inc. reported its third quarter 2016 results yesterday afternoon, as did Terra Nitrogen Company, L.P. On this call, we'll review the CF Industries results in detail and discuss our outlook, referring to several slides that are posted on our website. At the end of the call, we'll host a question-and-answer session related to the company's financial results for the quarter. 
As you review the news releases posted on the Investor Relations section of our website at cfindustries.com and as you listen to this conference call, please recognize that they contain forward-looking statements as defined by federal securities laws. Actual results may differ materially from those projected as a result of certain risks and uncertainties, including those detailed on Slide 3 of the accompanying presentation and, from time to time, in the company's Securities and Exchange Commission filings. These forward-looking statements are made as of today, and the company assumes no obligation to update any forward-looking statements.
This conference call will include a discussion of certain non-GAAP financial measures. In each case, a presentation of the most directly comparable financial measure, calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP and coinciding reconciliation [ph] of the non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable financial measure, calculated and presented in accordance with GAAP, is provided in the earnings release and the slides for this webcast presentation on the company's website, www.cfindustries.com.
Now let me introduce Tony Will, our President and CEO.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we posted our financial results for the third quarter and the first 9 months of 2016, in which we generated adjusted EBITDA of $83 million and $725 million, respectively, after taking into account t
componenttext:
Thanks, Anthony, and good morning, everyone. Last night, we posted our financial results for the third quarter and the first 9 months of 2016, in which we generated adjusted EBITDA of $83 million and $725 million, respectively, after taking into account the items detailed in our earnings release. The third quarter typically has our lowest volumes and lowest realized prices of the year, and this year was no different. 
The nitrogen cost curve has widened and flattened, pressuring product prices, as a significant amount of new capacity has come online globally. As capacity was increasing, the cost to produce and move nitrogen into market was decreasing due to lower feedstock and ocean freight costs and currency devaluations in certain production regions. 
In addition to low product prices and already seasonally low volume, the situation was exacerbated by a change in buyer behavior. The North American value chain delayed purchasing products, given the reluctance to take inventory risk as the application season was still several months away, and additional new capacity, including our own, will soon be online. As such, the channel largely took a wait-and-see approach to the quarter.  The net result was sluggish demand in North America and nitrogen product prices that fell to multiyear lows and were often trading below international parity. Bert will discuss this in more detail, including the moves we made in response to these conditions. 
The business generated $83 million of adjusted EBITDA in the quarter despite the challenging market conditions. A welcome new development has been the strengthening market conditions of late. Both sales volume and product prices have increased since the end of the quarter as buyers are finally moving off the sidelines and beginning to prepare for the application season. 
On our last call, we detailed plans to deal with difficult market conditions that are expected to persist through next year. Our continuing focus is safe, reliable operations; reducing our costs and capital expenditures; and maintaining strong liquidity. At the end of the third quarter, we had over $1.5 billion in cash in [ph] an undrawn revolver. Additionally, we expect to receive roughly $800 million in cash via tax refund in the third quarter next year, which is almost $3.50 per share. So we have the strong liquidity position we desire.
We have also made great progress in reducing both SG&A and direct manufacturing costs. In addition to our efforts to reduce costs and conserve cash, we highlighted our focus to complete the major capacity expansion projects at Donaldsonville and Port Neal. At Donaldsonville, we have done just that. As we announced in October, the new ammonia plant is online and producing. With the new ammonia, urea and UAN plants all running at or above nameplate capacity, the expansion project at Donaldsonville has been officially completed. 
At Port Neal, we are in the process of starting up the plant. We had a successful test run of the urea granulation plant in September, and gas and steam have been introduced into the ammonia plant, and we're proceeding with the urea plant start-up in parallel.  As a result, we expect both ammonia and urea production at Port Neal to begin soon. 
To help make this happen, we have brought a seasoned team from Donaldsonville up to assist the Port Neal final commissioning and start-up of the plants, allowing us to leverage what we've learned from our experiences. With the completion of Donaldsonville and with Port Neal starting up, now is a good time to take a step back and assess the good and bad of the capacity expansion projects. 
I want to start by referring to Slide 11 of the materials posted to our website. The total capital cost to build the new plants at Donaldsonville and Port Neal was $5.2 billion. Those plants are expected to produce roughly 4 million product tons per year. However, CHS paid $2.8 billion and have the rights to 1.7 million tons of that production. So that leaves $2.4 billion of capital and roughly 2.3 million product tons for CF's account. Therefore, our resulting net capital cost was roughly $1,050 per product ton of new capacity. 
As Page 13 suggests, while our costs have greatly exceeded our initial estimate and we're certainly not happy about that, it is an all too common occurrence in the industry as every major North American project we could find reliable data on has similarly experienced significant cost overruns as well. What is ultimately important, though, is the capital cost per ton of new production capacity. 
As shown on Page 13, our new plants at Donaldsonville and Port Neal have an effective capital cost per ton of production that is among the lowest of all the observable plants built recently in North America. And what is really important, as detailed on Page 14, is that the effective IRR for the projects remains significantly above our cost of capital despite the increased costs and lower product price environment. The net result of all of this is that we remain pretty happy with our decision to do these capacity expansion projects and the fact that we sold an equity interest to CHS. 
Now let me turn the call over to Bert who will talk more about the market and our outlook in more detail, and then Dennis will discuss our performance and our work on reshaping part of our debt capital structure, after which I will offer some closing remarks. Bert?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. The [ph] supply-driven market, the seasonal low demand period for fertilizer and changing buyer behavior pushed ammonia, urea and UAN prices lower throughout the third quarter, hitting multiyear lows for each of the products. In fact, nitrog
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. The [ph] supply-driven market, the seasonal low demand period for fertilizer and changing buyer behavior pushed ammonia, urea and UAN prices lower throughout the third quarter, hitting multiyear lows for each of the products. In fact, nitrogen prices of the U.S. Gulf remain below international parity for most of the third quarter, as Tony mentioned. Even as of late last week, lowly [ph] urea is trading at approximately $10 per short ton below the rest of the world. 
The global oversupply of nitrogen and its pressure on prices is not a new story. As we have said before, we believe 2016 represents the high watermark for urea capacity additions globally, with capacity additions projected to  drop off sharply after mid-2017. As an industry, we have yet to see the full impact of the new North American production capacity, but that which has come online has begun to displace imports.
The low global prices have challenged the ability of high-cost producers to operate. The marginal producer, which remains [ph] Chinese anthracite coal plants, have also seen production and transportation costs rise. Rail and trucking costs in China have increased, and electricity  subsidies for smaller urea producers were eliminated in April. Additionally, coal prices have increased due to government-imposed mining restrictions. 
Anthracite lump coal prices in China have been flat for most of the third quarter, but recent published reports suggest that prices have increased 20% to 30%. This has translated to additional plants in China shutting down and fewer Chinese product being offered in the international marketplace via exports. Through the end of the quarter, approximately 8 million metric tons of annual urea capacity has been shut down in China, and we anticipate that number to continue to increase. 
This fundamental economic pressure is affecting pricing. The Chinese port price per metric ton for urea had risen to about $220 as we entered November, up from $194 per metric ton at the end of September. Also, the average U.S. Gulf price for urea barge product was approximately $180 [ph] per short ton for the third quarter, and today, it is $30 to $40 higher.  We anticipate that prices in the coming quarters will also be supported by stronger demand. 
During the low price environment of the third quarter, customers took a new approach to purchases. While the third quarter typically has the lowest prices and lowest volumes in North America, demand was pressured more than normal. The trend of lower prices over the last 18 months has increased inventory risk in the mind of the purchaser. Over the last 10 years, customers have purchased forward, received the product out of season as inventory and then delivered the product to their customers for [ph] either fall or spring applications. 
Today, this is much less the case. Many domestic customers told us they did not want to purchase product in the third quarter, preferring instead to take a wait-and-see approach to understand how the market will develop, particularly with new capacity expected to come online in North America. This approach was a deviation from historical purchasing patterns, but we responded to this environment in a few specific ways. 
First, we delayed the launch of our UAN fill program, and we capitalized on our flexibility export [ph] from Donaldsonville, particularly for UAN. Our sales team has put in a great deal of work in recent years to open up new markets for our product, and that effort is benefiting the company now. In the third quarter, we exported a record amount of UAN for the first 9 months of the year.  The UAN exports have increased 143% over the same period last year and have risen from under 100,000 tons in 2012 to more than 700,000 tons year-to-date in 2016 .
We have also increased shipments of UAN to the East and Gulf Coasts by way of a new vessel commissioned earlier this year, allowing CF to compete with imports. In the past, we have not participated in these regions in a significant way as farmers in the Cornbelt  consumed the vast majority of our UAN, and cost-effective grade options were limited. 
We also have a significant amount of in-market storage for our products, with over 1.2 million tons of ammonia storage, 1.3 million tons of UAN and over 500,000 tons of urea storage across our network. Even if buyers stop [ph] for a while on the sideline, historically, we have been able to fully operate our plants and position product for when demand materializes. 
As I've said many times, nitrogen is a necessary nutrient. It has to be applied every year. Additionally, despite the record or near-record corn and soybean crops expected this year, 2017 futures prices suggest continued profitability at the farm level for corn and soybeans. We are forecasting 88 million acres of corn and for wheat to acres [ph] to remain flat at 50 million acres. Assuming that the weather cooperates, when demand for fall application season begins, we expect to be strong. 
At the same time, we believe that North American downstream inventory of ammonia, urea and UAN is low following the spring application season. Urea imports were down 55% year-over-year in the third quarter as well, suggesting that purchasing activity will have to accelerate to be ready for spring. With buyers holding off purchases, we expect there to be robust, just-in-time demand during the application season, which, as I've outlined, we believe we are uniquely positioned to provide. 
We've also seen tremendous progress in our U.K. operations. Since CF purchased the plants at Ince and Billingham, the manufacturing teams have set a number of production records. The team there also delivered a record amount of fertilizer to U.K. farmers in July as their season began, and they continue to move all of their product. We've also benefited from a continued decline in U.K. natural gas prices, which had an average price in the third quarter of 2016 at [ph] $4.08 per MMBtu compared to $6.44 per MMBtu in the same quarter of 2015.
For the North American natural gas market, the December NYMEX contracts started the quarter near $3.36 per MMBtu and is currently trading at around $2.79 per MMBtu. During the third quarter of 2016, we did not enter into any additional natural gas hedges, and we remain confident in the long-term outlook for low-cost North American natural gas. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Dennis.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bert. In the third quarter of 2016, the company reported an EBITDA loss of $6 million and a net loss per diluted share of $0.13. Included in these results on a pretax basis were approximately $21 million in unrealized net mark-to-market losses on
componenttext:
Thanks, Bert. In the third quarter of 2016, the company reported an EBITDA loss of $6 million and a net loss per diluted share of $0.13. Included in these results on a pretax basis were approximately $21 million in unrealized net mark-to-market losses on our natural gas derivatives; a $22 million unrealized mark-to-market loss on an embedded derivative associated with the CHF strategic venture; $24 million of expansion costs for our Donaldsonville and Port Neal facilities; $18 million of stand-up costs for the Donaldsonville ammonia plant; $3 million of net foreign currency losses related to intercompany loans; and $2 million of fees associated with the amendment of the private placement notes, partially offset by a $1 million gain on foreign currency derivatives. When [ph] taking these items into account, our adjusted EBITDA for the third quarter was $83 million, and our adjusted net earnings per diluted share was $0.13. 
Included in these results is a realized loss of $11 million or $0.17 per MMBtu on our natural gas hedges for the third quarter of 2016. Our gross margin per ton of urea and UAN was affected by the commencement of depreciation of our capacity additions at Donaldsonville, which increased depreciation expense in the quarter by $19 million. Including this amount, total depreciation for the quarter amounted to about $83 million for the 2 segments and about $30 per ton and $43 per ton for urea and UAN, respectively. As we bring up the remaining plants, our depreciation will again increase. 
In 2017, we expect to receive a refund of approximately $800 million related to the carryback of certain U.S. tax losses from the current year to prior [ph] years, primarily related to the bonus depreciation provision in the PATH Act. The amount of this refund is dependent in part on the timing of the completion of the expansion project at Port Neal. 
The company now projects a 2016 pretax loss, excluding noncontrolling interest. As a result, we recorded an income tax benefit of $131 million on a pretax loss of $131 million. The amount recognized represents the reversal of tax provisions that we recorded in prior periods this year.
Interest expense for the third quarter was $31 million, with another $53 million of interest being capitalized in the quarter. As the capacity expansions are completed, interest capitalization will decrease dramatically, increasing reported interest expense on the income statement.
As you know, CHS is entitled to semiannual distributions resulting from its minority equity investment in CF Industries Nitrogen, LLC. The estimate of the partnership distribution earned by CHS but not yet declared for the third quarter of 2016 is approximately $22 million. 
For the full year, the company expects to have total capital expenditures of approximately $2.3 billion, of which approximately $1.8 billion will be for the capacity expansion projects, and $450 million to $475 million will be for sustaining, improvement and other projects. The total completed capital cost of all capacity expansion projects, both at Donaldsonville and Port Neal, is estimated to be approximately $5.2 billion.
For 2017, we continue to expect capital expenditures to be in the range of $400 million to $450 million, returning CapEx to maintenance levels that continue our commitment to safe, compliant and reliable operations.
Let's turn now to our liquidity profile and capital structure. As we indicated in the release, due to the uncertain duration of the current low price environment, our company is taking steps to maintain strong liquidity and has made -- and is making certain changes to part of the debt capital structure to put in place financing more appropriate for the current business and operating environment. As of September 30, 2016, the company had a balance of cash and cash equivalents of nearly $1.6 billion in and [ph] undrawn revolver and was in compliance with all applicable covenant requirements on all debt instruments. 
In addition to maintaining strong liquidity, our intention is to put in place a capital structure for the business we are as opposed to the business we thought we would be a year ago. We recently obtained required lender consent for an amendment of our revolving credit facility, subject to the satisfaction of specified conditions that would, among other things, change and add natural [ph] covenants, reduce the facility size from $1.5 billion to $750 million and add security interest to provide credit enhancement to the lenders. We believe this security enhancement gave the lenders confidence to give us the appropriate flexibility to continue paying our dividend.
We expect to assume [ph] the prepayment of the senior notes due 2022, 2025 and 2027 and the related make-whole amount with the issuance of new long-term secured debt, borrowings under the company's revolving credit facility, cash on hand or a combination of any of the foregoing.
As many of you recall, we issued the private placement notes when we were in the middle of the proposed combination with certain businesses of OCI. Because of that, we were unable to issue traditional registered investment-grade debt. Instead, we opted to issue private placement notes with longer maturities that were spread out over time to meet our capital needs. However, the private placement covenant package is not appropriate for a stand-alone CF in the current operating environment. The intent of prepaying the private placement notes is to replace them with financing that has a long-term covenant structure more consistent with traditional debt capital for a cyclical industry. 
Before I hand the call back to Tony,  I would like to end by discussing our capital allocation philosophy, which has not changed. While the current pricing environment has impacted our ratings in the near term, we remain committed to investment grade over the long term. We will continue our proven approach to managing the balance sheet in order to be in a position to retire $800 million of debt coming due in 2018 and again in 2020. If you look at our Slide 19, what you will see is that we have returned to shareholders more than twice as much as we have net [ph] invested in large projects and assets. 
Looking at Slide 20, you can see that since 2010, our approach has resulted in our shareholders having greatly increased exposure to our underlying business as measured by nitrogen nutrient tons per 1,000 shares. 
With that, Tony will provide some closing remarks before we open the call to Q&A.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dennis. As we have tried to lay out in our slides on Pages 22 through 26, we believe that CF is exceptionally well positioned to benefit from recovery in the nitrogen sector. Although there is currently oversupply in the industry, global nitrogen
componenttext:
Thanks, Dennis. As we have tried to lay out in our slides on Pages 22 through 26, we believe that CF is exceptionally well positioned to benefit from recovery in the nitrogen sector. Although there is currently oversupply in the industry, global nitrogen demand is expected to continue to grow at roughly 2% per year. There is a lack of new plants scheduled to come online post-2017, and a result, the global supply-demand balance should tighten, leading to an increase in product prices.  As this price recovery begins in 2018 and continues thereafter, CF should benefit disproportionately.
As Page 26 indicates, a $25 per ton urea equivalent increase translates roughly to $350 million of additional EBITDA on an annual basis. Bert indicated that average published Q3 urea prices at NOLA was $180 per ton. However, prices are already $30 to $40 higher than that today.  With our new plants starting up and improving market conditions, we are very excited about the future. 
With that, operator, we'll open the call to questions.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Chris Parkinson with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Chris Parkinson with Crédit Suisse.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you mentioned, you've seen a nice [ph] movement in urea prices. I don't [ph] know what's going on in China, but globally, UAN and ammonia hasn't really moved that much despite higher feedstock costs and some curtailments in Eastern Europe and even some
componenttext: As you mentioned, you've seen a nice [ph] movement in urea prices. I don't [ph] know what's going on in China, but globally, UAN and ammonia hasn't really moved that much despite higher feedstock costs and some curtailments in Eastern Europe and even some extended maintenance in the Middle East. Do you just simply believe it's a matter of time before prices rebound? Or is demand still really that sluggish? So any color on UAN and ammonia would be greatly appreciated.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we are seeing -- this is Bert. We're seeing UAN prices already move. Egypt just closed a tender this week, and that was closed at $140 per metric ton. And that's up from the $125 level from the previous tender. We're seeing that prices increase in Euro
componenttext: So we are seeing -- this is Bert. We're seeing UAN prices already move. Egypt just closed a tender this week, and that was closed at $140 per metric ton. And that's up from the $125 level from the previous tender. We're seeing that prices increase in Europe, in France as well as other locations and in the United States. So we've seen the activity step up in North America over the last several weeks, and pricing correspondingly is increasing. Ammonia, we have not seen the big move yet for fall applications in North America, but we have pretty positive weather pattern in front of us. And we expect that to go fairly soon. Around the world, I think with the -- or ammonia specifically, with the additions in Asia, the SABIC plant [ph] and some of the new [ph] capacity that's come online, that did pressure pricing in Q3, but we expect moderating prices on the upside as we roll into 2017.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And just a little more comment -- or another question on ammonia, I suppose. Just can you comment on just what degree or what effect the competitor ammonia supply coming online during 3Q in the U.S. you believe affected your netbacks? And how do
componenttext: Perfect. And just a little more comment -- or another question on ammonia, I suppose. Just can you comment on just what degree or what effect the competitor ammonia supply coming online during 3Q in the U.S. you believe affected your netbacks? And how do you think this is going to evolve over the next year or 2, especially in the context of what we're still seeing from Trinidad?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] So I think the ammonia situation for us, it is just a lower quarter on demand. So you [ph] really don't have ag demand during  Q3, so it's an industrial-focused quarter. And with  Tampa pricing at a low level, with contracts either based on temper or
componenttext: [ph] So I think the ammonia situation for us, it is just a lower quarter on demand. So you [ph] really don't have ag demand during  Q3, so it's an industrial-focused quarter. And with  Tampa pricing at a low level, with contracts either based on temper or [ph] on gas, that drives a lower price for the product. And so for our specific price realization and demand, we do expect that obviously, we're [ph] going to see an improvement in Q4 with ag and then rolling into next year. Over the next year or 2, you're right, there is additional capacity coming online. We expect most of that North American capacity to be converted into upgraded products. And you have 2 new plants coming online that are probably net losses for ammonia. And the current capacity that's come online [ph] the Gulf outside the CF's is pretty much committed to Dyno and Cornerstone and some other movements. So we feel fairly good about the ammonia market as well as our ability to move and continue to participate through our terminal and distribution system in the ag as well as industrial market.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Piken from Cleveland Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Piken from Cleveland Research.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Was wondering if you could talk a little bit about some of the impact that the higher rail rates have had on your operations, and specifically, when some of the new capacity comes on, what type of savings might be available and if the rail companies
componenttext: Yes. Was wondering if you could talk a little bit about some of the impact that the higher rail rates have had on your operations, and specifically, when some of the new capacity comes on, what type of savings might be available and if the rail companies are willing to renegotiate some of those rates.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [ph] So we're constantly looking at all of our  costs. As Tony has mentioned, whether that be SG&A, production, CapEx, I think that in this type of an environment, we're driven to do that. And, obviously, logistics is one of those areas. And our logistics
componenttext: [ph] So we're constantly looking at all of our  costs. As Tony has mentioned, whether that be SG&A, production, CapEx, I think that in this type of an environment, we're driven to do that. And, obviously, logistics is one of those areas. And our logistics team has done a great job in terms of leveraging the various platforms that we have. And what we have done, I'll tell you, the rail rates have gone up, and there's been an impact on UAN. And we have met with the railroads, and we continue to do, whether it's spot situations or looking at the complex as a whole. One of the things we did last year was we opened up Stolthaven, which allowed us to get on the NS [ph] and bypass some of the blocked activity we believe we're experiencing in Donaldsonville. We've also leveraged and moved up our barge participation on UAN, increasing the level. And then like I mentioned earlier, the exports. And so we're able to achieve a fairly attractive netback, moving our product to all over the globe but principally to Argentina, Uruguay, Europe and some new markets we're developing. And we've been -- we've moved to France for less than $15, $14 a ton. We can't move to St. Louis for that on UAN. And so as you see us develop and grow and mature, we're going to continue to leverage those options and to benefit us. There's [ph] other opportunities for what we're doing, we've met with the railroads on shipping out of Port Neal. We have UPNVN [ph] servicing that plant, but we've built that facility to fully load that product up by truck. And so you have to take defensive measures during these times to be able to position yourselves to pull in the attractive pricing for rail and other logistical options. And that's what we're doing.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then could you give any sort of quantification in terms of like how much money it might save you once the urea is fully up and running in Port Neal in terms of trucking it out of Port Neal to other locations in the Midwest versus what you're cu
componenttext: Great. And then could you give any sort of quantification in terms of like how much money it might save you once the urea is fully up and running in Port Neal in terms of trucking it out of Port Neal to other locations in the Midwest versus what you're currently paying [ph] out of D'Ville?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it depends on where you go. I mean, obviously, D'Ville is going to be -- it's a huge plant, and we have a lot of urea coming out of there.  But most of it moves by barge, and now we have the ability to move that up by vessel. Some of it will move by
componenttext: Well, it depends on where you go. I mean, obviously, D'Ville is going to be -- it's a huge plant, and we have a lot of urea coming out of there.  But most of it moves by barge, and now we have the ability to move that up by vessel. Some of it will move by rail, but the product that we have been moving by rail into Iowa, Nebraska, the Dakotas, all of that will come out of Port Neal, and that will all be very competitively positioned. And we can load the trucks with the pop, [ph] so you can average more tons and lower your freight cost. And we think that will reach 500 to 700 miles by truck outside of the plant. And so then it's going to have to be, [ph] do the railroads want to compete with that? And we've already worked with our customers to be able to receive these products. So we believe that we have linked the system together to effectively serve and move our product at all times at the lowest cost possible.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Andrews from Morgan Stanley.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could just put a little more context to -- or frame around how soon, soon might be at Port Neal. And maybe what I'm trying to get at is just sort of, the market dynamics seem to be a bit influx [ph] over how much incremental imports are g
componenttext: Wondering if you could just put a little more context to -- or frame around how soon, soon might be at Port Neal. And maybe what I'm trying to get at is just sort of, the market dynamics seem to be a bit influx [ph] over how much incremental imports are going to be needed this year going into spring as a function of when new facilities start up. So just curious if you  -- what soon means and how it fits into your marketing strategy with the balance of your product.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we -- as I said earlier in September, we tested the granulation part of [ph] the urea plants. We have been stockpiling ammonia into the tanks. And anyone who is in the Port Neal area has seen the flare stack with that, [ph] so we've got gas and st
componenttext: Yes. So we -- as I said earlier in September, we tested the granulation part of [ph] the urea plants. We have been stockpiling ammonia into the tanks. And anyone who is in the Port Neal area has seen the flare stack with that, [ph] so we've got gas and steam going into the reformer front end. And as we work kind of from the reformer through the CO2 removal system, we're going to start sending CO2 over to the urea plants and then be able to coal [ph] ammonia out of the tanks. And so that's what we're planning in terms of the parallel [ph] commissioning. So it's very likely that urea will actually be online before the ammonia plant is fully up. It's a simpler plant to commission, and granulations are already operational. But our expectation is it's a matter of a couple of weeks, maybe 3 or 4, depends upon the number of little issues that you find as you go through it. But that was fairly consistent with our experience at Donaldsonville. And hopefully, we'll be able to improve on that because of the great team we've got from D'Ville to top [ph] helping the Port Neal guys. So I would say our expectation is urea, hopefully here by the end of this month and ammonia, plus or minus a week after.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just as a follow-up, Bert, you talked a little bit about sort of changing customer buying patterns. Sounds a little bit similar to me as what's happened in some of the other nutrients. So just curious, [ph] your view on total amount of storage capac
componenttext: Okay. Just as a follow-up, Bert, you talked a little bit about sort of changing customer buying patterns. Sounds a little bit similar to me as what's happened in some of the other nutrients. So just curious, [ph] your view on total amount of storage capacity you  have and whether you want to be or need to be more opportunistic with storage capacity. And also, you mentioned the 1 million tons of UAN in the vessels. How we should think about sort of the incremental ability going forward to use vessels both for urea and UAN to be more flexible around changes in customer buyer -- buying patterns.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when you look at our system, as I mentioned, we do have the flexibility first on production. So we can produce ammonia, urea, UAN and some of the other products. We'll continue to do that and leverage those options up and down as the market necess
componenttext: Yes. So when you look at our system, as I mentioned, we do have the flexibility first on production. So we can produce ammonia, urea, UAN and some of the other products. We'll continue to do that and leverage those options up and down as the market necessitates. Then you go into loading options, and so -- where we have pipe, barge, truck, rail, vessel. Then you go next to terminal opportunities and where those terminals are. We have taken on some additional terminaling space, which we believe is in our long-term interest, in markets that we have not necessarily participated as much in the past, and we can effectively serve now with our logistical options. But you're right, exports are a great opportunity because you can immediately put 40,000 tons out and load it in a day. And so that's a great leverage point when you're looking at inventory at the plant and how you're moving it out incrementally into the interior. Buying patterns have changed, and we anticipate that they'll probably be this way for another year or so. But at the end of the day, you do have to have your product in place to serve the farmer customer. You can only move so many rail cars per day, and railcars can only make so many trip and then to return empty and load out and get in line. And so we believe that window closes and everyday is another loss shipment day that will challenge the delivery system. And this is more of a UAN story than it is for urea because I think you can move that up by barge up to the various terminals.  So we're fairly positive looking forward into 2017. We're -- if you really look at it, it protects us in Oklahoma. That will start applications in February Midwest, March and then April. So you're not much more than 4, 5 months away from applications. We're just starting winter and we're already looking into spring. So where -- we think it's going to turn out pretty well for us.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steve from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steve from Bank of America.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bert, you mentioned you're looking at the opportunity to ship out of diesel UAN to both East and West Coast. I'm just curious about that. Does that reflect your view that post the start-up of OCIs Weaver in your Port Neal plants that UAN in the corn belt
componenttext: Bert, you mentioned you're looking at the opportunity to ship out of diesel UAN to both East and West Coast. I'm just curious about that. Does that reflect your view that post the start-up of OCIs Weaver in your Port Neal plants that UAN in the corn belt will become net balance on UAN and you need to find new homes for the UAN out of diesel?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wouldn't infer too much in that because what we're doing is just creating optionality for the company. And I would rather have 10 options to take 1 ton than have 1 option to take ten tons. And so we would rather create these options whether they be
componenttext: Yes. I wouldn't infer too much in that because what we're doing is just creating optionality for the company. And I would rather have 10 options to take 1 ton than have 1 option to take ten tons. And so we would rather create these options whether they be exports of the coast, and we have looked at the Coast throughout the years and participated in various manners. But today, when you look at East Coast, that's a million ton market that we probably had 50,000 to 100,000 tons 5 or 6 years ago, and I think that presents a tremendous opportunity for us. That's why we're getting on DNS, looking on to get on the CSX, utilizing port right on the CN. The West Coast, we've got some good agreements and partnerships out there with some of the distributors. We're able to rail directly from Woodford on the BN, from balances on the port on the UP, and we've been moving product by vessel through the Panama Canal to the West Coast, and that's an attractive opportunity for us. But I wouldn't -- yes, new products and new production is coming online in various parts of the country, and we're going to continue to participate in those areas. We are sales or adding capacity right at the heart of the corn belt, and we're just preparing.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, the other thing to kind of remember is, as we indicated, I think on some of our materials, the nitro gas at UAN at Donaldsonville is, have the largest single train that's out there at 4,500 metric ton a day, which is about a nameplate of about 5,00
componenttext: Steve, the other thing to kind of remember is, as we indicated, I think on some of our materials, the nitro gas at UAN at Donaldsonville is, have the largest single train that's out there at 4,500 metric ton a day, which is about a nameplate of about 5,000 short tons a day. And that plant is running over 20% above nameplate. We've done several days here just even this week at over 6,000 a day. So first, we've got a big job in terms of finding a home for all of that product, given how well those plants are running. And as it points out, what we're trying to do is just try to get the best aggregate net back across the entire ecosystem.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a follow up than that, Tony. Given diesel's effective capacity is going to be greater than nameplate, what would you say longer term is the fraction of production of that plant that will likely be exported?
componenttext: And just a follow up than that, Tony. Given diesel's effective capacity is going to be greater than nameplate, what would you say longer term is the fraction of production of that plant that will likely be exported?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's going to really vary based on market conditions. The trade patterns are evolving and started to adjust where the new capacity comes out. We certainly have an ability to export as much as 3 million, 4 million tons a year, but that wouldn't probably
componenttext: That's going to really vary based on market conditions. The trade patterns are evolving and started to adjust where the new capacity comes out. We certainly have an ability to export as much as 3 million, 4 million tons a year, but that wouldn't probably be our first choice, all of the things considered. The point though that I'd like to highlight just to remind everybody of, and we've got a slide to this effect in the appendix. But even after all of the new capacity that's inflight the North America comes online, North America is still going to be a very important-dependent region where there's about 30% of our total nitrogen demand has got to be met by imports. So when we're exporting here and there, it really is just around the edges and primarily during periods of time when there isn't a lot going to ground in North America and there's demand in other regions. So it's a way to maximize overall system net backs, not a have to do kind of thing.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joel Jackson from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joel Jackson from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to talk about the $1 billion of maturities that you're taking out in 2020. I mean, maybe you could elaborate a little bit more. I guess you had some pressure on the lenders on that with the covenants. I think some of that is related to the. Ca
componenttext: I just want to talk about the $1 billion of maturities that you're taking out in 2020. I mean, maybe you could elaborate a little bit more. I guess you had some pressure on the lenders on that with the covenants. I think some of that is related to the. Can you just talk about some of the decisions around and how soon you'll be repaying then?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Joel. This is Dennis. I think you're right, and said that our prepared remarks. Basically, those things were taken out in September as part of finance in the deal. At that time we did that, we weren't in a position to issue registered debt or even 1
componenttext: Sure, Joel. This is Dennis. I think you're right, and said that our prepared remarks. Basically, those things were taken out in September as part of finance in the deal. At that time we did that, we weren't in a position to issue registered debt or even 1 44 a debt because we wouldn't have had the requisite financial information we needed to issue that. So what we did is we looked at the couple of options. We looked at potentially taking out 3 [ph] 5-year term loan to provide the financing. And the reason we rejected that option was because effectively if you look at the post closing of the OCI deal, there wouldn't have been, had we done that, around $4 billion worth of maturities occurring this between sort of 2016 and 2021, and that was a concentration of maturities that really wasn't was a bit high risk to us. So we didn't set, as we went to the private placement market where we could basically throw a lot of those maturities further out to 2025 and also to 2027 so that we would have a more laddered effect. Now with the business that we intended to have coming out of that deal, which would have included 3 new operated plants and through time significantly less debt and also the operating environment that we foresaw at that time, the covenants instruction in the private placement notes is not perceived to be problematic. But a couple of things happened since that point in time. A, we didn't do the CHS. We didn't do the OCI deal, so we never got the 3 additional operating plants. In addition to that, and certainly with respect to third quarter, things turned out a bit more adverse than we had anticipated. And so with that highlighted to us, what the need to make surer that with respect to our long-dated capital, that the long-dated capital that we had in place to finance the business should be long-dated in capital that is consistent with the business to the cyclical and goes through ups and downs and is robust to that from a covenant perspective. And the reason that, that's important to us is because having a more appropriate set of covenants gives us the flexibility, as I said, with respect to the revolving credit facility to continue to pay the dividend and do other things on the equity side that would be more difficult otherwise. And so -- but the actions that we're taking here are really around reducing the risk and uncertainty around that sort of stuff and putting our capital structure I na framework that's far more appropriate to the type of business that we are today in the environment we're in.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That was helpful. And the second question I'll ask is on the ammonia contracts with Mosaic starting at January 1 and Mosaic obviously disclosed, I guess, last week or is this week? Sorry. In fact, the barge is late, so they will be taking products f
componenttext: Okay. That was helpful. Can you talk about we beginning to see during this interim period for the barge, we're beginning the same net backs in the minimum volume, any payment changes? Maybe talk about anything going on in the interim?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Joel. We have been in, as you would imagine, very close communication with the guys at Mosaic. So they've been keeping us abreast of what's going on from a delivery schedule perspective on the vessel. And burden is kind of part of working well at coming up with different ways to manage that situation, whether it's given ammonia via 5% [ph] or some pop through the terminals doing some time, products swaps and other things like that. So we're on top of it and kind of managing it jointly with the Mosaic guys and don't foresee that as any kind of real issue.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Adam Samuelson from Goldman Sachs.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe one first, I want to go back to, I think, it was Vincent's question about Port Neal. As one question around the impact on the tax refund next year. Can you just talk about what actually has to occur by year-end to ensure the receipt of that cash tax
componenttext: Maybe one first, I want to go back to, I think, it was Vincent's question about Port Neal. As one question around the impact on the tax refund next year. Can you just talk about what actually has to occur by year-end to ensure the receipt of that cash tax refund next year? And if the plant similarly is not fully operational by December 31, to how that will impact the timing and scope of the tax refund??

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Adam, the plant has got to be basically put in service and operational, and we're first to be able to depreciate it. So the -- we need the plant to be running now. That said, as I talked about, it's not an all-or-nothing kind of thing. We've already
componenttext: Yes. Adam, the plant has got to be basically put in service and operational, and we're first to be able to depreciate it. So the -- we need the plant to be running now. That said, as I talked about, it's not an all-or-nothing kind of thing. We've already tested the granulation plant of the urea. We're ready to put CO2 into the urea melt plant, the synthesis plant and kind of get that up and running. The off sites have all been sort of tested and are operational. And once we've got CO2 going over to the urea plant and the front end of the urea plant is operational, so, again, this isn't an all-or-nothing kind of thing. We're putting sections of the plant in operation as we go. But again, our expectation here is based on our experience at Donaldsonville, the urea plants are sister plants from one another, and the one at D'Ville started up within a week. So we think we have plenty of time to get it up and operational. The Port Neal ammonia plant is a lot less complex than the Port Neal plant is -- or Port Neal's less complex than D'Ville because Port Neal is a 2,200-ton a day plant where D'Ville is a 3,300 and configuration of the thin loop in Donaldsonville is much more complex. There's a whole another section to it. So as we look at this, we feel very comfortable in terms of being able to get the plant online here by the end of the year, and that's why we continue to say $800 million in terms of the tax refund next year because we expect to get everything online.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Dennis. I just want to clarify something I heard in your question. The timing of the receipt of the refund doesn't have anything to do with what happened in Port Neal. The timing of the refund has to do it when you get your tax return and when tha
componenttext: This is Dennis. I just want to clarify something I heard in your question. The timing of the receipt of the refund doesn't have anything to do with what happened in Port Neal. The timing of the refund has to do it when you get your tax return and when that gets processed through. And given that, we anticipate today -- or what we see today, we anticipate that, that will be a third quarter event next year, that is the refund. As Tony described to you, the Port Neal piece has to do with the amount because it's what drives ultimately for a portion of our depreciation, whether you have depreciation in your tax loss for '16 that you carry back to whether you don't and how much. And like Tony said, it's not an all-or-nothing type thing. It's a sort of a continuing kind of a strong expectations remains that to be fully depreciate in those assets this year.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just a follow-up on Slide 26 of your deck that has the EBITDA sensitivity to gas urea prices. I just wanted to be clear, that -- the urea prices if you laid them out, those are CF realized urea prices, not have a NOLA benchmark? A
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just a follow-up on Slide 26 of your deck that has the EBITDA sensitivity to gas urea prices. I just wanted to be clear, that -- the urea prices if you laid them out, those are CF realized urea prices, not have a NOLA benchmark? And as I think about the current environment, maybe environment in the next 6 to 12 months where you're finding the value of ammonia and UAN on an n [ph] ton basis is spread a little bit different than they've been historically, and I presume how you would envision them prospectively. Your results over the next, call it, 2017 wouldn't necessarily mirror the table, given the differences in spreads on product prices.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as you pointed out, this is based on kind of a pro forma simulation of various spreads that existed for our last full year, which was 2015. And if there are differences going forward, that's going to change. It is the vertical access are real
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as you pointed out, this is based on kind of a pro forma simulation of various spreads that existed for our last full year, which was 2015. And if there are differences going forward, that's going to change. It is the vertical access are realized price, but I think the -- in the third quarter, the published average NOLA price was 1 80 and our realized price was a little over $200. And so that we would expect that spread to go up once Port Neal comes online because we're adding about 1.4 million tons in market that's going to have a $30, $40 a ton premium associated with it because that's a transportation costs from the Gulf. The work, that kinds of gives you a general sense of kind of the premium to the Gulf that we will expect. In addition, although ammonia is a little bit different animal because of the volume that's available out there in the deepwater market, we would expect UAN premium to come back in line with urea, and we can switch back and forth between granulating more or producing more solutions, depending upon where that premium sits to the extent that you don't get the corresponding bump that you would expect in UAN will ship the product mix. So I think over the medium to long term, those things have to come back into rough kind of equilibrium otherwise. The producers shift the mix and the end values have to trade sort of at a minimum on parity with very likely UAN continuing to command a premium the way it has.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could comment on the weakness in industrial NIM you cited in your release. i assume some of that's phosphate, but is there anything worth highlighting in the DEF market? And on DEF, do you have any updated thoughts on how that market dema
componenttext: I was hoping you could comment on the weakness in industrial NIM you cited in your release. i assume some of that's phosphate, but is there anything worth highlighting in the DEF market? And on DEF, do you have any updated thoughts on how that market demand evolves over time?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in the -- when we mentioned the weakness, it's more of the weakness in the ammonia price structure and why that was driven more in relation to the contractual structure of our industrial book of business, which is a gas based as well as Tampa base
componenttext: Yes. So in the -- when we mentioned the weakness, it's more of the weakness in the ammonia price structure and why that was driven more in relation to the contractual structure of our industrial book of business, which is a gas based as well as Tampa based, and Tampa is very low. Demand has been a little bit lower in the Industrial segment due to some of the issues around capital and phosphate. I think this is just more of additional phosphates exports out of China has put a little pressure on some of the phosphate producers in terms of overall volumes and possible changes in mix as moving some to micronutrients, as Mosaic mentioned, away from possibly that. So weakness, it's just that I don't think it's anything we're concerned about and our volumes are, we think, it's going to hold steady. Regarding DEF, we're very more positive. What's going with the DEF market, continued demand. We're going to have a record year on DEF volume. Pricing is holding up. We're continuing to see the growth of the 30% to 40% that we have seen year-on-year. I do think that's due to this slight slowdown in shipments. You have probably seen the Class 8 truck volume, the new truck volume slowing down a little bit on that end, but you do have additional demand coming from off-road as well as different segments. So we're positive on the DEF front and continue to invest and grow and build the team and participate in that business.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And just a follow-up question on ammonia significant nitrogen equivalent discount to urea and UAN that you were discussing. Do you see this having any meaningful impact on how you supply nitrogen? Are there any early reads on direct applicati
componenttext: Okay. Great. And just a follow-up question on ammonia significant nitrogen equivalent discount to urea and UAN that you were discussing. Do you see this having any meaningful impact on how you supply nitrogen? Are there any early reads on direct application demand for ammonia versus demand for urea and UAN resulting from the lower prices?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's something important to remember here, which is the ammonia price when it's weak is primarily affects the industrial demand that Bert was talking about. In order to be able to get ammonia into the farmer's field, you have to have a place to move it
componenttext: There's something important to remember here, which is the ammonia price when it's weak is primarily affects the industrial demand that Bert was talking about. In order to be able to get ammonia into the farmer's field, you have to have a place to move it to. And it's not like urea where you can just leave it on a rail car, put it on a shed kind of thing. In UAN, there's a lot of availability of tank space. With ammonia, you got -- you have to have a big cryogenic storage tanks and there's principally only 3 companies and they're the producers that own those. CF has got the largest network of the ammonia tank terminal system. Coke has got some and has got some. And then there's 1 to 2 Z tanks, given they are that owned by other people at Trammell, and so forth. But if you don't have the storage terminals, then you can't take Gulf ammonia up into the marketplace and get it in the hands of the farmers because you got no place to move it through. And so even though there is some impact in terms of agricultural demand or agricultural price [indiscernible] for ammonia, it's not directly tied to Tampa ammonia the way urea price in the Midwest is tied to NOLA urea price. So that's one of the reasons why [indiscernible] new terminal system that we've got in ammonia is so valuable because it allows us to capture a pretty sizable spread between the value of agricultural ammonia versus cheap -- relatively cheap deepwater ammonia.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Relative to your question on demand and changes in demand patterns, we've experienced 2 [indiscernible] '14 and '15 that were below expectations and below normal, but that was weather-driven. And then we experienced 2 record springs in '15 and '16. And so
componenttext: Relative to your question on demand and changes in demand patterns, we've experienced 2 [indiscernible] '14 and '15 that were below expectations and below normal, but that was weather-driven. And then we experienced 2 record springs in '15 and '16. And so, as I mentioned earlier, when you look at 10- to 30-day forecast, we see some positive developments in all of our terminal regions, even up in Canada which we received snow in October. In limited applications, we see that drying out and temperatures staying in the 50s in the afternoon, allowing applications to accelerate. And when you look at, as a farmer, for corn, you have a number of options for an application thereof. For ammonia, traditionally, the pass was 180 pounds per acre and you put it on the fall and you plant it in the spring and off you go. That has changed with the different economic prescriptions, and so we have seen a little bit less supply in the fall and then pick up an additional application in the spring. 2, 3 and 4 stage applications, a combination of ammonia, maybe Cyprus ammonia, or UAN, UAN top-dress or even flying over with urea. Each of those are positive for us. And so we do see ammonia in the fall as a component to good ergonomic corn practices and we see that continuing.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Roberts from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Roberts from UBS.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about getting back to investment grade. I'm sure your creditors pressured you on the dividend here through these discussions. Can you get back to investment grade without adjusting the dividend? And then once you get back to a free cash flow po
componenttext: You talked about getting back to investment grade. I'm sure your creditors pressured you on the dividend here through these discussions. Can you get back to investment grade without adjusting the dividend? And then once you get back to a free cash flow positive again, is that a priority over buybacks? Or how do you think about the priority?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, John, on the dividend, if you look at our balance sheet, we had almost $1.6 billion of cash on the balance sheet. We've got an undrawn revolver. We've got $800 million of cash coming to us next year in the form of a tax refund. And so that's the
componenttext: Yes. So, John, on the dividend, if you look at our balance sheet, we had almost $1.6 billion of cash on the balance sheet. We've got an undrawn revolver. We've got $800 million of cash coming to us next year in the form of a tax refund. And so that's the $4 one of operating profit. And so the problem is not from an investment-grade standpoint, the dividend or liquidity situation. We have plenty of cash. The issue is all around in the near term, the pricing environment and the EBITDA generation relative to the aggregate amount of debt that we've got outstanding on the business. And so change the dividend, don't change the dividend, it doesn't have a meaningful impact in terms of that particular metric. And that's why we've worked really hard on the credit facility to make sure that we've got the flexibility that allows us to continue paying the dividend going forward because that's an important element for the equity holders. And so our focus is to get back to investment grade, and we are planning, as Dennis articulated earlier, to retire the debt that comes due 2018. That's $800 million. And so we'll be delevering at that point. That will certainly help. And then as we move into price recovery and the factor about that time, we expect that will help as well. So we're going through a short duration situation here and -- but it's not really dividend intended. Dennis.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's right.
componenttext: No, I think that's right.

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, the industry obviously has a very high level of M&A activity underway. You've been a participant in the pat. What are your current thoughts around the industry consolidation?
componenttext: And then secondly, the industry obviously has a very high level of M&A activity underway. You've been a participant in the pat. What are your current thoughts around the industry consolidation?

headline: CF Industries Holdings, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think consolidation, generally speaking, is constructive force. It allows for kind of rational behavior, and in general, there's some synergies to be had. So I think it's in that kind of natural consequence of things when you go through the cycl
componenttext: I mean, I think consolidation, generally speaking, is constructive force. It allows for kind of rational behavior, and in general, there's some synergies to be had. So I think it's in that kind of natural consequence of things when you go through the cyclical troughs periods like we're going right now. So let me back to one question or the second half of the question you asked earlier, which is, is our preference dividend or share repurchase? As a general theme, we'd like to maintain the dividend. We don't want to be in a situation where we are reducing that, but I think on a day in, day out basis for consistent and timely return of capital back to shareholders, our bias is towards share repurchase. We think that tends to be a more efficient vehicle to do that one.
